ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES

CANADA
The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa

Re: Indian day-schools in Bishop Coudert's diocese.

Attention: Mr. Phelan.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

I am in receipt of a letter from His Excellency Bishop J. Coudert, O.M.I., of White Horse, in which he urges that the teachers' salaries as well as the rent for the school buildings, at Burwash Landing, Teslin, Dease Lake and Klappan, be paid as soon as possible.

He has forwarded the T.D. 1A Tax Deduction Exemption Claim, duly signed by each school teacher and invoices covering the rent of each building.

One of his missionaries, the Reverend Father Carpentier, of Telegraph Creek, had to spend almost $1900.00 in relief for the Indians of his district and it is principally for this purpose that the Bishop urges that these bills be taken care of immediately, so that he will be in a position to reimburse this relief money. Reverend Father Carpentier bought these relief supplies from the Hudson's Bay Stores at Telegraph Creek and Dease Lake and the Bishop is anxious to pay the Company as soon as possible. Your early attention to this matter will certainly please the Bishop very much and will be of great help to him.

Thanking you in anticipation, I remain,

Yours very truly,

J.O. Plourde, O.M.I.
VICARIATE APOSTOLIC OF WHITEHORSE

P.O.B.95
Whitehorse,Y.T.

January 19,1946

Philip Phelan,Chief
Training Division
Indian Affairs Branch
Ottawa

Dear Mr.Phelan;

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your communication of January 16,and call your attention to the following explanations:

1.- Re Salary of our School Teachers.-In my letter of January 7 to Father O.PLourde I did not make any claim about the salary of our school teachers.-I am satisfied with the mode of payment the Branch has adopted lately,viz.,to pay our teachers through my office through a cheque made out directly payable to them.I perfectly well understand that such a cheque should not be issued unless the Branch has previously received the requested reports on the work for which they are to be paid.-Actually I have no complaint on the part of any of our teachers,and I think that all have received the cheques corresponding to their work of last summer.

2.-Re Rent of our Mission Houses for School purposes and payment of other Services around such Schools.-The Bills I sent you through Father Plourde on January 2nd referred to the Rent of our Mission Buildings,belonging to our Corporation and which are being used for School purposes by the Branch;they also refer to some other services as wood cutting and janitor's services to the same schools;I consider those services as an extra imposition on our missionaries.By special agreement with said missionaries,it was decided that I would collect that money personally,for the benefit of the whole Corporation.This is the reason why I sent you aforesaid bills.

If you remember we discussed that matter together last May,and I was instructed through Father Plourde to send in at the end of the year our bills for both Rent of our School Buildings and Other Outside Services to said Schools(besides the regular salary,of course).-In the making of said Bills I followed exactly the Model Forms suggested to me,and the amount mentioned was also the amount I was promised at the time.

3.- Correction of said Bills.-I admit,however,that I made some mistakes in the making of those bills,owing to the lack of proper informations.Several of our missionaires being actually here in Whitehorse for their annual retreat,I was able with their help to correct some of said mistakes;your own notes have proved also very valuable to me.

Re Burwash Landing; Father E.Morisset has taught at Burwash Landing January,February,April,June and July;he has also taught in October,November and December;you will receive shortly the School Reports for these last three months;they have been duly sent in,at the end of December,to the Acting Agent in Dawson.

Therefore:The Rent for said School and other Services rendered should cover eight months,instead of six,as in my previous report.
VICARIATE APOSTOLIC OF WHITEHORSE

Re: Dease Lake.—Father Cl. Carpentier has taught in Dease Lake up to Feb. 16 of last year, and therefore, occupied our buildings for School purposes and used them up to that date. However, as the School was not approved for a period extending beyond January 31st, Father Carpentier thought it useless to send a report for the two extra weeks he taught.

Similarly last Fall, Father Cl. Carpentier went to Dease Lake for the purpose of conducting the School; he stayed there from the beginning of October to the middle of November; some four children attended the school, the other Indians having gone down to the Alaska Highway last summer and having failed to come back for the winter. I instructed Father Carpentier to send in a report of the time he had taught to those four children, since he had gone purposely to Dease Lake to conduct school, but he has been reluctant to do so under the circumstances, and I doubt whether he will turn in any report for such a short period of teaching and for so few pupils.

Yet our buildings were used just the same during the stated periods for school purposes, and I think that it would be only fair that we receive at least the money covering the rent and other extra services, which were practically the same for four children as they would have been for twenty.

Therefore I still maintain my previous claim for three months of rent at Dease Lake and other additional services (fuel and janitor's work) for the Year 1945.

Re: Klappan.—Regarding my previous report for the Rent of the Building and other services for the Klappan School, I got somewhat confused over the months during which our buildings were occupied for that purpose, on account of the interruption caused last winter by Father Tanguay's sad accident. I applied for a rent of four months (as it should have been normally), while, actually, it appears from your school reports that our buildings were occupied there only three months, viz. from January 25 to March 9, and from April 1st to May 15.

Therefore; the Rent for our school buildings and other services at Klappan School should cover only three months.

Re: Liard Post.—I also made a mistake of half a month for August, not being aware that Father Forget was unable to teach the last half month of the term for lack of pupils who had all gone back to the woods.

Therefore; the Rent for our School Buildings and other services at Liard Post should cover two months and a half, viz June, July and half of August, instead of three months.

Re: Teslin Lake.—My previous report was correct. (Rent for three months, viz June, July and August).

As you will notice from this corrected report, it practically correspond to the report I had previously sent to you; I had forgotten two months for
VICARIATE APOSTOLIC OF WHITEHORSE

Burwash, and I had charged you one month and a half too much for Klappan and Liard Post, or even two months (if the Branch refuses to consider my claim for the extra time taught at Dease Lake). All in all it corresponds sensibly to the bills I submitted, and I would have been perfectly satisfied if you had settled it at once the way I had it.

Hoping that the above detailed explanations will prove satisfactory I remain,

Dear Mr. Phelan,

Yours sincerely in Christ

J.L. Coudert O.M.I.

P.S.- I am forwarding copy of this communication to Father O. Plourde. He will provide you with the corrected Bills, if new Bills are necessary.

Dear Sir:

Re: Alaska Highway Abandoned Camps.
File 16/3/5.

1. The Headquarters, North West Highway System, advises that Father E. Morrisset, OMI, Missionary for Catholic Missions of the Yukon, Whitehorse, has requested the allocation of a building from the abandoned camp at Mile Post 937 on the Alaska Highway for the purpose of establishing an Indian Mission and school at Mile Post 985.

2. I shall be glad if you will take this matter up with Father Morrisset and, after having done so, advise whether you wish the allocation of the buildings, which are apparently surplus to the requirements of the Highway organization at this time. Should you wish the buildings for departmental purposes, I shall arrange to have them declared surplus and advise War Assets that they are required by your Department.

Yours truly,

L.H. Phinney,
Acting Special Commissioner.

CC to: Lt. Col. R. Rowley
AIRMAIL

Ottawa, May 13, 1946.

Dear Bishop Coudert:

I attach, for your information a letter which has just been received and which explains itself. Please let me know if the building that Father Morisset has requested is at a new place or if it is at one of the places where authority has already been given for the operation of a seasonal school.

While I have no doubt that Father Morisset is acting under your instructions, I might point out that it would be much more satisfactory to us if all such communications were handled through your office instead of by individual Missionaries.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

P.O.B.95 - Whitehorse,Y.T.
May 17,1946

Mr.Philip Phelan
Chief Training Division
Indian Affairs Branch
Department of Mines and Resources
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr.Phelan;

Referring to your communication dated May 13 concerning the application made by Father L.Morisset to L.H.Phinney, Acting Special Commissioner, for the acquisition of some building material from the abandoned Camp at Mile Post 937, I beg to say that there seems to have been a little misunderstanding over this matter.

1.- Father Morisset was duly authorized by me to look for some building material towards the erection of a Mission Building at Mile Post 935, which is located in his missionary district.

For the past five years the Indians located at that point have asked us over and over again to open up a Mission Outpost in their camp; and it is, therefore, at their own urgent request that we have finally decided to do so.

We have given them plainly to understand that no School could be approved by the Branch until they have enough children of the Catholic Faith to warrant such an approval.

2.- The Officials approached by Father Morisset, knowing the wonderful work done by Father Morisset in behalf of the Indians, have naturally thought that the building material requested could be released more easily through the Branch, since it was finally intended for the welfare of the Indians. I admit, however, that our present purpose is mainly concerned with the religious and moral uplift of those Indians, who have been sadly neglected in the past. Some had some affiliation with the Church of England in the past; others still belong to the Russian Church, and a few still adhere to their native belief.

3.- If, therefore, the Branch cannot see its way clear to have the requested building released to our Mission free of charge for our purpose, kindly instruct Mr.L.H.Phinney, the Acting Special Commissioner, to take this matter up with the Sales Department of the War Asset Commission, 309 Taylor Bldg., Edmonton, Alta., where the Camp referred to, at Mile Post 937, is located.

VICARIATE APOSTOLIC OF WHITEHORSE

937 is officially acknowledged as abandoned. I think that with a word of recommendation on your part and that of Mr. L.H. Phinney, we might be able to obtain at a reasonable price from the War Asset Corporation the desired building material for our intended work for the welfare of the Indians of Mile Post 935.

Yours sincerely in Christ

[Signature]

J.J. Coudert O.M.I., Bishop of Rhodiapolis
Vicar Apostolic of Whitehorse
Ottawa, May 30, 1946.

Re: Alaska Highway Abandoned Camps.

Dear Mr. Phinney:

On receipt of your letter of May 7, in connection with the above, this Department communicated with Right Reverend J. L. Coudert, O.M.I., Vicar Apostolic of Whitehorse, and I have just received his reply.

Bishop Coudert would appreciate receiving, free of charge, the allocation of a building from the abandoned camp at Mile Post 937 on the Alaska Highway for the purpose of using it at Mile Post 985. The building would be used by Bishop Coudert for the welfare of the Indians in that vicinity and, consequently, if transfer free of charge can be arranged, it would meet with this Department's approval.

However, if it is not possible to transfer it free of charge, I would appreciate it if you would recommend to the Sales Department of the War Assets Corporation, 309 Tegler Building, Edmonton, Alberta, that the building be sold to Bishop Coudert at a reasonable cost, in view of the welfare purpose for which it will be used.

Yours sincerely,

L. H. Phinney,
Acting Special Commissioner
For Defence Projects in Northwest Canada,
9937 - 103 Street,
Edmonton, Alberta.

COPY SENT TO BISHOP COUDERT.
June 15th, 1946.

Commander,
Northwest Highway System,
Whitehorse, Y.T.

Dear Sir:

Ref: Building from Abandoned Camp, Mile 937 for use by Bishop Coudert.

1. I have a letter from the Director, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, asking whether it is possible to get a building from the abandoned camp at Mile 937 for the Right Reverend J.L. Coudert, Vicar Apostolic of Whitehorse. Bishop Coudert wishes to move this building to Mile 935 and use it as a welfare station in his Indian work.

2. If you are prepared to release this building will you kindly say so and I shall then recommend a quick sale by War Assets Corporation.

3. Bishop Coudert is in Whitehorse.

4. I am asking Bishop Coudert to get in touch with your office.

Yours truly,

L. H. Finney,
Acting Special Commissioner.

ccs Mr. R.A. Hoey,
Rt. Rev. J.L. Coudert.
VICARIATE APOSTOLIC OF WHITEHORSE

Colonel Bernard F. Neary, Superintendent
Welfare and Training
Indian Affairs Branch
Department of Mines and Resources
Ottawa

P.O.B.95
Whitehorse,Y.T.

December 15,1946

Re: School Teachers for Seasonal Schools at
Burwash Landing, Teslin, in Yukon Agency
Lower Post, Klappan, Sheasley, in Stikine Agency
Prophet, in Fort St John Agency

Dear Mr. Neary;

I am sending you herewith the names of our Missionaries proposed
as School Teachers in the above mentioned Seasonal Schools for our Catholic
Indian Children of the Yukon, the Stikine and Fort St John Agencies, for the
Year 1947, viz.,

1.-Burwash Landing,Y.T.(6 months)...Rev.E.Morisset O.M.I.
2.-Teslin,Y.T.(June,July,August)...Rev.B.Arsenault O.M.I.
3.-Lower Post,B.C.(June,July,August)...Rev.Jos.Forget O.M.I.
4.-Sheasley,B.C.(October,Nov.Decemb.)...Rev.Jos.Forget O.M.I.
5.-Klappan,B.C.(Jan.Febr.Mar.Apr.)...Rev.Ed.Turenne O.M.I.
6.-Prophet,B.C.(Oct.Nov.Dec.Jan.)...Rev.J.P.Tanguay O.M.I.

I have received your recent Application Forms for Employment in
our Indian Day Schools; I am forwarding same to our Teachers; they may be
some time before being returned on account of the difficulties of commu-
nication with some of our missions in winter time.-I may assure you, meanwhile,
that all the above mentioned missionaries have made their complete college
course in Canada, in colleges affiliated either to the Laval University or
to the Ottawa University; all have made their philosophical course and theo-
logical course in Scholasticates affiliated to the Ottawa University; most
of them have their M.A. and their B.A.

Yours sincerely in Christ

J.L.Coudert O.M.I.Vic.Ap.of Whitehorse

P.S.-Kindly send me some Forms T.D.1A to be filled by our Missiona-
ries for Tax Deduction at the source, if still necessary; I am out of them.

Our Fathers of Teslin, Burwash, Lower Post complain that they
have not yet received their salary for their work of last Summer; I am going
to instruct them from now on to send in their reports directly to Ottawa.

Indian Affairs (RG 10 Volume 6478, file 934-1, part 1)
Ottawa, 18 December 1946.

Rt. Rev. J.L. Coudert, O.M.I.,
Vicar Apostolic of Whitehorse,
P.O. Box 95,
WHITEHORSE, Yukon.

Dear Bishop Coudert:

We have your letter of the 15th instant advising us regarding the names of the teachers who will be in charge of the Indian seasonal schools in your Diocese during the calendar year 1947. Enclosed is a supply of T.D. 1A forms.

Today we received from Rev. E. Morisset, O.M.I., a return showing the attendance at the Burwash Landing school during the months of June and July, 1946. Payment of salary will be made to him at the same rate as last year.

Please have the teachers at Teslin and Lower Post forward their returns direct to this office so that payment of their salary can be made.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Schooling appears to have received a minimum attention—particularly during the war years. Only one residential school is situated in this Agency, at Carcross. One Roman Catholic day school functions all winter, at Burwash Landing, while the Church of England have year round day schools at Moosehide and Fort Selkirk. Re. H. Lee, a non-denominational protestant minister, requested permission to open a day school for Indian In Whitehorse and the matter was referred to Welfare and Training. It is strongly recommended that this school be given recognition.

R.J. MEEK
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,

Ottawa.

Attention: Mr. P. Phelan.
Re: Burwash Landing Day-School, Y.T.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Reverend Father E. Morrisset in charge of the above school states that he only receives biscuits for the noon meal of his school children and would appreciate receiving chocolate or cocoa as well as any other kind of food with which you might want to supplement the present ration.

May I suggest that you review the cases of all the schools conducted by our Missionaries in the same Territory and add whatever you may think necessary to the present menu that is being served to the children attending their several schools.

Yours very truly,

J. O. Plourde, O.M.I.
November 23, 1948.

Rev. J.O. Plourde, O.M.I.,
University of Ottawa,
Laurier Avenue East,
Ottawa.

Dear Father Plourde:

We have your letter of the 13th instant regarding the Burwash Landing Day School.

As I have pointed out to you on previous occasions, it is not our practice to supply unlimited quantities of food for mid-day meal purposes due to the payment of family allowances.

The next time you are in the office we will discuss the matter further.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan
Chief, Education Division.

Miss Sarah Ann Dougall,
Teacher,
Mayo Indian Day School,
Mayo, Yukon.

Dear Miss Dougall:

Your letter of August 4th has raised questions which have required discussion with officials in other Departments and which also require further correspondence with Mr. Indian Agent Meek through whose office all official Government business is done.

I am sorry that a number of matters in regard to Mayo have not been finalized but here is an unofficial indication of what you may expect. I shall summarize your questions and give the answers I have obtained as follows:

1. Unemployment Insurance Book: Teachers do not contribute. You should keep the book in case you change your employment.

2. House Furnishings for Teachers: The Branch supplies all the reasonable requirements. You should send the Agent a list of what you require indicating what is available in local stores. He will nominate the dealer and arrange the purchase, forwarding the bills and vouchers to Ottawa for payment. For the time being please limit your requirements for kitchenware to whatever is necessary to serve meals to yourself and one guest.

3. Fuel and Light: The Department supplies these subject to arrangements by the Agent who will probably wish to buy wood from the Indians. Fuel for lamps is to be ordered from the local dealer and vouchered by the Agent in the usual manner.
4. Cost of Transportation: The Department makes no allowance to teachers and I know of no reduction fare. As a special concession to you, you will draw your salary from the date you left Whitehorse direct for Mayo. Your actual teaching duties will, accordingly, be rather light for the first few weeks.

5. Adapting the Church to School Purposes: Reverend Mr. Wareham will indicate what the Church will allow. You should ask local tradesmen to give estimates and air mail these to the Agent who will order the work done and forward the bills and vouchers to Ottawa. Twenty-four new desks have been ordered which, with the Church benches, will rather crowd the accommodation. For the present please, keep the changes to the Church to a minimum as the Curriculum for the next year or two will be of such an elementary nature that it should be possible to carry on in a make-shift classroom.

6. Tables and Cupboards to be Constructed Locally: The action which you have taken can somehow be squared with the procedure indicated in number five. These articles with the teacher's desk and chair which have been ordered will almost make it necessary to remove most of the church furniture while school is in session.

7. Dispensary: On this subject, the Director of Indian Health Services is to correspond with the Agent.

8. Welfare Work: The Chief of the Welfare Division is to correspond with the Agent on this subject.

9. Janitor: We have found that the most satisfactory arrangement is to make an allowance for the janitor work, the money for which is paid upon receipt of a voucher. Actually, the money is paid to the teacher to be distributed at her discretion in quarters and half dollars to those who do the chores ordinarily assigned to a janitor. I think that it is a worthwhile educational activity to have the pupils participate in cleaning up and attending to the school with perhaps, token wages for such work as kindling the fire in the mornings, as this activity requires someone to make an early appearance. As the money allowed for the janitor is usually only about $10.00 a month, it will save paper work to claim for it quarterly.

I am sending you copies of the list of articles, books, etc., which have already been ordered sent to Mayo or which the Agent has been authorized to purchase.
Do you mind if I say that I suspect that your poor opinion of the fertility of the soil may, in part, be inspired by the remarks of some Indians who dislike the idea of working the ground. Reverend J. Martin, as Constable Ivor Mast, R.C.M.P. will tell you, made considerable progress with vegetables and might have transformed much of the Reserve if a flood and his fatal illness has not intervened. If gardening is handled as a school subject related to language and arithmetic, the attitude of the younger Indians might be changed.

If it is any comfort to you, may I say that the Indians on the hills surrounding the garden city of San Diego, California are in an even worse condition than some of our Yukon bands. In a former era with the leadership of the Mission, they had a prosperous agricultural economy. Now they lack leadership and vegetables.

Please give my regards to the Warehams and be assured that we appreciate, in part, at least, the efforts required to do successful church and school work in places like those where you live.

Yours most sincerely,

C.A.F. Clark,
Educational Survey Officer.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Mayo Indian Day School, Yukon Territory.

During the past ten years, whenever missionary-teachers of the Church of England were available, the Department supported a seasonal school on the Mayo Indian Reserve.

Officials of this Branch surveyed the situation in May of this year and have reported the need and the desire for better school facilities.

Arrangements have been made with the church authorities to rent buildings which, with minor alterations to be made by this Branch, are considered suitable for a school and a teacherage.

RATIONS - INDIAN DAY SCHOOL TEACHERS

At some of the settlements in the Northwest Territories the assortment of groceries and provisions available for purchase is rather limited. In many cases, the stocks are meagre and there is little variety in the items offered.

To overcome this situation and as a measure of assistance to the teachers, arrangements have been made with the Hudson's Bay Company to have requisitions for rations filled at Edmonton and shipped directly to the individual teacher.

The Nutrition Division of the Department of National Health and Welfare has prepared a ration list of the items required for one person living for one year in the North. We have secured approximate prices as quoted by the Hudson's Bay Company in Edmonton. Attached is this list, with the prices, of course, being subject to variation.

On the basis of this list the teacher may then prepare an order and forward same to this office. We will then place the order with a wholesale grocery firm in Edmonton and the items will be shipped by water transportation. The cost at wholesale price of the rations purchased in this manner on behalf of the teacher, together with transportation charges on same will be deducted on a monthly basis from the living allowance paid to northern employees of the Department. The maximum that can be deducted from the Northern Living Allowance is $7.4 a month (i.e.) $350.00 for Day School Teachers and $26.00 from Welfare Teachers. In cases where the cost of the rations and transportation charges is in excess of the above possible deductions, the teacher will be obliged to pay the difference.

The requisition showing the requirements must reach Ottawa prior to March 15, 1950, complete with express address and shipping instructions to ensure delivery during the navigation season.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Your letter of March 22nd, file 166-9-5 (E.I.), re voucher 449, for $30.00 for transporting supplies from Mayo to Mayo Indian Day School.

I immediately took up this matter with Miss S.A. Dougall, our School Teacher at that reserve, who replies as follows:

"W.R. Gordon transported supplies only by gas boat."

It is my error that I assumed the supplies were taken down by dog team, as the Stewart River is usually frozen over by that time. It may be, however, that the date of Mr. Gordon's account, November 29th, may not be the date on which he did the freighting, but simply date of account.

I cannot find where the account was submitted previously, and it is not understood why Mr. Gordon states "For which work I received your cheque." Substituting the words "by dog team" for "by gas boat" would correct voucher No. 449. But I am not able to explain how Mr. Gordon was paid twice for transporting supplies to the Indian School.

(R.J. Meek)

Superintendent of Education.
Re Mayo Landing Indian Day School. During a recent visit to Mayo an inspection of the school was carried out and has already been reported to you. A much larger enrollment than was anticipated has crowded existing accommodation to such an extent that efficiency and comfort are being impaired.

A meeting of the adults of the village was held on May 19th, and the question of a new school was brought forward. The present building housing the school is the Church of England building, which, with a minimum of alteration, has been adapted for use as a schoolroom. It is not suitable. We are paying the Diocese of the Yukon a rental of $30.00 per teaching month for the use of the church, and also the teacherage. The latter building has been repaired and altered, it is very suitable for present requirements.

Figures for initial work on a new school measuring 40' x 30' are as follows: with a ceiling of 9', about 120 logs needed, these can be obtained upriver from Mayo; a team of horses could be hired with harness and equipment for $5.00 per day, to haul logs to water, and again at Mayo, out of the water to the proposed site; six days hire, $30.00; four men could easily cut the required logs and place them on the site in 7 days, at the rate of $1.00 per hour 8 hours a day, total $224.00; charter of gas boat for one day $25.00 gasoline $15.00; cost of digging cellar 10' x 15', 8' deep, $50.00. Total: $344.00. This would simply mean the bare walls and roof poles, all interior work would be extra.

An appropriation of $350.00 for building exterior of new school would be well advised. Fortunately there is a sawmill at Mayo and building lumber could easily be obtained for all ordinary purposes.

I am advised by Miss S. Dougall, Welfare Teacher at Mayo Indian Day School that she has not received payment for account submitted for lumber used in School greenhouse, Mayo, Y.T.

Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Your letter of November 5, 1948, file 935-5 ( ), re Mayo Indian Day School. Unfortunately the lumber mills at Mayo shut down for the winter and no information could be obtained until quite recently.

The Mayo Lumber Co. is in a position to supply rough green lumber at $90.00 per M. They do not recommend the use of this lumber for a permanent building as it is neither kiln nor air dried.

For a satisfactory job of the proposed school building, it is recommended that all lumber come from Outside. I would suggest that one of the Vancouver lumber mills be the best source of supply. There is no lumber dealer in Whitehorse at the present time.

I regret the delay in replying to your letter, but until very recently no authoritative person at Mayo could be interviewed.

(R.J. Meek)

New School at Mayo, Y.T.:

This structure is intended to replace the temporary classroom operating in the Anglican Church. It is desired to reserve the church building for religious purposes.

The teacher will continue to live in the present residence, and so it is not presently necessary to build a teacherage.

It is proposed to build a log building for a classroom. A plan for this building was drawn up, but it would be well to compare this with plans for the completed buildings at Alexis or Nordegg before making a final decision as to plan and specifications.

The logs have been obtained, but their number and measurements should be verified to ensure that they will be adequate for the plan adopted. To secure a building of adequate length, "splicing" of logs may be necessary, i.e., logs of 24 ft. in length may have to have a twelve-foot piece added to them. This process does not affect the strength of the walls.

You will recall that funds to get out the logs had to be obtained by transfer as nothing had at that time been voted. I do not recall seeing an item in the estimates for building this school during 1949-1950. I note, however, that building materials have been ordered at Vancouver as follows:

Purchase Order No. 13940G $749.05
" 13942G 627.80

As the logs cost over $400, and no work can be done now until spring (well after April 1st, 1950) it will be necessary to re-vote additional funds to complete this project. Just how much money should be voted will depend upon the plan which Mr. Gooderham recommends.

It is intended to employ Indians with an Indian ("Charlie") as foreman. The teacher, Miss Dougall, may be able to do the paper work and accounting.

As at Roseau River, Man., this area may sometimes flood. The school should be higher off the ground.

C.A.F. Clark

Reference your letter of November 18th, 1949, file 935-5 (El) regarding the present situation at Mayo. Miss S.A. Dougall, teacher, advises that the basement measuring 30 x 40, and six feet deep, has been dug. All logs have been cut, ready for construction. Logs designed for the basement have been milled on three sides, which is the custom in this part of the country.

Robert Campbell of Whitehorse, shipped 500 b.f. spruce lumber to Mayo during September. Unfortunately, lumber and Donnacona from Reliance Lumber Co., Vancouver, did not reach Whitehorse until after the close of navigation, and consequently all this material is in the freight sheds at Whitehorse. Spring navigation should open about the last week in May, 1950.

I advised Miss Dougall that our appropriation for the present fiscal year had been exhausted. The Indians of the Mayo Band are not primarily trappers, and are available for construction work until the opening of navigation in late May. May I be advised as early as possible after the beginning of the 1950 - 51 Fiscal Year, if money is available for construction to proceed on the Mayo Day School?

On April 25, last, Mr. Lithgow, Acting Commissioner, of Dawson, was asked to take up the school question in the Yukon with Mr. Bragg, Superintendent of Schools for that territory. Mr. Lithgow now incloses a report from Mr. Bragg, who has just concluded an inspection of all the Indian schools there.

From Mr. Bragg's report it would appear that very little can be done to improve the condition of these Indians by education at present. Mr. Lithgow states that he thinks the money would be much better expended if arrangements could be made to move the whole Indian population back on a reserve near the Peel Indians or somewhere in that country than in attempting to educate them, as their present locations, which are in the proximity of mining and trading towns inhabited by white men, seem to work always to the degradation of the Indians, and the Indians living in the valley of the Yukon are getting to depend more and more on the Government for supplies and assistance, while the Peel Indians are comparatively self-supporting.

There is one school, however, the Carcross Boarding School, which is doing good work, but the building is quite inadequate to the demands made upon it and applications for admission have to be refused on account of lack of space. This is the school for which Bishop Stringer asked assistance in erecting and equipping an adequate building and, judging by the Inspector's report, the Department would be quite justified in expending a sum of money for this purpose in that one locality.

Sir,

I have the honour to submit for your consideration the following report concerning the proposed Industrial School for Indians at Carcross.

In my report to the Department of Indian Affairs last Spring I dealt with the general conditions of the education of the Indians carried on by the various missions of the Church of England, so far as I have been able to observe them, and I beg to draw your attention to that part of my report in which I compared the results obtained at the Moosehide and Selkirk Day schools with the much better results obtained at the Carcross Boarding school. The building in which the latter school has been conducted is wholly inadequate to accommodate satisfactorily even the few pupils who have been placed there, and the equipment is extremely meagre; yet in spite of all the disadvantages, I could not help being impressed most favourably with the progress made and the excellent work that has been done. I feel convinced that such a boarding school is the only satisfactory means of dealing with Indian education in the Yukon Territory, that the ordinary day schools are practically useless, and the energy and money expended in maintaining them are comparatively barren of results. Therefore, if the Department of Indian Affairs is desirous of having efficient educational work done among the Yukon Indians generally, I would beg to recommend that a substantial grant be made for the erection of suitable buildings at Carcross, giving ample accommodation for all Indian children from all parts of this Territory, who would probably be induced to attend an Industrial school.

The work to be provided for in such an industrial school should include, in addition to the ordinary rudiments of a school education, carpentry and gardening for the boys and possibly blacksmithing, and cooking and general domestic service for the girls.

Alexander Henderson, Esq., K.C.
Commissioner, Y.T.
Dawson.
As to building and equipment, I regret that I cannot go into very precise details. I think it would be well to provide accommodation for not less than 35 boarders. The main building should provide for a kitchen, a dining room, two class rooms, three private rooms for the staff and four dormitories, two for the boys and two for the girls with separate entrances, all under one roof. In addition there should be a building for a workshop, laundry and bath separate from the building. It would probably be best for a married man to preside over such a school, and in that case there should be a residence for a principal.

As to approximate cost I think $8,000.00 might be sufficient for suitable buildings if economically spent, but this amount would probably not be sufficient for furnishing as well, for which another thousand dollars might be needed.

If the department of Indian affairs should favor a grant of this nature the money might go further and be used to better advantage if it were put directly under the control of the Bishop of Yukon, who could attend personally to all details of construction and submit to the Government a full report of all expenditure conditions in this country would render it difficult and expensive for Government officials directly to superintend such work.

Regarding the cost of maintenance I regret that I have no data on which I could make at present any recommendation. This matter could be adjusted on the basis of a comparison with the cost of similar institutions in Western Canada, making due allowance for a proportionate increase in the cost of all supplies in this Territory.

In the Department of Indian Affairs should look with favor upon the proposal herein recommended I would respectfully suggest that the matter be dealt with as speedily as possible, so that new buildings may be erected next summer. Suitable accommodation and greater facilities are urgently needed to ensure anything like efficient work on a scale commensurate with the population to be served.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

T.G.Bragg, Superintendent of Schools

Dear Sir:

A number of requests have been made to me by the parents of Half Breed children in Yukon Territory, that these children be admitted to the Carcross Indian Boarding School. I have had to tell them that this is contrary to the regulations of your Department. Over and over again I have been asked to do something for these children, who live in places where there are no school facilities. Parents are able to do very little in the way of financial help, and therefore send them to boarding or other such schools. Unless something is done for these children, they must remain without the advantages of schooling, and they will thus grow up in ignorance.

Only one way occurs to me in which the difficulties could be overcome. Some of the parents could give a small amount towards the upkeep of a school. I shall endeavor also to secure other additional financial aid. It has occurred to me that we might utilize a small log building, which is situated on the homestead acquired by your Department for the Carcross Indian Boarding School. The building would have to be repaired and put into order, and perhaps enlarged by a small addition, but would then give sufficient accommodation for the present, without incurring any great cost.

I know of about half a dozen white men who are married in a regular manner to Indian women, and who apparently intend to spend all their lives in this country, but who because of their employment as hunters, trappers or miners, are not able to take advantage of the white schools. Their
children are practically excluded from the Indian school also. The parents are anxious to have their children educated, and it seems very desirable that something should be done for them.

If this experiment which I now propose, does not prove a success, the arrangement could be cancelled at any time.

Hoping to have a favorable reply from you

I remain,

Yours sincerely,

In accordance with the wish of your Department, I visited Carcross, Yukon Territory, on June 20th, 21st and 22nd last and the Indian School on the afternoon of June 21st, and I have to report as follows:

Immediately upon my arrival in Carcross I was visited by a number of the people of the town who had many complaints to make as to the manner in which the School was being conducted, and as some of these were persons whom I felt were sincere and had the well being of the school at heart, I considered that careful enquiries should be made as to the management.

This school, with an average attendance of 27.38 for March quarter and 24.9 for June quarter, has a staff as follows:

E. D. Evans, Principal.
Mrs. E. D. Evans, Matron.
F. Harding, Farmer.
Mrs. F. Harding, Cook.
Miss F. Hutchison, Teacher.

This, in my estimation, appears to be too large for the attendance, and the present facilities for handling the pupils.

The Principal, prior to his engagement by the school, was employed on Indian work in Alaska, and it is doubtful whether he has had any experience in Industrial School

Of Indian Affairs,

School work.

Mr. Harding, who is supposed to be the farmer, is an ex navy man, and prior to his engagement, had only been in this country a few weeks.

Miss Hutcheson, the teacher, has been with the school for a number of years.

Complaints were made that the pupils had not been receiving sufficient nourishment, and from that cause, they were developing tubercular troubles, and I found, upon investigation, that these complaints were, during the winter, well founded, and I found that the pupils were not receiving, at the time of my visit, the nourishment to which they were entitled.

The Missionary Society supplied this school with a cow and a number of hens, and prior to my arrival, milk and eggs were being sold regularly in the village, and the Principal told me that the children did not care for either milk or eggs, and as they could not use them all themselves, they sold the surplus. This, however, was not borne out by my investigation, as I found that the children were given to understand that they could not have these things, and that they must say that they did not care for them. This, to my mind, was not very creditable to the management, and I informed the Principal that the selling of milk and eggs must stop immediately, and that the children must receive whatever eggs and milk were produced.

I found that during May and June the Principal bought, in Skagway, Alaska, the following articles, from funds supplied by the church authorities for the maintenance of the
the school:

May 11th, 3 Rugs and duty upon same, $74.25
June 10th, Second hand Printing outfit, $350.00

The printing outfit is entirely unnecessary and useless and is of no benefit to the school in any way, and the money paid for its should have been used in supplying nourishment for the children.

The heating of the school was also the cause of much comment and I found that during all of last winter the temperature had been kept much higher than was necessary and that the children suffered physically from confinement in overheated rooms and lack of ventilation, and at the time of my visit, in June, although the weather was exceedingly fine and the temperature about 70, a fire was being maintained in the furnace and all of the children were sleeping in the dormitories, although the boys were specially anxious to go into camp, as had been their custom at the old school.

In going over the list of pupils furnished me under your letter of July 4th, and covering the attendance for March quarter, I am informed that No.29, J. H. Adams, is an American Indian boy, and comes from Eagle, Alaska, and that No's. 022 Annie de Wolfe, and 023, M. Anderson, are both half breeds and come from the vicinity of Twelve Mile, which is some distance below Dawson, and if such is the case, these names should not appear upon the attendance report for the payment of grant.

Upon my visit to the school I found everything about the school building tidy and clean, although the dormitories bore evidence of having been prepared for my visit.
visit. The furnishings supplied by the Department had not yet arrived.

The ground under cultivation had not been extended, and only that portion which had been previously cultivated was being worked, and with the present staff, some considerable amount of clearing should have been done to prepare for an extension of the farm and vegetable gardens.

Upon my return to Carcross, in October, I was unable to visit the school building, and I cannot say whether any improvement in the conditions had taken place since my previous visit, but from reports, I am led to believe that the management is far from being satisfactory.

The recruiting to the school is coming from the Indians who are a long distance from Carcross, and the Indians in the immediate vicinity are taking their children away from the school, and a feeling of distrust in the management is spreading among the Indians, and unless some change is made in the management in the near future, the church authorities will find difficulty in inducing the Indians to allow their children to go to the school.

A complete list of the furnishings in this school belonging to the Government should be furnished by the Principal, in the same manner as Industrial Schools, and the church authorities should be asked to submit a statement of the expenditures at the school, to enable your Department to know how the grant is being used.

Dear Sir—

I wish to acknowledge your communication of Nov. 15th, which followed me up and reached me on my way to Dawson, hence the delay in answering.

In this letter you state that Mr. Stockton, of the Auditor's general Department, who, in the past Summer inspected the Carcross Indian Boarding School, advises the Department, that there, on the roll, two half-breeds, Annie deWolfe and Mary Anderson, Nos. 832 and 833 respectively, and also one American Indian J.H. Adams No. 29 and you ask me for an explanation, referring me to your official letter of July 23rd last, in which you made the statement that "The grant will be paid for the children of regular members of Indian bands in the Yukon only, not for half-breeds."

I wish to inform you that Annie deWolfe and Mary Anderson were discharged from the School in the month of July last, even before your official letter reached Dawson. These girls had been in the school for some time, under the old regime, and were not recently admitted, as your letter would imply. They were not in the school at the time of Mr. Stockton's last visit to Carcross, and in fact were sent home about two months before he left the Territory. He got his information either during his visit to Carcross in June, or else from someone who had inaccurate knowledge of the circumstances.
With reference to J.H. Adams— it is a debatable question, whether he is a Canadian or an American Indian. He was born on the Canadian side, and was baptised by my predecessor, Bishop Bompas, and for some time lived with his people at Forty Mile on the Canadian side of the Boundary. He also lived for a time at Eagle, just across the Boundary, on the American side. I believe his parents are both dead. The tribe of Indians to which he belongs have been going and coming across the Boundary. However, he is now dismissed from the school. I do not know from whom Mr. Stockton got his information, but it would be difficult to prove that he is an American Indian. Many of our Indians live near the Boundary of Alaska, and sometimes hunt and live for longer or shorter periods on the American side. We have no desire to admit children of American parents in to the Carcross Indian School, but sometimes it would be difficult to determine their nationality, and I do not imagine your Department, would wish us to exclude all children who spend part of their time on the Alaskan side, if they can be fairly considered Canadian Indians.

Trusting that the above explanation will be satisfactory,

I remain,

Yours sincerely,

Isaac C. Stringer

Dear Sir:

I wish formally to reply to your communication of December 12th last, with reference to Mr. Stockton's report of the Carcross Indian Boarding School. While in Ottawa in January, I gave a personal explanation on some points, to Mr. Scott. He asked me to give a written answer as well, and the apparent seriousness of some of the complaints, necessitates a written statement. I am sorry my reply has to be rather lengthy, but most of the complaints can be understood only by explaining the surrounding circumstances.

In the first place, certain of the criticisms are necessarily based on personal opinions, and are hard either to prove or disprove. Take for example the complaints that the children were not receiving sufficient nourishment, and that the building was kept too hot, and was poorly ventilated. I believe Mr. Stockton spent only two or three hours at the school, and so far as his personal observations were concerned, I am quite willing to accept his criticisms, and have tried to profit by them, and by the information received therefrom. But possibly his judgment in the various matters referred to, was based to a considerable extent, on the complaints made by the Carcross people, who, as he says met him on his arrival, and who made a point of stating things derogatory to the management of the school. Probably some of these people believed certain exaggerated stories that were in circulation, and I have no wish to judge them harshly. But I cannot forget that some of the same people criticised just as severely, the former management. Reports regarding the lack of food supplied the children, have been made periodically ever since the school was founded. Take an illustration—When I arrived in Carcross in January of this year, a committee representing the white population called on me, and complained with much emphasis and vehemence, that Archdeacon Janham was starving an Indian boy named Jacob Njootli, who was living with him. So far as I could learn almost the whole white population believed this, and they did not take the trouble to investigate the truth or falsehood of the report. After careful and impartial enquiry, I found the accusation was utterly false and misleading, and I think...
I was able to prove it to the satisfaction of everyone. It was gratifying to have this matter straightened out, and if the people who complained to Mr. Stockton, had come to me when they had an opportunity, or had written me, I could have corrected many misleading and exaggerated reports, and also would have had an opportunity of remedying any defects or mistakes in the conduct of the school.

During the year under criticism, I visited the school three times, spending about two weeks in and around the school on each occasion, and had a better opportunity than any casual visitor, to notice things. I was also quite alive to the possibility hinted at, namely that the best side would be shown for my benefit. However, I knew each pupil, and always have found the children very free in telling me things that happen around the school. I was more anxious than anyone else that the school should be a success in every way. I am quite free to acknowledge that some mistakes were made, and these were pointed out from time to time to the Principal and members of the staff. However from my own observations, and from the observations of others whom I asked to look into the question after certain reports became current, I do not believe the children suffered from lack of nourishment. I always gave emphatic directions that the children should be well fed, no limit was put on the amount of food that was to be supplied to the children, and there could be no motive for starving them. To me and to others whose opinions I obtained, the children appeared to be well nourished. It is a difficult question on which to make an absolute pronouncement, and I merely give my opinion after careful enquiry.

Regarding the question of overheating and lack of ventilation, it is again largely a matter of opinion. I believe that careful attention was always paid to the ventilation, judging from my own observation, and from information gathered through others. With reference to the overheating I accept Mr. Stockton's opinion of what he personally observed, but I emphatically repudiate some of the absurd and exaggerated reports that reached me, and which no doubt, reached him. I know Mr. Evans was particularly anxious during the Winter of 1911-1912 lest the pipes should freeze in cold weather, and at such times kept the fires going all night. Because of outside criticisms, he was less exacting in this direction during this Winter, with the result that the water pipes froze up, entailing...
considerable expense for repairs.

I now come to the more specific complaints:

1st—Mr. Stockton states "That the Missionary Society supplied the school with a cow and a number of hens and prior to his arrival milk and eggs were being sold regularly in the village. The principal told him that the children did not care for milk and eggs and, as they could not use them all themselves, they sold the surplus. This, however, was not borne out by his investigation, as he found that the children were given to understand that they could not have these things and that they must say they did not care for them."

The Missionary Society had nothing to do with the purchase of cow and hens, and gave nothing towards the expense. A few of the hens were given by some friends, the majority I purchased myself as also the cow, thinking they would be profitable investments or would at any rate pay for themselves. I discussed the matter beforehand with the Principal, and his dealings were quite open and above board. On account of the absurd importance given to the question of selling milk and eggs, I have investigated the matter very carefully, with this result:—The cow was a good milker and for a time gave thirteen quarts per day. Some of the children did not care for cow's milk, not an uncommon thing among native and even white children unaccustomed to cows milk. Mr. Evans asked the children if they would rather sell some of the milk, and buy something they liked instead. They said yes they would like that. There were sixty hens, and it was thought best to sell a few of the eggs (fresh) at a good price. He could buy the same kind of eggs as there would be if packed away, at a cheaper price later on. For about three weeks milk and eggs were sold to a very limited extent by the children under the supervision of Mr. Harding, who gave me an itemized statement of the amount of money taken in and how expended. The members of the staff considered it a little industry that was helpful all around till they learned that it was being criticised and then it was dropped. In all the sum of $16.45 was taken in for milk and eggs—five dollars of this was paid towards the freight on the cow and hens and the remainder was spent by the children themselves for jam, maple sugar and other such things which they liked. The statement
to the effect that the children were told to say that they did not care for the milk and eggs seems to have little force under the circumstances. The sale of $16.45 worth of milk and eggs at Carcross prices would not make much difference in the food supply of the school. After a thorough enquiry, I exonerated Mr. Evans and do not consider it a serious offence either in intention or result. The most that could be said in criticism is that it might be considered a lack of judgment, and yet it was heralded from one end of the country to the other as a most serious accusation.

2nd—The complaint that the principal bought in Skagway three rugs and a printing outfit.

The rugs were never charged to the school. Mr. Evans took one, Mr. Harding another, and Rev. W.G. Blackwell of Whitehorse the third as personal property. I fail to see any offence in this transaction and only an enemy could have given Mr. Stockton the information for the purpose of making a complaint. Even if used for and charged to the school it would scarcely be a grievous offence if I became responsible for the payment.

With regard to the Printing Outfit—It was not paid for out of the school funds, and I do not consider it has any necessary connection of spending money in supplying nourishment for the children. Mr. Stockton states that it was entirely unnecessary and useless. It may have been a mistake to procure it just at that time, but the responsibility rests on me, not on the Indian Department, and I can assure you the purchasing of it has not, and will not interfere with the food supply for the children. I have been assured by some who have a considerable knowledge of printing presses, that it will answer our purpose, but I am not an expert on the subject, and it yet remains to be seen as to whether it was a wise investment.

I am pleased that Mr. Stockton found everything about the building clean and tidy. After a casual but careful enquiry, I do not think the staff had time to prepare for his visit as the news of his arrival preceded him only a very short time. Other visitors who came entirely unannounced, have borne out this his one and only recommendation of the staff.

Mr. Stockton states that a large amount of clearing should have been done to prepare for an extension of the farm and vegetable gardens. I did not intend or expect that much should
be done in this direction the first year especially. The ground already cleared is sufficient to keep a man or two busy for the first couple of years till the ground is got into shape. However, I have no fault to find with this criticism as it is a matter of opinion. I hope we may be able to make the best possible use of the ground which can be profitably cultivated.

In answer to the last complaint that recruiting for the school was being done at a distance, I wish to state that such recruiting had no connection with the unpopularity of the management. Most of the school children have come from the Northern part of the Diocese, as our workers have been longer among the Indians of the North, and the parents are more anxious to send their children. It is true that last Summer I brought eight children from some distance, at the earnest request of the parents, during a long itineration, but it was during this long absence that the local criticism became severe and this so called recruiting would have been done just the same, no matter how popular the school was locally. On the other hand, it is also true that a feeling of distrust was being engendered among the Indians of the vicinity, due largely to the influence of a few white people who personally disliked Mr. Evans. I do not pretend to say that the management of the school was perfect, some mistakes were made, and an endeavor was made to correct these from time to time. However I considered most of the criticisms that were made so public were unjust and I felt I should give you my opinion.

I think the discipline of the school was excellent and the management of the school at least as good as at any time in the history of the school. Apparent faults that generally would be overlooked were magnified into grievous offenses partly because of the increased critical attention paid the Institution in the new costly Government building, and partly because of local jealousies and other circumstances which I need not explain, and some of which would be difficult to explain intelligently to anyone who did not know the surroundings.

It is my belief that Mr. Stockton's opinion, was to some extent influenced by exaggerated reports— it could scarcely have been otherwise. And yet how quickly opinions change. Some of those who criticized Mr. Evans most severely, afterwards realized
how unjust some of the exaggerated reports were, and expressed to me their regret at his leaving the school. However, it is now a thing of the past. Mr. Evans resigned his position as Principal and has given up his work in the school.

We hope that under the new management the school may prosper more and more, and that much good work may be done in training the Indian children, and making them a credit to the Indian Department which I know is anxious to co-operate with us in every effort for the advancement of the Indians of the country.

I remain,

Yours sincerely,

Isaac O. Stringer
Bishop of Yukon.

The publication of this little paper fills two objects; it informs those who are interested regarding the work in this northern diocese, and it gives opportunity to the boys of the school to learn a little about type setting and press work. These two ideas we have sought to combine, so that all we expect from subscriptions is to cover the cost of material and the postage. Small as the subscription is it would be appreciated if the many friends of the Yukon diocese would just remember to send it year by year. We take this opportunity of thanking those who have subscribed up to the present, and also to acknowledge a number of letters encouraging us in the undertaking.

Our readers will please remember that "Northern Lights" has two circulations, namely, the Yukon itself, and "Outside", as the rest of the world is termed in the language of the North. There are perhaps many things that would interest "Outsiders" that would appear trivial or commonplace to the Yukoner. We are trying to build up a paper that will be interesting to church people the world over, and we ask all that are interested for their cooperation.

School News.

Although there was an unusual quantity of snow last winter, still the spring was fairly open, and as a result gardening was begun nearly two weeks earlier than the year before. Carcross is not by nature adapted to farming. The elevation (2,164 feet) gives cold nights even in the hottest season, so that things grow better in Dawson, although that is much further north. Another drawback is that some seasons there is very little rain. This has been overcome near the school by a small irrigation ditch connected with the falls. We are able to forestall the season by planting the first seeds in the hotbed; thus we had such things as lettuce, radishes and cress by the middle of May. The plowing was begun on May 4th, and the whole crop was in before the end of the month.

The last meeting of the J.W.A. was held at the School July 7th. All the members were present but two. When the books were closed it was found that there was $10.00 available for missions. This money had been earned by the children during their play hours, and so was entirely their own. It was voted to send $5.00 towards the children's work in the diocese of Honan. With regard to the other $5.00 there was quite a lively discussion, the boys being more interested in the Eskimo work and the girls in the School for the Blind at Gifu, Japan. The Carcross Indians, almost to a man, left to attend a great semi-religious gathering in Whitehorse at the beginning of April. Some have returned since, the rest have got employment on the steamer and at the wood camps.

Early in May the Rev. W.G. Blackwell visited the mission at Teslin. During the same month Rev. Brett spent a Sunday here on his way to Teslin.

In June the Rector left on a visitation of the Diocese. If back in time he may proceed to Vancouver to attend the General Synod. During his absence the church and parish will be in charge of the Rev. W.T. Townsend.

Carmacks and Little Salmon.

There is to hand a list of those who have contributed to the new church and mission house at Carmacks. The small pretensions of this paper and the length of the list of those who have chosen this tangible way to show their interest in the Yukon make it impossible to publish the names in detail, as was the intention. The list includes names from France and Ireland as well as Canada. Anyone wishing to contribute toward this, the newest branch of the work to be taken up in the diocese, may

During the winter, services were held regularly at Carmacks in the Road House. The average attendance was about eight, the smallness of which is due largely to the clique difficulty so prevalent in small places. We hope for better things in the future. Whenever there were any Indians here services were held for them in their tents, there being as yet no church building. The ordinary petty medical work of the northern missionary was done; in one case a broken leg was set. This belonged to a little Indian girl from Lake Lake. Her parents refused to let her go to Whitehorse, so first aid was all that could be done. We are glad to say that the leg healed well.

The Indians at Little Salmon were away most of the winter tending their traps, but the missionary in charge, Rev C. Swanson, paid seven visits during the winter months, holding services whenever there was anybody to come, and teaching two boys. These latter are very promising indeed. They paid for their tuition by teaching in their turn. Their pupil, the missionary himself, was not as bright in learning their language as they in learning his. It is very hard to learn a new tongue simply by hearing. With the advent of Spring the Indians came out over the ice, and some by the first water. Services have been held and have been very well attended. We are also holding school in the afternoon for the boys and girls, and in the evening for the adults.

The Indians all through the territory seem to have been the victims of a scourge of "La Grippe." Little Salmon was no exception. At every tent we were met with the same story. "Me head sick. Me bones all sick too." However it has all passed off now, and the general state of health is quite good. There are one or two cases of incipient consumption. In May a little girl died in a very advanced stage of tuberculosis.

We are now waiting for the arrival of some lumber to make seats and desks for the Church and school. At present we are using rough-hewn logs.

In March Mr. and Mrs. Swanson paid a visit to Nansen Creek. Mrs. Swanson traveled the whole way in quite a blizzard and three feet of snow. Not bad for a Cheechako! In this tough too Mr. Swanson started to go to the Polly River Indians, but was unable to get a guide and dogs, so the trip had to be postponed. By the kindness of Mr. W. Drury he will be able to go on the first trip of the steamboat Klondike with her annual supply for the Ross River Store. This trip is particularly interesting and important, from the fact that the Mackenzie River Indians, or at least a band of them trade at this store. Mr Field of Selkirk visited them last year for a very short time. They were evangelists in the diocese of Mackenzie River, and it is important that mission work should be kept up among them, as the Roman Church is only too keen to make proselytes of Protestant Indians.

St. Paul's, Dawson.

There have been many improvements made in the church buildings within the last few months. The vestry has been renovated by the Dawson branch of the Woman's Auxiliary and the members of the Vestry. Theabling rooms are greatly improved by the building of compartments for cassocks and surplices. A cupboard has also been built in which to keep the Bishop's and clergy's robes. One of the members of the Vestry has volun-
teered to supply sufficient paint, and
with the help of several others to paint
the church fence. A bishop's chair,
made of unpolished English oak, has
been placed in the chapel, together
with a new clergy chair.

It has been the custom at Dawson
for years for most of the people to climb
the "Dome" on the night of June 21st,
to see the "Midnight Sun". As that
date this year fell on Sunday it was
arranged to have a midnight service on
the summit. The collection went to-
wards a new operating room in the
Good Samaritan Hospital.

The Ven. Archdeacon Canham vis-
ited Dawson this summer during his
visitation of the diocese. He arrived in
time to officiate at the Communion ser-
vice on the first Sunday in July.

St Barnabas' Moosehide.

The Indians of Moosehide have had
a good winter's hunt, and have sold
much meat. They are at present in
good health, and in some measure pros-
pering. There is, however, from time
to time, considerable drunkenness which
we profoundly regret. We feel we
must go on perseveringly against this,
with faith in God. The Authorities are
not able to do very much to suppress
this curse amongst the Indians, owing
to prevailing difficulties.

In spite of their weaknesses and
temptations they attend church well,
which may be taken perhaps as a sign
of their desire for spiritual help.
There are some backsiders who for
some reason have given up their work
for God. For such we must pray and
work.

It is encouraging to listen to a pupil
in the Sunday School reading the Word
of God in the Indian tongue, and who
in early years attended our day-school
receiving her first lessons in reading
there. The Service for children which
is held once a month in the English
language is much appreciated. The
elder ones listen attentively, sing well,
and join intelligently in the worship.

The Indian day school has been
visited recently by the Indian Agent.
A good number of pupils attended and
went through their examination.
Many of the children have to leave the
school when their parents go away to
hunt. Several of the young men attend
and occasionally one or two of the
women. The pupils are making steady
progress. The younger ones are an-
xious to attend school.

The Station at Forty Mile has been
visited, and Divine Services held for
the Indians and Whites. The Sacrament
of the Lord's Supper was administered
to the Indians. The church there has
been somewhat burnt.

St. Andrew's, Selkirk.

The usual Indian exodus has taken
place to the fish camps at the lake.
The jackfish is the favorite catch.
Caribou and moose hunting have been exten-
sively followed, and meat has been plen-
tiful. What bids fair to become the
most popular pursuit among natives and
white people alike is the search for the
rare breeds of foxes, silver-gray and
black. The price offered for these
animals alive is sometimes as high as
$1000 for silver-grey, and even higher
for black. A Coffee Creek Indian, now
in Selkirk, realized some $500 for a
young silver-grey fox. Such rewards for
Indians are calculated to work much
harm upon their morals. With no idea
of money value, with little or no ten-
dencies towards economy, such fortunes,
as they may well be called, will, it is
feared, produce discontent and selfish-
ness.

Church attendance, both Indian
and white, has been on the whole good,
while the school has been open as often
as the constant journeysings of the chil-
dren's parents will permit.

General.

The Bishop of Yukon, the Right Rev. L.O. Stringer, returned to his diocese in September, after a very successful year in England. As has already been stated, the Bishop was in England endeavouring to raise the $50,000 necessary to complete the endowment of his diocese. He was so far successful that he raised all but $5,000 of that amount. On his way to Dawson he visited the various missions along the route, staying over at Carcross, Whitehorse and Carmacks, and paying a flying visit to Selkirk. The Bishop was accompanied to Dawson by Mrs. Stringer and their four boys; their daughter, Miss Rebecca Stringer, remained in Toronto, where she is attending Hartsgate College.

Rev. C. Swanson has been very busy at Carmacks in the building profession. A Church has been erected, 26 x 18, with a chancel 9 x 12. It is hoped that this winter there will be good attendances in it. A new house has also been started for the missionary, as the present residence, 14 feet square is hardly big enough.

Mrs. Swanson went to the W.A. meeting in Carcross, leaving her husband to build a small addition to the Little Salmon house, and to make the seating in the Church. This latter is now complete, and, with two good desks for the school, forms an excellent equip-

Archdeacon Sunk's visit was enjoyed by all. The Indians particularly welcomed their old Missionary, who had labored among them for many years, the mission house being the headquarters for many visitors.

Christ Church, Whitehorse.

Ralph, the youngest of Rev. W. G. Blackwell's five boys, is at the time of writing down with a mild attack of scarlet fever, and the house is in quarantine. For this reason the article by Mr. Blackwell, which usually appears in this paper under the head of Whitehorse is not available. Up to the present the pulpit at Whitehorse has been filled by the Ven. Archdeacon Caubham and Rev. W. T. Townsend.

During his stay in Whitehorse the Bishop extended Mr. Blackwell's field of labor by making him responsible for the work in the direction of Champagne.

St. Saviour's, Carcross.

The return of our good Bishop after more than a year's absence from the Diocese was warmly welcomed by us all. We had much to tell him, but a great deal more to learn from him. He is well pleased with the work he has done with the endowment fund, and comes back to us with a load of anxiety removed. The Endowment Fund is not completed, but there is hope of its being so in the near future. The Bishop's stay here had to be short, but we were glad to have him even for one Sunday. He had yet about 500 miles further to go to reach home, and from news received since he started, it seems he is having a somewhat trying time. There is delay on route, and we have heard nothing definite as to cause of it.

The Rector returned from his visitation of the Diocese early in September having traveled some 1200 miles. At all the Missions visited the works are meeting with encouragement.

St. Paul's, Dawson.

The work of St. Paul's is very encouraging in its steady progress, and in its outlook for the future. The members of the congregation attend the services regularly, and contribute generously to the support of the work. At the evening service on July 5th the Ven. Archdeacon Sunk, of the Diocese of Alberta, preached a powerful sermon to a large congregation. The Rev. G. D. Christian, formerly missionary in charge at Nome, delivered an inspiring address at St. Paul's on Sunday evening, August 2nd. The annual children's flower service was held on Sunday afternoon, August 30th. The church was beautifully decorated for the occasion with plants and flowers, and the services on that day were well attended by scholars, parents and friends. On Sunday evening, Sept 30th, the service was of a special character, being the occasion when the congregation and friends bade farewell to several members of the N. W. M. P. who left Dawson on Monday morning to go to the front.

The ladies of the Senior Woman's Auxiliary are working most faithfully toward the completion of their sale, which they propose to hold sometime during November. The members of the Junior Branch of the Woman's Auxiliary are also laboring enthusiastically. In a northern parish such as St. Paul's, it is impossible to underestimate the work of the Woman's Auxiliary in the Church.

School News.

The School crops have been successfully harvested. Owing to the short time that the School has been on the present site, the amount of ground under cultivation is not large, but new ground is being added each year. This year the yield was about 8 tons of hay, 2 tons oats and 1 ton to be used as fodder, 60 bushels of potatoes and other garden vegetables in proportion. On account of the elevation and latitude many things that would naturally be expected cannot be raised at all.

During the month of August Mr. J. Hawksley, Superintendent of Indian Affairs for the Yukon Territory, paid an official visit to the School in connection with the new workshop and septic tank which have been constructed by the Department of Indian Affairs. The workshop will aid greatly to the efficiency of the work done by the School, as manual training is by far the most important thing for an Indian boy, who has to earn his living in the Yukon. It is hoped that the septic tank will successfully solve the drainage problem, which has been a source of trouble for some time.

Bishop and Mrs. Stringer stayed some days at the School on their way home from England. During his stay the Bishop held a Confirmation Service in Carcross, at which Bella Njootli, one of the girls of the School and daughter of the Rev. Amos Njootli of Rampart House, was confirmed. Bella returns to her Arctic home next summer, where it is hoped that she will have a strong influence for good.

With the passing of Miss F. Hutchison, who last month resigned her position as teacher in the School, the Staff loses the last of its old members. Miss Hutchison came to Carcross in 1905. She has worked under Bishop Bonpars, Rev. J. Hawksley, Archdeacon Canham and Mr. Evans as well as the present management. She knew the School as a couple of log shacks, and has seen it grow into the present commodious building. Miss Hutchison has known real pioneer missionary life at a time when conveniences were by no means as numerous as at present, and we believe that all who are interested in the Yukon Diocese will join with the members of the Staff in wishing her every happiness in her well earned rest. Miss Hutchison's address for the present will be 2010 Inverness St., Vancouver.

Fur raising has come to be one of the recognized industries of the Yukon, and Carcross at present leads the Territory both in number and size of its fur farms. The larger boys of the School have made their spending money, not only in hunting gophers and rabbits or fox feed, but in some cases in catching live minks. The money the boys make in this way is their own, though we try and advise them not to spend it foolishly, as they are somewhat prone to do. Alfred has started an account in the Postal Savings Bank. We hope that others will follow his example.
