Sir:-

I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your letter dated Nov 21st, 1914, file #297298/1 in reference to the apparently large staff employed at the Carcross Indian Boarding School.

In connection with the above I beg to submit the following report.

During my visits to the Carcross School I was a guest there and thus had a good opportunity of observing the staff at their work. Their time was fully occupied with the various duties in the several departments, they appeared to have very little time for recreation, this was a matter I called to the attention of the Principal. In a place like Carcross where everything has to be done on the premises the work seems endless. My experience as Principal of the school for three years, 1906 to 1909 verifies this.

Being within easy reach of the Bishop of Yukon and wishing to supply the Department with accurate information as early as possible, as I do not anticipate having to visit the school until the opening of navigation (it being so costly to make a trip in winter) I interviewed the Bishop who kindly gave me the following information.

The present members of the staff are:-
The Rev W.T. Townsend, B.A. Principal.
Mr C.F. Johnson Manager.
Mrs * * * Housekeeper.
Miss E.J. Naftel Girl's Matron.
Miss A. Appleyard Boy's Matron.
Miss R. Sibley Kitchen Assistant.

The Bishop says that he has gone into the matter very care-
fully. It would be to the advantage to the Church of England financially to manage with a smaller staff inasmuch as the Gov't grant is not sufficient to cover all expenses and that he has to look to other sources for the balance. After several years experience, and after learning all he could from the experience of other such institutions he has come to the conclusion that six workers are essential to efficient service. It might be possible to manage with five but it would mean very hard work and considerable strain on each one.

In many cases workers in boarding schools throughout Canada have broken down in health because of the continuous strain. The workers have very little relaxation. In most avocations a person has some part of the day or week free from responsibility. In an Indian boarding school the strain is continuous, even Sunday is not exempt. A public school teacher for instance may have hard work and much responsibility from 9 A.M to 4 P.M but he or she has certain hours free from the responsibility and tension of keeping order and giving instruction. Such freedom is almost unknown in an Indian boarding school and can only be attained in any degree by having the helpers relieve one another. This cannot be done unless there is a sufficient number of workers. During the greater part of the day all the staff have some special duties, the children too have their allotted tasks to perform and as a rule they need constant supervision in order to have the work done properly and in a workmanlike way. If the work in the class room were all it would be a comparatively easy task, but instruction is also given in other branches of work, carpentry, work in the woods, hunting, fishing, printing, care of live stock, gardening, washing, ironing, mending, scrubbing, sewing and cooking, all these require more or less supervision.

It means so much to have the workers satisfied, with the present they are all satisfied, with one less they would all be dis-satisfied, I feel sure that resignations would be more frequent if the number were reduced.
The salaries paid are very small compared with the general run of salaries in the Yukon. They are as follows:

Rev W.T. Townsend - $1200 without board
Mr & Mrs Johnson - 900 with board
Miss E.J. Naftel - 400
Miss A. Appleyard - 400
Miss R. Sibley - 300

Their duties overlap more or less but generally speaking may be designated as follows. Rev W.T. Townsend teaches the day school, gives physical drill, superintends the publication of the little paper "Northern Lights", takes the boys out at certain times, and as Principal sees after the acceptance and dismissal of the pupils, and conducts the general correspondence.

Mr Johnson has charge of the school plant, superintends the heating and water supply and has oversight of all the outdoor work of the pupils. He also looks after the hay and the firewood, gives instruction in the care of live stock, gardening, carpentry, and blacksmith work, in addition he has the ordering of supplies and keeps the accounts.

Mrs Johnson the housekeeper in addition to care of the food and clothing gives special instruction in cooking, jam making, and laundry work and many other small things that crop up daily take up her time and attention.

Miss Naftel is girls matron, she teaches sewing, mending knitting, etc., and is responsible for the girls generally, their deportment and cleanliness.

Miss Appleyard is the boys matron whose duties are similar to those of Miss Naftel, she also gives assistance in the laundry.

Miss Sibleys duties are for the most part confined to the kitchen preparing meals with the assistance of one or two of the girl pupils and attending to the cleanliness of the kitchen utensils.

Mr Townsend is a qualified teacher with considerable exper-
ience, in addition to his work as principal of the school he has certain missionary duties to perform for this reason part of his salary is paid from Church sources.

Mr Johnson is peculiarly fitted for his position as manager. He is an engineer and a good all round mechanic and could get three times as much wages as an engineer. His ability as a mechanic to repair many things about the school which before his coming were done by a tradesman at the expense of the Department has undoubtedly saved the Dep't quite a sum of money, I might venture to say hundreds of dollars.

Miss Naftel and Miss Appleyard have both had special training and a good deal of experience.

Miss Sibley joined the staff last Sep't to fill the place vacant by the resignation of Miss Hutchison. It might be mentioned in passing that Miss Hutchison after leaving the school wrote (without any ulterior object) voluntarily expressing her opinion that six workers were necessary to carry on the work of the school efficiently.

The financial statement for the year ending March 31st 1913 showed a total expenditure of $7640.00. Last year it would be somewhat more. Deducting say $350.00 for Mr Townsend's board the total amount for salaries will be $2850.00 and board including Mr Townsend's entire salary, adding the board and salaries together for the whole staff it would not amount to more than is paid for the services of two qualified teachers in the public schools in Dawson.

The Bishop strongly expresses the opinion that a staff of six workers are absolutely necessary for the work. At the same time he states that he will gladly consider any recommendation from the Dep't and would like their opinion on the question after reading this report.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Superintendent.

Diocesan News, General.

Rev. C. C. Brett, after five and a half years' work in the Diocese, has resigned and left for Eastern Canada the middle of February. He and Mrs. Brett and child, Marion, journeyed out from Selkirk by stage to Whitehorse.

Mr. Brett's work has been chiefly at Champagne and Teslin, which latter place he left last summer for Selkirk, much to the regret of the residents of Teslin, both Whites and Indians. Mr. Brett left entirely at his own request. We wish them every happiness and prosperity in their future sphere of work. We would not be surprised to hear of Mr. Brett being on his way to the front.

Jonathan Wood, an Indian Catechist from Moosehide, has gone with his family to Selkirk, where his wife's relations live. James Wood, his son, who recently graduated from the School, is to teach the Indian day School. 'Jimmie' was our head printer for two years.

St. Paul's, Dawson.

The annual congregational meeting was held on Monday evening January 16th. Various reports were submitted which showed growth in the Church's activities. The total income for the year 1915 amounted to $2940, being an increase of $800 on the previous year. Mr. A. C. Lee was reappointed Rector's Warden and Mr. W. G. Radford was elected People's Warden. In order that the parish may be better able to attain self support, Mr. Joseph Bunnell (Verger) and Mr. Alfred Ramsley (Side-man) have voluntarily undertaken to do the Janitor work for the year.

On Sunday afternoon, February 6th., and also on March 10th., the Choir of St. Paul's Church rendered most acceptably a service of song. The entire collections, amounting to $97, were devoted to the Red Cross Society. Amongst the paper and silver money donated at the time of the first recital were two gold nuggets, which were afterwards valued at $7.—A reminder of early days.

Paardeburg Day, Sunday February 27th., was duly observed in Dawson by a joint service in St. Andrew's Church (Presbyterian), which was held under the auspices of the "Imperial Order Daughters of the Empire." The Rev. F. H. Back read the lesson, and the Rector of St. Paul's delivered the address. The collection, which amounted to $863, was devoted to the "Patriotic Fund."

The Dawson lodge of the Independent Order of Oddfellows attended divine service at St. Paul's on Sunday evening, March 5th. Bishop Stringer conducted the service and expressed a hearty welcome to the members and their friends, after which the Rector preached an appropriate sermon.

The pioneer Church of the Territory was fittingly honored on the evening of March 12th. by the attendance at St. Paul's of the Yukon Order of Pioneers. The occasion was unique, in that this was the first church parade organized by...
the Order. The members are real pioneers, since all 'mashed' into the Territory over the rugged Chilkoot or White Pass, before July 1st., 1899, that is previous to the time when the railway which now connects Skagway with Whitehorse commenced operations. In search for the gold that perishes the miners have undergone numerous hardships, and to the story of the unsearchable riches of Christ and the gold that perishes not, these present listened most attentively.

School News.

We have been having trouble this quarter with the water supply. The water for the school ordinarily comes from a well beneath the basement, being pumped from there to a tank in the attic, from which the plumbing is supplied by gravity. This winter the well went dry, so all the water had to be hauled from the creek near the school. During the extremely cold weather the creek froze to bottom, and then the nearest water was a mile and a half away, except what was got by melting snow and ice.

The Right Rev. L.O. Stringer, our Bishop, visited the south end of his Diocese in March, and stayed a few days at the School. There was much to be done, and the Bishop had time for very little else besides business while he was here. On Saturday, March 25th., Rev. W.G. Blackwell and Mr. W.S. Watson came over from Whitehorse between trains, and the Bishop called a meeting of the Advisory Committee for the Southern Yukon. This committee consists of four members: Ven. Archdeacon Canham, Rev. W.G. Blackwell, W.S. Watson, Esq., and Rev. W.T. Townsend, with the Bishop as chairman. The Bishop returned to Whitehorse the same day. From there he has paid a short visit to Champagne Landing. He intends to visit several stations on his way back to Dawson.

On Friday, April 14th., Mr. Townsend made a trip to Tagish by dog team, and held service there on the following Sunday, returning to Carcross on Monday. On his return journey Mr. Townsend had a passenger, Mrs. Scott of Tagish, who is assisting in the school as Girls' Matron during Miss Naftel's absence. Mrs. Scott was at one time Matron of the Isolation Hospital at Edmonton, so found no difficulty in taking up the work at the School.

On April 19th., Miss Naftel left for a six weeks' holiday. She plans to reach Toronto in time for the annual meeting of the Diocesan Woman's Auxiliary, spending a couple of days in Victoria en route.

The Children of the School have taken a keen interest in the mite box collection. On Easter Sunday when the money was counted, there was an array of heads close around the desk. The amount given was fifteen dollars ($15).

Christ Church, Whitehorse.

On Sunday, March 26th., the Bishop of Yukon administered the rite of Confirmation to four adult male candidates. The Bishop preached a very powerful sermon on Acts 8:17. After the service there was corporate communion for the newly confirmed candidates.

On April 11th., Bishop Stringer, assisted by the Rector, gave an illustrated

Mrs. W. J. Studhart, secretary of the Woman's Auxiliary, received the sad news of the death of her brother at the front.

Carmacks and Little Salmon.

The Indians have been keeping pretty well to the hills this year, as fur has been very plentiful and of good price. There was not the scarcity of food and consequent suffering that some of us anticipated.

About the middle of January, Rev. C. Swanson went across to Ross River with an Indian, having a very good trip favored by fine weather all the way. On a long trip such as this (200 miles), a great deal depends on one's dogs by day and robe by night. The load consists of food for the trip, dog food (rice, grease and dry-meat), blankets, mail, extra clothes etc., snowshoes and an axe; in all about 100 pounds. With such a light load the driver can ride whenever he wishes. At night when making camp the order of the day is as follows. Make camp with green brush, cut dry wood and start a fire. Unhitch dogs and tie them up. Make tea and cook the food. Cook the dogs' food and feed them. Bed.

The trip was unfortunate in its results. The last day of the journey was windy. The first day at the Fort was very windy, the next was fifty degrees below zero, the next sixty, and so on for ten days. It seemed as if the weather had broken after twelve days, and the missionary was due home, so he started off.

The return trip was good, though cold, as it was from thirty to fifty below. Mr. Swanson travelled alone without mishap and duly arrived home in six days. The trail was heavy, and was badly drifted.

After his return Mr. Swanson stayed at Carmacks for two months. Service were held for Whites and Indians. The former were much better attended than heretofore.

The Mission was honored in March by the arrival of the Bishop. He stayed four days and held one week night service, and as well visited everybody in the vicinity. There is one criticism to make of the visit—it was not long enough. We are like Oliver Twist and want more—much more!

Church Camp Mission.

Immediately after Christmas Mr. Buck visited Sulphur, Granville, Humber and Dominion Creeks, holding services at the first three. In spite of the extremely cold weather there was a remarkably good attendance.

After a short stay in Dawson the Missionary set out on a three weeks' trip to Steward City. Services were held at Quartz Creek, Eureka Creek, Black Hills, Henderson Creek and Steward City. At Quartz Creek and Black Hills nearly the whole population was present, and the interest shown in the smaller centres was equally fine. When men and women will come for miles on foot or by dog team amid the bitter cold of a Yukon winter to attend Christian worship, it may surely be believed that the force and value of religion is still being felt even in these days of materialism, where faith in God and the cross of Christ is to some a stumbling block and to some foolishness.

During the extreme weather in the latter part of January and the beginning of February, except for a week-end trip to Bear Creek, the Missionary was
NORTHERN LIGHTS.

compelled to remain in Dawson. As soon as the weather grew warmer Mr. Back paid another visit to Sulphur, Gold Run and Hunker Creeks, and then on February 28th set out for his second trip to Mayo. Except for glaciers and running water on Clear Creek the trail was good, and Minto Bridge was safely reached on March 5th. Two splendid services were held at Mayo Landing with an attendance of well over forty at each. The Indian settlement has, for a time at least, been transferred to thirty miles above Fraser Falls. This district is a little better hunting and trapping ground, and is removed from the insidious temptations of the saloon. Haggart, Galena, Johnson, Highway and Duncan Creeks were visited, and services held at the first three, and at Minto Bridge as well. The latter place is a distributing centre for the mines. The ore from the Silver King Mine is the richest yet taken out, and it is hoped that the mineral wealth of the district will attract many new settlers, and that a prosperous community will spring up. A church and library are badly needed at Mayo, where great interest has been shown in the religious work that has so far been accomplished. The trip back to Dawson (165 miles) was completed by the Missionary in 6½ days, and was extremely difficult.

Mr. J. M. McCormick, the Superintendent at Winnipeg, is expected to visit the Yukon in the early summer, and a hearty welcome is assured him.

St. James', Fortymile.

An account of our Christmas entertainments, which was unavoidably postponed until New Year's Eve, was promised in this number. The immemorial event duly took place in the presence of a crowded audience of both white people and Indians. The tree was almost hidden by the splendidly brave array of glistening decorations and gifts. These latter were handed around accompanied by voice and gesture, and to the evident delight of the recipients. The children especially enjoyed the fun and the wonder of anticipation, as their little fingers fumbled with paper and string, in which many presents were carefully disposed. When the tree had assumed more or less its normal appearance, the strains of the gramophone were added to the incessant chatter and laughter which prevailed. The ceremony of providing for the comfort of the inner man was the next item on what proved to be a varied programme. A goodly supply of ham and meat sandwiches, and eggs ditto, was twice and thrice produced, followed by cakes enticing to the palate, and in addition "the cup that cheers, but not inebriates". The meeting had begun about 8.30, and as 11 o'clock approached, the reminder that the last half hour of the old year would be spent as belated so solemn a time, produced the necessary restraint over perfectly natural and delightful merriment. A hymn sung, verses read with remarks regarding life's prospect, the good resolutions made, the hope that the Great War would soon end followed by a lasting peace the outcome of the determination of an awakened earth, and that so far as may be, all wars, all cruelty and oppression may cease.

Our heartiest thanks are given to the many good friends far and near whose kindly thoughts and deeds added so much materially to our success. The Mission Band of All Saints', Toronto, as usual was well to the fore with its many charming gifts.

It is most encouraging to relate as an instance of spiritual progress, that a Men's Bible Class has been started, and has, under God, every prospect of continuance.

A Trip to Rampart House.

BY THE REV. J. A. DAVIES, B. A.

"May be we'll get away tonight". Thus daily for two weeks did Mr. Schaefer, hunter and trapper, who had not been to town for twenty years, express the uncertainty of the departure of the trading boat "Rampart" bound on its annual return trip from Dawson to Rampart House. However a start was made on Wednesday afternoon, July 26th. At last it seemed as if patience had been rewarded as our craft was swept down stream at the thrilling rate of six miles an hour. A new boiler had just been installed, the ship's crew were Indians and four "White" had enjoyed a comparatively long stay in the midst of civilization, and things generally betokened a speedy trip. But within an hour and a half it was easily realized that something had gone wrong, for our boat was now drifting helplessly in a very swift current. Great fear was entertained lest the boat should strike a sandbar which stretched far into the river. Happily it was missed, and after twenty minutes in which time we had drifted a considerable distance, we were able to make shore. The needed repairs to the steam valves were of such a nature as to incur a delay of nineteen hours. Thursday, at midnight, we reached Forty Mile, the last Canadian port on the Yukon river. Here, with Mr. Field the Missionary-in-charge and other friends, an enjoyable chat about the war and other up-to-date topics was indulged in. The "wee sma' hours" came all too soon, when it became necessary to go aboard again. A heavy rain was falling, which easily penetrated the roof of a new cabin which had recently been built on the barge. On this occasion and many others, a couple of waterproof sheets rendered valuable service. We left Forty Mile, which is 32 miles from Dawson, at 6 A.M., and arrived at Eagle, the first stop in Alaska, at 3 P.M. Clearance papers had to be obtained, and two passenger boats made the port that afternoon, we were delayed 6 hours. The time on shore passed quickly, chatting with friends who were returning to Dawson, and who were vividly impressed with the sights and smells of our boat—a mixture of dogs, Indians, dried meat, smoked fish, etc. The next town—Circle City—is 180 miles from Eagle, which we passed on Sunday evening. Earlier in the day the Indians on board sighted a porcupine climbing the river, and although the porcupine provides a favorite Indian dish, they refrained from killing it because of their respect for the day. After making shore a service was held which was attended by all on board. Schaefer remarked that he had not been to a service for more than a dozen years. Monday morning we left the mountains of the Upper Yukon and travelled through the Yukon flats for a distance of 90 miles, when we reached Fort Yukon, which stands in the Arctic circle. Fort Yukon is one of the oldest posts formerly occupied by the Hudson Bay Co., and the scene of many of the memorable labours of the late Archdeacon MacDonald.

Porcupine river, a side stream 1000 miles long, enters and discharges its waters. Our craft now left the Yukon waters and pushed upstream against the delightful current of the Porcupine. In the afternoon we landed for wood at an Indian camp and incidentally found an old squaw suffering from a badly festering head. After bathing the head with an antiseptic solution, some relief was afforded by the application of clean bandages and dressing. The next day was fine and dry when the washing was done before breakfast in the morning. Sally, an Indian girl returning from Carcross school, fell overboard. Fortunately she was seized instantly and lifted on deck, little the worse for her experience, though wet and affrighted. A series of minor accidents ensued during the next few days, such as bursting of steam pipes and the dripping of tubes. Delay seems to be the hallmark of travel up sidestreams in the North. The following Sunday I found a new treasure in the prayer book. Generally we think of the Prayer Book as being specially fitted for public use, but possibly it is equally profitable for private use, and specially in the light of its associations. Evening service was conducted by the Indians. The "whites" were unable to be present as they were engaged in making repairs necessitated by an accident which happened in the afternoon. The next evening we were afforded a rather exciting experience. We had now reached a sharp bend in the river where the water was very swift on a riffle, caused by a long gravel bar. The bank on the opposite side was undercut for several feet. The boat pulling with full steam almost attempted to force its way, but as soon as it reached the foot of the riffle the barge and boat were swept around and rushed downstream. Happily the engines responded promptly to the handling of the engineer and kept the boat in midstream, otherwise large and night might have been lost. A second attempt to pass the riffle proved successful, and when we got out for the night it was with feelings of thankfulness for travelling mercies vouchsafed through another day. One hundred miles from Fort Yukon we entered the mountainous region and saw the range of hills everywhere. Perhaps the most striking part is known as "Howling Dog". At this particular point the cliffs on both sides of the river are high and vertical, and of a beautiful brownish colour. When dogs were howling there they have no choice on whether the "Howling Dog" bluffs but to swim. Invariably as they pass these towering rocks they are said to howl; hence the name "Howling Dog". Thirty miles from Rampart House we encountered very smooth water again and were hours travelling further. Saturday evening we came to a cliff called "Swoozie" where it was necessary for nine men to pull on a line. After thirty minutes of strenuous hauling, when the boat was within a few feet of the head of the riffle, the line broke. The immediate result was that the boat and barge were violently rushed downstream and unfortunately the bottom of the barge struck a rock. After making sure it was found that the barge was leaking badly. One of the Indian boys was told off for the night to pump the water out of the barge until a steam syphon could be fixed. Instead of attending diligently to his duties he fell into the arms of Morpheus. About two Sunday morning, with a heavy rain falling, it was discovered that twenty cases of pneumonia developed in five, two of which were fatal. During the absence of Mr. Swanson at the camp, the services were conducted twice by Bishop Stringer and once by Archdeacon Cumham.

St. Paul's, Dawson.

At the request of the Bishop the Rector of St. Paul's, Rev. John A. Davies, has made a visit to Rampart House Mission. An account of the trip will be found in the leading article of this issue. Mr. Davies was away from Dawson for seven weeks. During his absence the Rev. F. H. Buck took charge of the parish, and conducted the regular services.

St. Paul's congregation is being greatly depleted. Many members have already left the North, and many more purpose leaving before the close of navigation. Many of the men of the Church have enlisted for overseas service, including former curate George Black, Captain Yukon Infantry Company, and William G. Radford, church warden.

The annual W.A. service was held in St. Paul's on August 15th. The Rev. D. Fitty administered the Holy Communion, assisted by Mr. Bush while Mr. J. M. McCormick, Superintendent of the Church Camp Missions preached the sermon.

St. Barnabas', Moosehide.

The Indians of the mission have lately been busy getting in their crops from the garden. Potatoes grew well this year. Chief Silas has two sows stored in the mission pig pen. The latter had about 400 lbs. of potatoes from his gardens, all of excellent quality. One man had some large cabbages and numbers of others have been grown. Meat has been fairly plentiful, as hounds have been occasionally seen up the Yukon. Some of the young men have been engaged on steamboats; others have been busy with rafts of wood, and helping white men on their farms. One or two of the older school boys have been so engaged.

James Wood and his father are back in the village. The latter gives valued help to the missionary. It is hoped that James will soon recommence his Sunday school class. The health of the village has been good for the last few months; and there is only one in the hospital at present.

The White River Indians had a happy and pleasant time here. Classes, services, and school were held for them, and a large number were confirmed. The Bishop and others visited the mission and rendered very great help. The natives very much appreciated what was done for them, and went back to their hunting grounds with happy and contented hearts. Julius Kendt has gone to teach the Indians at Mayo. He needs our prayers.

St. James', Forty-mile.

The peace and quiet of our parish was agreeably disturbed by visits of Dawson residents during the summer. Forty-mile has assumed a new role, independent of its mining industry, so greatly diminished of recent years, by becoming a centre for leisure resort. The cares and distractions of "city life" may henceforth be dissipated by sundry trips to the oldest camp in the Territory.

The Indians have had a successful fishing season and will continue the dog salmon fishing until the end of September. No sickness, either among the white people or natives, has occurred; and all are anticipating a happy and useful time during the long winter months.

Through the kindness of the Bishop and his Dawson friends, the expenses towards a new floor for the church have been met. The church is now in
Church Camp Mission.

During the first week of July Mr. Buck visited the power plant of the Canadian Klondike Company at the North Fork of the Klondike. Here a huge reservoir is being constructed, which will supply the need of the Company for several years. A splendid service in the open air attended by the whole camp, was held by the missionary, and it certainly sounded grand to hear the old familiar tunes ring up to God in the great cathedral, of which the starry heavens formed the roof.

Early in July Mr. J. M. McCormick arrived from Winnipeg to inspect the work in the Yukon. No time was lost in commencing the work. Splendid services were held at Black Hills and Eagle Creek, where Mr. McCormick, with usual force told the people the "old old story of Jesus and His love". It is safe to say from the serious reverent faces of the men, and their hearty handshakes, that the message was not given in vain. The dining room of the Mission at Fox Gulch was visited, and a series of photographs taken of the different mining operations on Bonanza and Eldorado Creeks.

The following week Mr. McCormick, accompanied by Mr. Buck, journeyed to Mayo on the steamer "Vigilante". A splendid service was held by Mr. Buck at Fraser Falls among the Indians, and three babies were baptized. The missionary and an Indian boy rowed forty miles to Mayo next day. Highest Creek, Mint-a-Bridge, and the Silver King mine were visited in turn, and inspiring services were held.

After this "Mac the Sky Pilot" and his crew returned to will be as well known and liked in the valley as he is among the railway construction camps of the Rockies, or the workers on the Welland Ship Canal, where the mission is performed so good a work for God. Leaving Mr. Buck at Mayo, Mr. McCormick returned to Dawson. A service at Mayo was held by the former, attended by nearly everyone in town, and the walls of the log school house rang as the dear missionary sang the well known hymn, "Jesus loves me of all others most". It is at times like these that one can set aside all his doubts and fears, and feel of a truth that God is close beside him. Before leaving the district, the missionary visited Haggard's Landing, a little English settlement away in the midst of the North, but where the services of the Church are indeed appreciated. Several requests for a celebration of the Holy Communion at the next visit of the missionary were received.

On the return trip Dawson a service was held on the S.S. "Vigilante". Many passengers from Dawson were on board, Capt. Barrington and all the men who could be spared were present. One of the men accompanied the singing on his guitar. The people remained for some hours after the service singing hymn after hymn. All agreed that they had seldom enjoyed a Sunday evening as they did that one.

As far as the facts go, Mr. McCormick left Dawson for his home in Winnipeg, accompanied by the best wishes of all with whom he came in contact during his brief stay in the Yukon. He suffered considerably from the unaccustomed fatigues of the long day's marches, but he bore them with the greatest calmness and self-control that have made him for so many years the leader in the Church's work among the men in the camps.

For the ensuing six weeks Mr. Buck remained in charge of the church in Dawson, in the absence of the Rev. J. A. Davies at Rampart House. Since the latter's return Mr. Buck has held services at Fox Gulch, Gold Run, and Sulphur Creek. As there were his farewell services before his journey outside with the Yukon Contingent, they were exceedingly well attended, despite the worst inclement weather and many were too weak to attend. We offer missionary's good luck and safe return. Next Sunday he will visit Quartz Creek, which will be his last service before leaving for the Front.

School News.

Again there have been changes on the Staff. Mrs. Dean found the work very heavy, as her health was not of the best. She had wished to resign in June, but stayed on till late in August, as there was a little difficulty in finding a suitable worker. Miss C. E. Bennett, the new member of the Staff will be known, at least by name, to many of our readers. She is a graduate of the Danforth House in Toronto. Her experience in Indian work has been gained at Less Slave River, while she has had a couple of years experience in parish work at St. Paul's in Edmonton.

Nearly all the members of the Staff have now had their holidays. Miss Appleton spent hers at Fort Moody and Vancouver. Mr. and Mrs. Johnson and their two children are camping at Tagish. They have just sent in part of their sport some trout that would make English anglers green with envy.

This has been a season of visitors. Besides between two and three hundred tourists, we have had a number who were directly connected with the work in the Yukon. Mr. McCormick, Superintendent of the Church Camp Mission, was able to stay several days with us on his return from Dawson. Mr.
The past summer has been very unfavorable for gardening. The Spring was late and cold, so that many of the crops did not germinate. Yet in spite of many blights and in the absence of our potato crop, we had a harvest yet. The yield was as follows:— Potatoes 15 bushels, turnips 50 bushels, carrots 5 bushels, and other garden truck in good quantities. The fall semester had a telling effect on our crops. We managed to get sufficient for our needs, but the quality is much inferior to other years.

A PRAYER USED AT NOON HOUR, BY THE CHILDREN OF THE SCHOOL.

O Lord, we pray Thee for our soldiers, who are fighting the battles of our country, lead them on at all times to put their trust in Thee; give them courage in time of danger, and mercy in time of victory. We also pray Thee, O our God, for the doctors, nurses, and others engaged in their service and skill in the healing both of pain and sorrow; And all we ask in the name of our Saviour, Jesus Christ. Amen.

When the wind was favourable, we made use of an improvised sail but for 4 days the wind was contrary and we were compelled to use the oars. The return trip to Fort Yukon occupied 6 days during which time I conducted 3 Communion services—each time to Indians isolated from the missions. By day we ate fish, ducks, fish, and moose, and at night the camp was set by night slept beneath the trees. On returning at Fort Yukon the social life of the Indians proved that I was a temporary Indian in more ways than one.

On account of a delay in the steam boats up bound on the Yukon a stoppage of 10 days was unavoidable. However, the opportunity of addressing the Fort Yukon Indians was afforded by the courtesy of the Rev. William Loebl, native missionary at Fort George, and also of assisting the medical mission of Dr. Burke, in his services for the “white” population. A Trip to Rampart House.

By the Rev. J. A. Davies, B. A.

"May be we'll get away tonight". Thus daily for two weeks, did Ab. Schafer, hunter and trapper, who had not been to town for twenty years, express the uncertainty of the departure of the trading boat "Rampart" bound on its annual return trip from Dawson to Rampart House. However a start was made on Wednesday afternoon, July 26th. At last it seemed as if patience had its reward as our craft was swept down stream at the thrilling rate of six miles an hour. A new boiler had been installed, the ship's crew—five Indians and four "Whites"—had enjoyed a comparatively long stay in the midst of civilization, and things generally betokened a speedy trip. But within an hour and a half it was easily realized that something had gone wrong, for our boat was now drifting helplessly in a very swift current. Great fear was entertained lest the boat should strike a sand bar which stretched far into the river. Happily it was missed, and after twenty minutes, in which time we had drifted a considerable distance, we were able to make shore. The needed repairs to the steam valves were of such a nature as to incur a delay of nineteen hours. Thursday, at midnight, we reached Forty Mile, the last Canadian port on the Yukon river. Here, with Mr. Field the Missionary-in-charge and other friends, an enjoyable chat about the war and other up-to-date topics was indulged in. The "wee sma' hours" came all too soon, when it became necessary to go aboard again. A heavy rain was falling, which easily penetrated the roof of a new cabin which had recently been built on the barge. On this occasion and many others, a couple of water-proof sheets rendered valuable service. We left Forty Mile, which is 52 miles from Dawson, at 6 A.M., and arrived at Eagle, the first stop in Alaska, at 3 P.M. Clearance papers had to be signed, and, as two passenger boats made the port that afternoon, we were delayed 6 hours. The time on shore passed quickly, chatting with friends who were returning to Dawson, and who were vividly impressed with the sights and smells of our boat—a mixture of dogs, Indians, dried meat, smoked fish, etc. The next town—Circle City—is 180 miles from Eagle, which we passed on Sunday evening. Earlier in the day the Indians on board sighted a porcupine swimming the river, and although the porcupine provides a favourite Indian dish they refrained from killing it because of their respect for the day. After making shore a service was held which was attended by all on board. Schafer remarked that he had not been to a service for more than a dozen years. Monday morning we left the mountains of the Upper Yukon and travelled through the Yukon flats for a distance of 90 miles, when we reached Fort Yukon, which is within the Arctic circle. Fort Yukon is one of the oldest posts, formerly occupied by the Hudson Bay Co., and the scene of many of the memorable labours of the late Archdeacon MacDonald.

Porcupine river, a side stream 1000 miles long, enters and discharges its waters. Our craft now left the Yukon waters and pushed upstream against the delightfully clear current of the Porcupine. In the afternoon we stopped for wood at an Indian camp and incidentally found an old squaw suffering with a badly festering boil. After bathing her hand in an antiseptic solution some relief was afforded by the application of clean bandages and dressing. The next day was laundry day when the washing was done before breakfast. At noon Sally, an Indian girl returning from a successful hunt fell into the river. Fortunately she was seized instantly and lifted on deck, little the worse for her experience except wet and affrighted.

A series of minor accidents occurred during the next few days, such as bursting of steam pipes and the dumping of tubs. Delay seems to be the hallmark of travel up side streams in the North. The following Sunday I found a new treasure in the Prayer Book. Generally we think of the Prayer Book as being only suitable for public use but possibly it is equally profitable for private use and specially in the light of its associations. Evening service was conducted for the Indians. The "whites" were unable to be present as they were engaged in other work which necessitated an accident which happened in the afternoon. The next evening we were afforded a rather exciting experience. We had now reached a sharp bend in the river where the water was very swift on a riffle, caused by a long gravel bar. The bank on the opposite side was undercut for several feet. The boat pulling with full steam ahead attempted to force its way, but as soon as it reached the foot of the riffle it began to list to one side and immediately rushed downstream. Happily the engines responded promptly to the handling of the engineer and kept the boat in midstream, otherwise barge and freight might have been lost. A second attempt to pass over the riffle proved successful and shortly after noon on the night it was with feelings of thankfulness for travelling mercies we chafed through another day. One hundred miles from Port Yukon we returned to the mountainous region and saw the majestic range of the Rockies. Perhaps the most striking peak is known as "Howling Dog." At this particular point the cliffs on both sides of the river are high and vertical, and of a beautiful brownish colour. When dogs are heard howling there is no chance on reaching the "Howling Dog" bluffs but to swim. Invariably they pass these towering rocks they are said to howl, hence the name "Howling Dog." has been introduced. Thirty miles from Rampart House we encountered very swift water and again passed several hours travelling 3 miles. Saturday evening we came to a riffle named "Sweegee" where it was necessary for 9 men to pull on a line. After 30 minutes of strenuous hauling, when the boat was within a short set of the head of the riffle, the line broke. The immediate result was that the barge and barge were violently rushed downstream and unfortunately the bottom of the barge struck a rock. After making a thorough examination it was found that the barge was leaking badly. One of the Indians boys was told off for the night to pump the water out of the barge until a steam syphon could be fixed. Instead of attending diligently to his duties he fell into the arms of Morpheus. About two Sunday morning, with a heavy rain falling, it was discovered that the Indians had been busy getting in their crops from the garden. Potatoes grew well this year. Chief Silas has two sacks stored in the missionary's cellar. The latter had about 600 lbs. of potatoes from his garden, all of excellent quality. One man had some large cabbages, and members of others have been grown. Meat has been fairly plentiful, as hunting trips are occasionally made up the Yukon. Some of the young men have been engaged on steamboats; others have been busy with rafts of wood, and helping white men on their farms. One or two of the older school boys have been so engaged.

St. Paul's, Dawson.

At the request of the Bishop the Rector of St. Paul's, Rev. John A. Davies, has made a visit to Rampart House Mission. An account of the trip will be found in the leading article of this issue. Mr. Davies was away from Dawson for seven weeks. During his absence the Rev. F. H. Buck took charge of the parish and conducted the regular services.

St. Paul's congregation is being greatly depleted. Many members have already left the North, and many more purpose leaving before the close of navigation. Several of the members of the church have enlisted for overseas service, including Commissioner George Black, Captain Yukon Infantry Company, and William G. Radford, church warden.

The annual W. A. service was held in St. Paul's on August 15th. The Rev. B. Totty administered the Holy Communion, assisted by Mr. Buck; while Mr. J. M. McCormick, Superintendent of the Church Camp Missions preached the sermon.

St. Barnabas', Moosehide.

The Indians of the mission have lately been busy getting in their crops from the garden. Potatoes grew well this year. Chief Silas has two sacks stored in the missionary's cellar. The latter had about 600 lbs. of potatoes from his garden, all of excellent quality. One man had some large cabbages, and members of others have been grown. Meat has been fairly plentiful, as hunting trips are occasionally made up the Yukon. Some of the young men have been engaged on steamboats; others have been busy with rafts of wood, and helping white men on their farms. One or two of the older school boys have been so engaged.

James Wood and others are back in the village. The latter gives valued help to the missionary. It is hoped that James will soon recommence his Sunday school class. The health of the village has been good for the last few months; and there is only one in the hospital at present.

The Peel River Indians had a happy and pleasant time here. Classes, services, and school were held for them, and a large number were confirmed. The Bishop and others visited the mission and met the Peel River Indians. The natives very much appreciated what was done for them, and went back to their hunting grounds with happy and contented hearts. Julius Kendi has gone to teach the Indians at Mayo. He needs our prayers.

St. James', Fortymile.

The peace and quiet of our parish was agreeably disturbed by visits of Dawson residents during the summer. Forty mile has assumed a new role, independent of the mining industry, so greatly diminished of recent years, by blossoming out into a health resort. The cares and distractions of "city life" may henceforth be dissipated by sundry trips to the oldest camp in the Territory.

Church Camp Mission.

During the first week of July Mr. Buck visited the power plant of the Canadian Klondike Company at the North Fork of the Klondike. Here a huge reservoir is being constructed, which will supply the needs of the Company for some time. A splendid service in the open air attended by the whole population was held by the missionary, and it certainly sounded grand to hear the old familiar tunes ring up to God in the great cathedral, of which the starry heavens formed the roof.

Early in July, Mr. J. M. McCormick arrived at Winnipeg to inspect the work in the Yukon. No time was lost in commencing the work. Splendid services were held at Black Hills and Eureka Creeks, where Mr. McCormick, with usual zeal, told the people the story of the glory of Jesus and His love. It is safe to say from the serious reverent faces of the men, and their hearty hand clasps, that the message was not given in vain. The reading room of the Mission at Fox Gulch was visited, and a series of photographs taken of the district, including pictures on Bonanza and Eldorado Creeks.

The following week Mr. McCormick, accompanied by Mr. Buck, journeyed to Mayo on the good ship "Civilian." A splendid service was held by Mr. Buck at Fraser Falls among the Indians, and three babies were baptized. The missionary and an Indian boy rowed forty miles to Mayo next day. Higher Creek, Minta Bridge, and the Silver King mine were visited in turn, and inspiring services were held. After this, "Mae the Sky Pilot" and his cheery personality will be as well known and liked in the Yukon as he is among the railway construction camps of the Rockies, or among those of the Welland Ship Canal, where the mission is performing so great a work for God. Leaving Mr. Buck at Mayo, Mr. McCormick returned to Dawson. A service at Mayo was held by the former, attended by nearly everyone in town; and the skills of the big bass drum and the deep manly voices sang the well-known hymn, "Jesus lover of my soul."

It is at times like these that one can lay aside all his doubts and fears, and feel a truth that God is close beside him. Before leaving the district the missionary visited Quartz Creek, a little English settlement away in the wilderness of the North, but where the services of the Church are indeed appreciated. Several requests for a celebration of the Holy Communion at the next visit of the missionary were made.

On the return trip to Dawson a service was held on the S.S. "Vidette." Many passengers from Dawson were on board. Capt. Barrington and all the men who could be spared were present. One of the men accompanied the singing on his guitar. The people remained some hours after the service singing hymns. After the hymn, all agreed that they had seldom enjoyed a Sunday evening as they did that one.

A few days later Mr. McCormick left Dawson for his home in Winnipeg, accompanied by his best wishes of all with whom he came in contact during his brief stay in the Yukon. He suffered considerably from the unaccustomed fatigues of the longday's marches, but he bore them with the same gameness and self-control that have made him for so many years the leader in the Church's work among the men in the camps.

For the ensuing six weeks Mr. Buck remained in charge of the church in Dawson, in the absence of the Rev. J. A. Davie at Rampart House. Since the latter's return Mr. Buck has held services at Fox Gulch, Galt River, and Chipibin Creek. As there were his fare well services before his journey outside with the Yukon Contingent, they were exceedingly well attended, despite the most inclement weather; and many were the wishes expressed for the success and safety of the return. Next Sunday he will visit Quartz Creek, which will be his last service before leaving for the Front.

School News.

Again there have been changes on the staff. Miss Dean found the work very heavy as her health was not of the best. She had wished to resign in June, but stayed on till late in August, as there was a little difficulty in finding a suitable worker. Miss C. E. Bennett, the new member of the Staff, will be known at least as near to many of our readers as she is a graduate of the Deafness House in Toronto. Her experience in Indian work has been gained at Lesser Slave Lake, while she has had a couple of years experience in parish work at St. Paul's, Edmonton.

Nearly all members of the Staff have now had their holidays. Miss Appleyard spent hers at Port Moody and Vancouver. Mr. and Mrs. Johnson and their two children are camping at Tagish. They have just sent in a part of their crops, some root that would make Eastern gardens green with envy.

This has been a summer of visitors. Besides between two and three hundred tourists, we have had a number who were directly connected with the work in the Yukon. Mr. McCormick, Superintendent of the Church Camp Mission, was able to stay several days with us on his return from Dawson. Mr.
The past summer has been very unfavourable for gardening. The Spring was late and cold, so that many of the seeds did not germinate. Yet in spite of many blank places in the field our potato crop was the largest yet. The yield was as follows: Potatoes 15 bushels, turnips 50 bushels, carrots 5 bushels, and other garden truck in small quantities. The dry summer had a telling effect on our hay crop. We managed to get sufficient for our needs, but the quality is much inferior to other years.

The school gratefully acknowledged gifts from the following churches: St. James' Cathedral, Church of the Redeemer, St. Simon's and St. Paul's of Toronto; St. Martin's of Montreal; St. George's of Kingston; St. Mark's, St. Michael's, St. Paul's, All Saints', St. James' and St. George's of Vancouver; St. Matthew's of Abbotsford, B.C.; and one bale from Tamworth, Ont.

A PRAYER USED AT NOON HOUR BY THE CHILDREN OF THE SCHOOL.

O Lord, we pray Thee for our soldiers and sailors, who are fighting the battles of our country; teach them at all times to put their trust in Thee; give them courage in time of danger, and mercy in time of sickness. We also pray Thee, O God, for the doctors, nurses and ministers, give them tenderness and skill in the healing both of pain and sorrow: And all we ask in the name of our Saviour, Jesus Christ.

Amen.

Great interest was taken in the plebiscite held on August 30th. The voting took place at the post office. Seventeen votes were cast, ten being in favor of Prohibition and seven against. This unexpected result caused much satisfaction to the "dry" supporters.

A remarkable instance of two unarmed men, by name Dryden and Sparks, beating off a bear with sticks, occurred on polling day. The men were on their way from their claim to vote, when their dog disturbed a bear and her cubs cranberry feeding. At a call from his master the dog returned followed by the bear, which immediately attacked Dryden, who, seizing a stick, attempted to defend himself. Accidentally falling, the bear now fully enraged, jumped on him, pinning him to the ground. His companion also arming himself with a stout cudgel, belabored the bear's nose to such effect as to cause her to release her victim and to turn upon her new assailant. Blow after blow was aimed at this vulnerable part of bear anatomy, whose owner, recognizing that discretion was the better part of valor, finally quitted the field. As a matter of fact the creature's nose was so badly punished, that for many a long day she will probably not look a human being in the face. Dryden and Sparks beat a hasty retreat, ever and anon looking back for fear of a renewed assault. Dryden was badly bruised and scratched about the face and shoulder, but otherwise was uninjured. He declares that but for the prompt and courageous conduct of his friend he must have lost his life, being absolutely at the bear's mercy. This story is one of the few bear stories which possesses the merit of being true.

Church Camp Mission.

During the first week of July Mr. Buck visited the power plant of the Canadian Klondike Company at the North Fork of the Klondike. Here a huge reservoir is being constructed, which will supply the need of the Company for some time. A splendid service in the open air, attended by the whole camp, was held by the missionary, and it certainly sounded grand to hear the old familiar tunes ring up to God in the great cathedral, of which the starry heavens formed the roof.

Early in July, Sup't J. M. Mc Cormick arrived from Winnipeg to inspect the work in the Yukon. No time was lost in commencing the work. Splendid services were held at Black Hills and Eureka Creeks, where Mr. McCormick, with usual force told the people the "old old story of Jesus and His love". It is safe to say from the serious reverent faces of the men, and their hearty hand clasps, that the message was not given in vain. The reading room of the Mission at Fox Guleh was visited, and a series of photographs taken of the different mining operations on Bonanza and Eldorado Creeks.

The following week Mr. McCormick, accompanied by Mr. Buck, journeyed to Mayo on the good ship "Vidette". A splendid service was held by Mr. Buck at Fraser Falls among the Indians, and three babies were baptized. The missionary and an Indian boy rowed forty miles to Mayo next
covered that the barge was within 3 inches of being underwater. On becoming forcibly acquainted with his danger every person on board seized his bed and hurled it to the shore as quickly as possible, and thus was our immediate danger averted. After the barge had been duly repaired we resumed our journey but did not reach our destination until August 16th. Distance covered 50 miles. Time 22 days.

On arrival at Rampart House all the Indians of the district, 125 in all, were assembled on shore waiting to shake hands and extend a cordial welcome. After being enthusiastically received, it was necessary to listen to all the individual trials and woes of the past year which ranged in importance from the death of Paul Stephen's mother-in-law to William's tug-out need of a ball of twine wherewith to repair his fish net, and old Eliza's desperate request for a pipe of tobacco. In the evening the ship's pilot made a feast and a dance. The whole community was invited. The first call having been sounded there was no alternative but to partake of an abundant repast of mulligan with 50 or 60 other guests in a cabin 15 feet square. Supper ended personal appreciation had to be shown by witnessing a few "jigs" and "squares" in the traders' warehouse. The days were all too short. Services were held in the church daily. Personal help and counsel were given to Amos, the native clergyman. An English day school was opened with twenty pupils enrolled, whose ages range from 6 to 16. Jacob Njoottli, a graduate of Carcross school is in charge. The older people were told of the need of self-support in so far as practicable. Their willingness to help was shown in the amount of the annual collection which realized $56 in cash and $24 in furs. The men voluntarily promised to go to the woods sometime during the coming Winter and cut suitable logs wherewith to erect a schoolhouse 14 x 20 feet. The annual Communion service was administered on Sunday morning August 20th when 71 Indians attended. Amos read the service in the native tongue, except the parts to be read by the priest. First he recited the "Order For Morning Prayer", followed by the Holy Communion, which included the various exhortations and all the offertory sentences. Such zeal on the part of a native is not to be belittled, although it may be more or less trying to an outsider. The collection plate was piled high with gifts which included 34 boxes of matches, 2 planks of Hudson Bay tobacco and $8.50 in cash. The evening service was conducted in English for the benefit of the trappers and others.

Next morning I began my return trip in company with 2 Indian families, 3 children, and 11 dogs, in a poling boat. When the wind was favourable we made use of an improvised sail but for 4 days the wind was contrary and we were compelled to use the oars. The return trip to Fort Yukon occupied 6 days during which time I conducted 3 Communion services each time to Indians isolated from the missions. By day we dined on ducks, fish, and moose, around the camp fire, and by night slept beneath the trees. On arriving at Fort Yukon the socialism of the Indians proved that I was a temporary Indian in more ways than one.

On account of a delay in the steam boats up bound on the Yukon a stopover of 10 days was unavoidable. However the opportunity of addressing the Fort Yukon Indians was afforded by the courtesy of the Rev. William Loola, native missionary in charge, and also of assisting the medical missionary, Dr. Burke, in his services for the "white" population. Moreover it was a great pleasure to enjoy the friendship and hospitality of Dr. and Mrs. Burke. It may be of interest to note that when a boy William Loola was trained by the late Arch-

McTavish is a printer by trade, and the time he spent with the boys in the print shop is having a telling effect in the getting out of the present issue of the paper. Mr. Hawkshaw, Superintendent of Indian Affairs for the Yukon, made his semi-annual visit of inspection during the last week of August. At the same time the Bishop was with us. He was returning to Dawson from the Provincial Synod in Edmonton. Our next visitor was Miss K. Martin, a new worker in the Diocese. Miss Martin is to be located at Selkirk, where she will teach the Indian day school.

Two of our oldest pupils, Charles Teyah and Jessie Charlie, graduated this year. Jessie deserves special mention, as she has been at the school for ten years. During the past year she was able to help in the school work by teaching one of the primer classes.

On the invitation of Archbishop Du Vernet, Rev. W. T. Townsend made a trip to Atlin, B.C. With the exception of two miles on a little puffing railway between the lakes, the journey is entirely by water. Atlin is the centre of a thriving mining district. During the past summer there was a large tourist traffic, as the trip is one of the finest in the North. There is no minister of any denomination in the camp, although the Church of England has both a church and a rectory. Captain Hathorn, a retired officer of the British Navy, acts as voluntary lay-reader. Mr. Townsend received a hearty welcome, and enjoyed every minute of his stay.

The past summer has been very unfavourable for gardening. The spring was late and cold, so that many of the seeds did not germinate. Yet in spite of many blank places in the field our potato crop was the largest yet. The yield was as follows: Potatoes 115 bushels, turnips 50 bushels, carrots 5 bushels, and other garden truck in small quantities. The dry summer had a telling effect on our hay crop. We managed to get sufficient for our needs, but the quality is much inferior to other years.

A PRAYER USED AT NOON HOUR, BY THE CHILDREN OF THE SCHOOL.

O Lord, we pray Thee for our soldiers and sailors, who are fighting the battles of our country; teach them at all times to put their trust in Thee; give them courage in time of danger, and mercy in time of victory. We also pray Thee, O our God, for the doctors, nurses and ministers; give them tenderness and skill in the healing both of pain and sorrow; And all we ask in the name of our Saviour, Jesus Christ. Amen.

Leaving Mr. Buck at Mayo, Mr. McCormick returned to Dawson. A service at Mayo was held by the former, attended by nearly everyone in town, and the walls of the log school house rang as the deep manly voices sang the well known hymn, "Jesus lover of my soul". It is at times like these that one can lay aside all his doubts and fears, and feel of a truth that God is close beside him.

Before leaving the district, the missionary visited Haggart Creek, a little English settlement away in the wilds of the North, but where the services of the Church are indeed appreciated. Several requests for a celebration of the Holy Communion at the next visit of the missionary were made.

On the return to Dawson a service was held on the S.S. "Vidette". Many passengers from Dawson were on board. Capt. Barrington and all the men who could be spared were present. One of the men accompanied the singing on his guitar. The people remained for some hours after the service singing hymn after hymn. All agreed that they had seldom enjoyed a Sunday evening as they did that one.

A few days later Mr. McCormick left Dawson for his home in Winnipeg, accompanied by the best wishes of all with whom he came in contact during his brief stay in the Yukon. He suffered considerably from the unaccustomed fatigues of the long day's marches, but he bore them with the same gaiety and self-control that have made him for so many years the leader in the Church's work among the men in the camps.

For the ensuing six weeks Mr. Buck remained in charge of the church in Dawson, in the absence of the Rev. J. A. Davies at Rampart House. Since the latter's return Mr. Buck has held services at Fox Gulch, Gold Run, and Sulphur Creek. As these were his fare well services before his journey outside with the Yukon Contingent, they were exceedingly well attended, despite the most inclement weather; and many were the wishes expressed for the missionary's good luck and safe return. Next Sunday he will visit Quartz Creek, which will be his last service before leaving for the Front.

School News.

Again there have been changes on the Staff. Mrs. Dean found the work very heavy, as her health was not of the best. She had wished to resign in June, but stayed on till late in August, as there was a little difficulty in finding a suitable worker. Miss C. E. Bennett, the new member of the Staff, will be known, at least by name, to many of our readers. She is a graduate of the Deaconess House in Toronto. Her experience in Indian work has been gained at Lesser Slave Lake, while she has had a couple of years' experience in parish work at St. Paul's in Edmonton.

Nearly all the members of the Staff have now had their holidays. Miss Appleyard spent hers at Port Moody and Vancouver. Mr. and Mrs. Johnson and their two children are camping at Tagish. They have just sent in as part of their sport some trout that would make Eastern anglers green with envy.

This has been a summer of visitors. Besides between two and three hundred tourists, we have had a number who were directly connected with the work in the Yukon. Mr. McCormick, Superintendent of the Church Camp Mission, was able to stay several days with us on his return from Dawson. Mr.

Dear Sir:

Last year one of our boys in the Carcross Indian Boarding School named Alfred Ellis, graduated, as he had passed the age limit. He is an orphan and has been in the school from the time he was a small child. He was willing to remain on at the school, and temporary arrangements were made to retain his services as a worker to be paid at the rate of $20.00 per month. He is an exceptionally good boy, and is especially useful in the printing shop and the shoe repair shop.

I wish to ask your department to allow him at the rate of $20.00 per month. I understood that sometimes you help graduate students, and this seems to be an exceptional case. We may need to give him more than this after a time, but if your department will allow at this rate it would help out materially. The school, of course, would provide his board which costs a good deal, especially at the present time.

I shall be pleased to hear from you in this matter and I am sure you will take an interest in the case of this boy. I remain,

Yours sincerely,

J. O. Stringer

Dear Sir,

I wish to ask you for a grant of $700.00 towards defraying the expenses of fuel for the Carcross Indian Boarding School. During the last year about (150) one hundred and fifty cords of wood were used. The staff together with the older boys did a great deal of work in providing a portion of this. Last year we had a number of big boys in the school who were a considerable help. Most of these are leaving the school this Summer, and Mr. Johnson, the principal, has decided that it will be impossible to procure the wood themselves for next Winter. He is therefore endeavouring to get someone outside to supply one hundred (100) cords of wood by contract. The staff and the boys will also do what they can in procuring wood. We find, further, that if the bigger boys have to spend all their spare time in getting wood the teaching of other practical departments, such as carpentering, has to be neglected.

As you can readily understand, the cost of supplies for the school has gone up tremendously the last couple of years, and we find it increasingly difficult to finance the school with the per capita grant which the department has given us. If it were possible to increase the per capita grant to $200.00 it would, of course, help us out of the difficulty.

I shall be glad if you will do what you can in the matter, and oblige,

Yours sincerely,

J. O. Stringer
Bishop of Yukon.

Rev. Sir -

Your two communications of July 26th, last, one application for a grant of $700.00 towards defraying expenses of fuel for the Carcross Indian Boarding School, and the other for a grant for Alfred Ellis, have been brought to my attention.

With regard to the former, I realize the extra strain that war conditions have placed upon the management of this institution, as well as similar institutions throughout Canada. Beyond the small increase in the per capita grant made sometime ago, no special provision has been made by Parliament to meet these abnormal demands.

With regard to the boy, Alfred Ellis, while I quite appreciate the recommendations that you give him, I think the Department may be considered to have dealt very fairly with him in so much that it has educated him for 13 years at a cost of nearly $5,000.00. At 18 years of age he should be in a position to earn his own living, either in the institution itself or the work he is engaged in at present or outside. Of course the costs of management including wages such as this must be borne by the school from their per capita funds or other available funds.

I regret very much that it is not possible for me to consider favourably either of Your Lordship's requests.

Yours very truly,

Deputy Superintendent General.

Sir,

I have been informed by the Bishop of Yukon that the Rev Dr Westgate has written him in reference to the enlargement of the Carcross Indian Residential School to provide accommodation for 200 pupils. Whether I should write on this matter until asked to do so by the Department is a question, however, with all due respect to Dr Westgate I venture to suggest that he is not sufficiently familiar with the conditions here to form any reliable judgment as to the need of enlarging the school. Last summer he visited Carcross and Whitehorse at the south end of the Territorial Road very few Indians, talked the matter over with the Principal who at that time had less than a year's experience in the Yukon under these circumstances a knowledge of the real need of enlargement could not very well be obtained.

The Bishop of the Yukon says that it is out of the question to fill a school large enough to accommodate 200 pupils. Accommodation for 50 or 60 at the most would be ample and he was not certain that this number could be kept up regularly.

If I may be permitted to express an opinion on this subject I would say that under existing conditions the school as it now stands is large enough to meet the demands. It will be seen from reports of past years that the school has not always been full only in the last year or two have the full number been in residence. From experience I find how difficult it is to get Indian parents to send their children to a residential school, a candidate or two on the waiting list does more to enhance the value of the school in the Indian mind than a constant pleading for children to fill vacancies.

These northern Indians are quite a different type to those of the plains not nearly so far advanced in civilization, many of their old superstitions remain and are not easily overcome. They do not fully realize as yet the benefit of education I speak from 35 years experience of work amongst them.

All these things have to be taken into consideration before the expenditure in enlargement is undertaken and I respectfully submit them to you for that purpose.

Your obedient servant,

John Hawkesley,
Indian Superintendent.
