The Mission Fields

HERSCHEL ISLAND AND SHINGLE POINT.

Very little information has come through from the Arctic Coast since the last issue of Northern Lights. A wireless message early in the New Year indicated that everything was going on as usual. We can imagine the Reverends W. A. Geddes and A. C. McCullum carrying on the services and holding school at one or other of the central stations, and also making trips to the different settlements of Eskimos on the Arctic Coast.

The long, dark, sunless days are well over by the middle of January, and as the length of sunlight increases about half an hour each week, the missionaries and Eskimos among the hills take a new lease of life and gladness seems to replace the gloom. The song intoned by the Eskimos on the return of the sun after an absence of many weeks seems to express the feelings of all. Translated into English it means "Now we shall live another year; we have seen the sun once more."

RAMPART HOUSE AND OLD CROW.

From latest reports received the Indians were well and prosperous. During the early part of the winter the caribou swarmed over the hills in greater numbers than usual, and the people were able to get a good supply of meat for themselves and their dogs. This meant much for the Indians as very few fish were caught last summer. Foxes and other fur bearing animals were plentiful and the people expected a good season's catch.

John Tizya, the veteran Indian Lay Reader, conducts services regularly at Old Crow. They miss Mr. Moody who is now located at Fort Yukon.

Two young children died at Old Crow, but otherwise the general health has been very good.

Mrs. Julia McDonald, the widow of the late Archdeacon McDonald, is making her home again this winter at Old Crow where her son, Neil McDonald, has a trading post. Her letters are quite cheerful and she sends cordial greetings to all her friends.

HEAD OF PEEL AND PORCUPINE.

Some of the Indian men from this place came into Mooseshide for the Christmas season but Richard Martin remained to hold services for those who were left behind. He reports having had a very happy time with the people who appreciated the services of the Church especially at the Christmas season. On his arrival in Dawson in January he received a wireless message from his brother, the Rev. John Martin, who formerly lived on the Yukon side, and who is now stationed at Akla-vik, stating that Jane's daughter, Maggie, was married on Christmas Day. Mr. Fred Firth, youngest son of Mr. John Firth, the patriarchal retired officer of the Hudson's Bay Company at Fort McPherson, Bishop Rompas Memorial Church, Mooseshide.

The Christmas festivities are at an end in this little village, and the
Indians are getting back to their usual routine of work, hunting, trapping and wood chopping.

The Christmas and New Year Services in church were very well attended. The natives who had several opportunities of preaching to the congregations, and their words were attentively listened to by the people. The Bishop has been amongst us, and encouraged and cheered us by his presence and example. The Church was filled by an eager and expectant congregation on Christmas morning, when the Holy Communion was administered to a good number of Indians.

The usual collection was made on behalf of the Indians, and subscriptions were also made by the natives towards the expense of painting their church next summer. They seemed glad to give to these objects according to their means.

Ped River Indians have returned to their hunting grounds in the woods. Their stay in the village amongst the Mowichelle Indians and in church with the people was found very helpful and inspiring, especially so with regard to the hymn-singing. They led all the hymns in church with much ability.

The lay-reader and others were always ready to give of their best in this good work. One of them was busy for a few days sitting for his examination with a view to being admitted to Deacon's Orders by his Lordship the Bishop.

There were a large number of gifts on the children's Christmas tree, many of them very useful articles. All are indebted to kind friends who so generously contributed to the pleasure and enjoyment of the young folks. Teaching in school is continued as usual. The winter term was commenced a few days ago with a good attendance.

A number of the Indians have been sick and some are still ailing. All are well cared for by the Indian Department.

We are depending on the goodwill, interest and prayers of the readers of our mission notes for continued patience, perseverance, and success in the work under God's blessing and guidance.

Benjamin Toty
St. Mary's Church, Mayo.

While we have no direct communications from Northern Lights from Mayo, we have other reports indicating that the Church work in Mayo and Keno is having an exceptional winter.

The Rev. G. F. Leigh, who was recently ordained for this work, is entering into his labors with great enthusiasm and the people are responding.

Lieutenant Talbot, who was recently transferred from Dawson to Mayo, and who is a talented musician, has given invaluable services in organizing and training a choir.

Mayo and Keno are making steady progress and a general spirit of optimism prevails throughout the camps.

St. Paul's Church, Dawson.

The Christmas and New Year's Season in Dawson was favored by the most ideal weather imaginable. For several days before Christmas and for several days after we had entered on the new year, not once did the thermometer drop as low as zero, and at the time this article is written (January 12th) the weather is still very mild.

The Christmas Services at St. Paul's were attended by about the usual numbers in spite of the declining population, and the reports given at the annual parishioners' meeting were of very encouraging nature. While the Sunday School records are not available for the whole history of the parish it is doubtful if they were ever higher than in 1925, which showed an average attendance of 147 for four and an income of over two hundred dollars. The congregations have kept up remarkably well in comparison with former years, and the church collections during 1925 were larger than they have been since 1916.

It may seem strange to our readers to find in this article a sense of satisfaction in keeping up with the past, but we have only to state that in 1909 the population of Dawson exceeded twenty thousand and that it has gradually declined until in 1925 there were considerably less than one thousand in Dawson.

The Woman's Auxiliary in all its branches have excelled in the work of their activities. The payment on the parish hall and rectory has been met in full and the missionary assessment on the parish has been oversubscribed by a considerable amount.

On the last Sunday evening of the year the rector of St. Paul's Church conducted a service at Bear Creek. There are only five families at Bear Creek this winter (two of the five have since moved into Dawson) but the people came from creeks adjoining until a congregation of thirty had assembled.

Resignation of Bishop Lucas.

The Right Reverend J. R. Lucas, D.D., Bishop of Mackenzie River, has resigned as Bishop, his resignation to take effect at the end of March.

For thirty-four years Bishop Lucas has served as missionary, Archdeacon, Diocesan Secretary and Treasurer, and Bishop in the remote districts of Athabasca and Mackenzie River. He was consecrated Bishop in succession to Bishop Rowe in 1913. His zeal and perseverance have been remarkable and both Bishop and Mrs. Lucas will be much missed throughout the whole of Mackenzie River.

May God continue to bless and use them wherever they may be located.

The choice of a successor rests with the Provincial Synod of Rupert's Land. Between the meetings of the Provincial Synod the selection is made by an appointed standing committee representing all the Dioceses of the Province. They meet the people who are interested that God may guide them and that the most suitable man may be chosen.

Northern Lights extends congratulations to Rt. Rev. P. T. Rowe, Bishop of Alaska, on the response which he has received to his appeal for assistance to missions with the epidemic of influenza last summer at Fort Yukon and other parts of his diocese. In a recent issue of Spirit of Missions it was stated that the response to his appeal had reached the sum of nearly fifteen thousand dollars, and subscriptions were still coming in.
St. Paul's Hostel, Dawson.

(By Bishop Stringer)

This year the Hostel was the scene of one of the brightest and merriest Christmas records for this comparatively young Institution. On the night before Christmas a number of visitors shared the warm hospitality of the Hostel's executive and staff at a cheery dinner party which was followed by the arrival of Santa Claus and his wife and the disbursement of many presents which weighed down the branches of the Hostel's prettily decorated Christmas Tree. Amidst the tinkling of sleigh bells, and with many a twinkling eye in the capable and bearded-faced old gentleman and his wife, who were attired in their crimson and time honored regalia, the messengers of good cheer burst in upon the merry band of enthusiastic children and happy guests.

There were presents for everybody. How the youngest and most delightful of them all rejoiced! The girls fondled their newly delivered dolls in raptures of appreciation, while soon the newly acquired steam engines, jack knives and other presents which the boys received, were very much in evidence.

On Christmas morning the staff and the children all assembled so early in St. Paul Cathedral Church where the Christmas spirit was co-mingled in the touching services and the beautiful anthems. Music which breathed with the delightful charm of the Christmas spirit added a realistic touch to the appropriate sermon delivered by the Rector, Archdeacon Shirley.

Evening followed with a special feast of good things to eat for all the children and the staff, making their Christmas one of good cheer filled with sweet memories.

A few of the children, whose parents live within reach of Dawson, were able to spend part of the holiday season in their own homes, but in the majority of cases, relations and friends of the children live at long distances from Dawson. But although, however, the Hostel, are brought to a very close realization of the joys that the great holiday season holds in store.

New Year's Day also proved an enjoyable holiday for the children. With the passing of this happy season, all again settled down to the routine of studies and duties, but with a much greater anticipation of the holidays festivities which will linger clearly in their memories for another year.

Twenty Years A Bishop.

December 17th was the twentieth anniversary of the consecration of the Rev. I. O. Stringer as Bishop of Yukon. The consecration took place in St. John's Church, Winnipeg in 1905.

On the evening of the anniversary a public reception was held at the rectory and the people of Dawson, irrespective of creed, came in large numbers to extend their congratulations to Bishop and Mrs. Stringer and to wish them continued health to carry on their work.

A presentation in recognition of the event is to be made at a later date, as soon as communications can be received from the distant parts of the diocese.

Pioneer Called By Death.

St. Paul's congregation has sustained a great loss in the death of William Galpin. Coming into Yukon in the great stampede of 1898, telling his friends in England that he expected to be back in two years, he made the North his home and his last resting place on earth.

While he came to engage in mining he was soon back in his chosen profession, teaching. In speaking at the funeral Bishop Stringer said that the deceased had been a teacher for over fifty years and had, he thought, rendered a longer service to the educational work of Yukon than any other teacher had ever rendered.

The cause of death was cancer, yet he stuck to his duty to the end. He taught school on Friday, going into the hospital on Sunday where, within three weeks, he passed away.

He was a loyal and devoted churchman, serving as layreader on Quartz Creek where he was engaged in mining, and in Dawson and Whitehorse he was choir master. Religion entered deeply into his daily life and gave him a wonderful influence over his pupils. In them his life and ideals will continue.

Our deepest sympathy is extended to Mrs. Galpin in her bereavement.

Dear Sir:

I have just received your letter of June 28th (166-1-1) in which you refer to certain conditions at the Carcross Indian Residential School as reported to your Department by the Indian Superintendent for the Yukon. In reply I beg to state that for two or three months past our Society has been very deeply concerned about the conditions which have obtained at this institution. Our concern arose in the first place, out of the illness of one of the lady agents (Mrs. Morrison) who tendered her resignation and returned to her home in British Columbia. Another lady agent was immediately secured and sent to the School to take her place. Just at that time an epidemic of influenza laid hold on the School and prostrated a number of the children and two lady members of the staff. The children I am happy to be able to state have all, so far as I have been informed, made a good recovery and I heartily wish that I could make the same statement with regard to the members of the staff. One of these, (Miss Ingram) as soon as she was convalescent and able to travel, tendered her resignation and has since returned to her home in Victoria. The other lady agent Miss Helen Bushell was so seriously ill that she had to be taken to the Hospital at Whitehorse. For some weeks we had hopes that she too might recover, but in this we were sadly disappointed, when we received a telegram on June 14th stating that she had died on the previous day. As soon as information was received that the numerical strength of the staff was reduced below its normal strength through the serious illness of these two lady agents, steps were taken to secure others to take their place, and although appointments have not yet been actually made, it is expected that this will be done in the very near future.

From the above information it will be clear to you that
A certain amount of disorganization in the daily routine of the School was inevitable. When Miss Bushell's services were no longer available for the Kitchen duties, Miss Ridgeway who is the teacher and head matron, and a fully qualified dietician, felt it her duty to leave the class-room and take over the Kitchen work in order that the health of the school and staff should suffer as little as possible. When she retired from the class-room I was under the impression that Mr. Bagshaw, the Principal had undertaken this duty. This he appears not to have done, and I have written to him asking for an explanation. That he, as Principal of the School, should have taken over these duties, there is no question in my own mind whatever, except that certain circumstances which have not yet been reported to me, made it impossible for him to do so. As I have written to him for an explanation I do not see that further action can be taken until this has been received.

There is a strong probability that I myself may visit this institution during the month of August, but in the meantime I should like to assure you that the whole situation is receiving our Society's very careful attention and I hope to be able to inform you in the near future that completely satisfactory conditions again obtain.

I remain, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

Sir:

I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of June 28th, file No 166-1-10, in reference to the general conditions at the Carcross Indian Residential School, mainly through the illness of two members of the staff, one of whom died in the Whitehorse hospital.

In reply I beg to say that I have recently returned from a visit to the above school and regret that I have to report that I found things much disorganized. No teaching had been done since April 15th; Miss Ridgeway was acting as cook and in addition had undertaken all the nursing duties to members of the staff as well as to some of the pupils. She was on the verge of a nervous breakdown and had to go away for complete rest. Some of the older girls took charge of the kitchen. Miss Nevill arrived from the Alert Bay school and took over the kitchen work, a girl's Matron was expected from Vancouver in a few days.

Discipline was at a low ebb. Three of the boy pupils ran away from the school they got as far as Whitehorse where they stole a boat and started down the Yukon River. They were seen about 10 miles below the town by an ex-pupil who called them ashore, flagged a passing steamer and returned the boys and the boat to Whitehorse. I had just reached there on my return from a visit to the Champagne Indians, I took charge of the boys and returned with them to the school. Their joint fares for steamer and train was $21.50. Two of the truants were new boys who found the regulations of the school irksome. It is fortunate they were seen otherwise I am afraid they would have come to grief in some of the rapids.

The members of the staff were discontented, not so much with regard to their pay which is about $1.00 per day, as the meager rations they were allowed which are considered insufficient. This seems to be the main reason why there so many changes.

The usual examination was postponed until my visit in September when the teacher will be free to attend the schoolroom.

Some of the local Indians requested me to allow their children leave the school as they were not being educated.
It would appear that too much freedom is allowed the pupils especially in the matter of visiting the town which is about two miles from the school, and attending dances which keep them out late.

There is a good deal of criticism, both among whites and Indians, regarding the unsatisfactory state of affairs. The Bishop of Yukon visited the school recently, he wrote me saying, "You will find things at the school unsatisfactory. I hope you may be able to do something to straighten up matters."

When the Principal was spoken to in reference to the state of affairs he claimed that it was due to the slowness of the Indian and Eskimo School Commission in filling vacancies.

Are the school authorities liable for the amount disbursed in returning the three truants to the school?

Your obedient servant,

John Hawksley.

It is with many regrets that I sever my connection with Northern Lights. The publication has been one of the most interesting features of my four years work in Yukon, and has brought me into contact with a great many people. I am leaving Yukon to become assistant in the work at All Saint's Church, Pasadena. As a considerable number of our readers live in California, and many others visit there, we hope to meet many personally whom we have as yet only met through the columns of Northern Lights. I desire to express my appreciation of the support and encouragement given me by our readers during these last four years and trust that the same kindly consideration will be given to my successor as editor, Rev. W. H. L. West of Whitehorse.

Sincerely yours,

J. A. Shirley

It is really with fear and trembling that I take over the editing and management of Northern Lights because I fear that to follow after one who has accomplished so much, is far beyond my limitations. Nevertheless it will be my objective to maintain the fine standard that has been attained to by my predecessors in office.

The success of the publication not only depends upon our correspondents in various parts of the Diocese but upon our subscribers who have so generously supported the paper in the past.

To our correspondents in the various posts manned by the Diocese may I ask for your cooperation. Send your news items in early and regularly and much delay and disappointment will be avoided.

To our subscribers may I ask for your continued support. You can assist by not allowing your subscription to fall behind. I feel that only this reminder is needed in order to have all delinquents send in their arrears, otherwise it will in future be necessary to cut them from our mailing lists, as the sum charged, twenty-five cents per annum, the smallest coin in use in many parts of Yukon, is not exorbitant and barely covers the cost of printing, mailing, etc.

May I therefore ask for your cooperation. Friendly criticism is always welcome and makes for progress.

Yours faithfully,

W. H. L. West,

On Sunday morning, June 6th, 1926, a very interesting event took place in the Old Log Church at Whitehorse, Yukon, Canada, when Mr. J. H. Byrne, B.A., a graduate of Emmanuel College, Saskatoon, was made a Deacon.

Following the Litany, the Ordination Service took place, the sermon being preached by Rev. G. A. Bagsshaw, Principal of the Choota Indian School of Carcross. The candidate was presented by the Rev. W. H. L. West, L. Th., Rector of Christ Church, Whitehorse. The Ordination proper followed, the Rt. Rev. I. O. Stringer, B. A., D. D., Bishop of Yukon, officiating, and other Missionaries present were Mr. G. C. Ashbee, Missionary in Charge of Little Salmon and Carmacks, and Mr. Alex J. Stringer, who is in charge of the Mission at Champagne Landing.

Following his ordination Rev. J. H. Byrne preached at the Evening Service, and later went on to Carmacks and Little Salmon to initiate the new recruit for the work at these points, afterwards going to the Ross River settlement. It is understood that after his return Mr. Byrne is to temporarily succeed Rev. J. A. Shirely in Dawson, and will be in charge of the pro-Cathedral until a successor is found for this part of the work.

Work was commenced at Teslin early in June, and although there were not many Indians at the post school was commenced. Bishop and Mrs. Stringer visited us on the 14th. A service was held in the evening, which was well attended by both the white and native people. There was a celebration of Holy Communion the next morning, and many infants were baptized in the afternoon. At 11.30 p.m. with the aid of a flashlight the Bishop baptized another infant, and he and Mrs. Stringer left on the Thistle at midnight. Their visit was much enjoyed by all.

But a few days after the departure of the Thistle and the great majority of the Indians came down to the post. The school attendance rose to 33, but the usual epidemic of a mild flu meant a very fluctuating attendance.

One very sad accident took the heart right out of the native people. Matthew Jackson, one of the young men, met his death while engaged in cutting the winter wood. He being the eldest son and only newly married, made his loss keenly felt. He was laid to rest on the ninth day of July.

Carmacks and Ross River.

The missionary activities at the centres, Little Salmon, Carmacks and Ross River, commenced for the year 1926 with the arrival of Messrs Ashbee and Byrne at Whitehorse on June 3rd, from the Steamer Princess Mary.

On the Sunday following their arrival Mr. Byrne was ordained to the Diaconate. This necessitated a stay in Whitehorse of one week.

On Wednesday, June 9th, both missionaries started down the river on the Steamer Casca. At Little Salmon a large number of Indians had already gathered and more were expected. Here Mr. Ashbee received his initiation into Indian work. Mr. Byrne, who had been in the work for the two previous summers, remaining for a or two for that purpose.

Thursday evening was spent in renewing acquaintances both by visiting at the camp and games. Friday school was opened with an attendance of thirteen. The attendance increased considerably subsequently and a promising summer seems to be ahead. On Saturday Mr. Byrne left for Carmacks, leaving Mr. Ashbee to carry on at Little Salmon.

At Carmacks the greater part of the time was spent in repairing the mission house, which has to undergo a thorough overhauling in preparation for permanent residence. During the week's sojourn two services were held for the white people and one for the Indians. Of the latter there were just a few in the village.

Little Salmon.

Work began at Little Salmon this summer on June 10th. Last winter having been a poor fur year in this district it has been difficult to get children to day school for any length of time, as the Indians are compelled to make frequent excursions in search of moose meat. Altogether thirty-two scholars have attended school this summer, although only half that number have been regular in their attendance. Church services have all been well attended.

The weather has not been good, there having been one or two thunder storms and heavy rain on several occasions. This has resulted in a number of minor cases of sickness, and two fatal cases of pneumonia. Little Salmon Johnnie died in Whitehorse General Hospital on July 4th, and Pat Pelly died at Little Salmon on July 10th. Both were buried in the burial ground at Little Salmon. The two deaths in such a short time have cast a cloud over the tribe at Little Salmon, and most of them left the district soon after the second death.

An interesting event took place at St. Peter's Church on the 15th July, when the first wedding since 1914 was held there. The contracting parties were Mr. George E. Walker, trader, of Little Salmon, and Miss Jessie Smith, of Whitehorse. The Rev. W. H. L. West, L.Th., Rector of Whitehorse, performed the ceremony, and Mr. G. C. Ashbee, missionary at Little Salmon, was "best man." After the wedding the Rector and best man were guests at the wedding breakfast at the home of the bride and bridegroom.

At eight o'clock the same evening Mr. West and Mr. Ashbee, with Donald, Mr. Walker's son, left for Carmacks in a row boat.
Apart from a few over zealous mosquitos, during a halt which was made for a midnight lunch, the forty-five mile trip was most enjoyable, though a little strenuous. Arriving at Carmacks at 2.45 a.m., a few hours sleep was taken, followed by a visit to all the white families in the village. There were no Indians there so the "trio" returned on the Steamer Whitehorse in the evening. First aid was successfully rendered by the missionaries to a lady tourist who was taken ill on the boat, as there was no doctor on board.

A large number of minor sicknesses and casualties have been dealt with. There is a vast amount of work to be done among this people. In addition to teaching the Gospel message, consistent education in hygiene, personal cleanliness and right living, as well as in the three "R's," is essential. All these things take time and patience, but with God's help, and the prayers of all those who are interested in the spreading of the Kingdom of Heaven on earth, the seed consistently sown will grow, and the result will be true-living, God-fearing Indian men and women.

The Rev G.A. Bagshaw, Principal of the Carcross Indian Residential School writes that Mr T. Storey and he have both resigned their respective positions in the school and will be leaving Carcross on December 29th. Both resignations have been accepted by the Indian and Eskimo School Commission.

With Bishop Stringer On The Porcupine.

The Rev. A. C. McCullum was ordained to the Priesthood by the Bishop of the Diocese on Sunday, August the first, at Old Crow on the Porcupine river.

Mr. McCullum had arrived a few days before from the Arctic Coast, coming by way of the portage over the mountains to La Pierre's House.

The Bishop met him on the river and spent a week or more with him visiting the Indians along the Porcupine.

The ordination service was held in the little log building used for a Church, the congregation consisting of all the Indians with the few white residents, the building being packed to the door.

No other clergyman was available to assist and Mr. McCullum was presented by Mr. Neil McDonald, a son of the late Archdeacon McDonald, a trader at Old Crow village.

Though the surroundings were most primitive the service was impressive and solemn.

During the week spent at this place the Indians were busy erecting a new log church, giving their time freely and without charge.

Mr. McCullum hoped to have his radio in working order before winter.

Dawson and Moosehide.

Bishop Stringer returned from the Porcupine about the middle of August and on Sunday, the 22nd of August, he ordained as Priest the Rev. J. H. Byrne, B.A.

The Rev. Canon B. Totty assisted, and the sermon was preached by Rev. G. H. Moody, who was visiting in Dawson at the time.

On the same day Rev. Richard Martin, a Takudh Indian, was ordained to the Diaconate in the Bishop Bompas Memorial Church, Moosehide. The Rev. Canon Totty, who had done much during the past several years in preparing the candidate for Holy Orders, presented him to the Bishop who preached the sermon.

Before the close of the service the new Deacon spoke to the people, asking for their prayers that he might be kept humble and be used in God's work among his people as he travelled from place to place.
During the summer months the little town of Carcross takes on quite a different aspect.

Whereas during the winter months we could have numbered our population on the fingers of our two hands, now during the summer months we have been alive with the "dainty, painted, powdered and gay" that Molloy sings about in his "London Bridge." Over three thousand tourists have passed through Carcross this summer, either to the North or to Atlin and Ben-McChree. They have helped us to look on the brighter side of life with their free and easy manner, and they have been generous, kind-hearted and thoughtful. Our little Church has oftentimes been full to overflowing at the morning service with tourists who have always given us the glad hand and a merry smile after the service in thankfulness that they have been privileged to worship once more in the House of God as a unit in that vast company of God's worshippers, irrespective of creed and caste. They have also been generous in their alms:

The Chootla Indian School, Carcross.

We regret to have to report the passing of one of our staff, Miss Helen Bushell, who held the position of kitchen matron. Miss Bushell came to us on the tenth of March and was taken seriously ill six weeks later. She was removed to the hospital at Whitehorse where, after a lingering illness, she passed away on Sunday, June 13th. The remains were brought to Carcross and rested in the little Church until Wednesday, June 16th, when the interment took place at the Indian Cemetery. The Burial Service was read by the Principal, assisted by the Rector of Whitehorse. Six boys from the School bore the coffin to the graveside. Many friends from Carcross attended the funeral, and the whole school, attended by the staff, walked in procession. Numerous tributes of flowers and cards of sympathy covered the casket. The late Miss Bushell was a native of Salisbury, England, being born there 43 years ago. She has left two brothers, A. B. Bushell of Chingford, England, and H. J. Bushell, of Kensington Road, Toronto.

We are glad to report that we have now a full and efficient staff. Miss Nevill, who has seen much service in Mission Schools, is our kitchen matron; Miss Ridgeway, teacher; Miss Smith, boys' supervisor; Miss Cameron, girls' supervisor. Mr. Storey, who came to us at the same time as the late Miss Bushell, is an enthusiastic general assistant. His labours in the gar-
den have borne good results. We have a splendid crop of all kinds of vegetables and our hay crop is twice as large as last year.

We have now 36 pupils in the school.

The Department is having the School painted and many necessary improvements are being looked forward to for the benefit of all concerned.

Dr. Westgate, Field Secretary for the Indian and Eskimo Commission, paid us a visit during the month of August and was well pleased with the condition of things in general.

Whitehorse.

The summer has passed and we are now down to our regular winter population. The tourists have gone but during their stay in our midst much work was done amongst them in the way of giving lantern lectures, services, and assistance in any other way possible in order to make their stay the more enjoyable. Much appreciation was voiced regarding our efforts to cater to the growing tourist traffic.

Armistice Day was fittingly remembered. First at the monument a short service of commemoration was held under the auspices of the Daughters of the Empire, the Rector of Christ Church leading in prayer and giving a short address. On Sunday evening, November 14th, the Old Log Church was crowded to capacity, when a special service was held in honour of those who gave their all for the sake of the Empire. The service was of an appropriate character, and the War Veterans attended in a body, and the remaining citizens turned out en masse for the occasion. The service closed with the sounding of the "Last Post" by Drum Major Smith, late of the 47th Battalion, C. E. F.

Carmacks.

Owing to the need at Dawson the work at Carmacks this summer has been of a much interrupted and unsatisfactory character. The best that could be done was done under the existing circumstances.

During the two visits of the Rev. J. H. Byrne, the first of a week's duration in June before his trip to Ross River, and the second of two weeks after his return in July. Most of the time was devoted to rendering the mission house habitable for the winter time, a work much needing to be done. Five services were held, three for the white population and two for the Indians. The former were especially well attended and enjoyable and we trust helpful.

Rev. Byrne was assisted during his second visit by Mr. G. C. Ashbee from Little Salmon.

It is hoped that next year with the return of Rev. J. H. Byrne the work will assume a more stable character.

News In Brief.

Rev. G. H. Moody was married during the summer to Miss Anderson. Miss Anderson has worked both in the Carcross School and in St. Paul's Hostel. Rev. Moody was in charge of the mission at Rampart House and Old Crow and for a time Rector of Dawson. They are now at Eagle.

Rev. F. H. Buck, who left Mayo for the outside, is now Principal of the Cranbrook High School.

C. F. Johnson and family have returned from their year's leave of absence. They were accompanied by Miss M. R. Austin and Miss M. Whittaker, who have taken positions in St. Paul's Hostel.

Caribou have been reported as numerous during the season so that all should have an abundant supply of food for the winter. Dawson reports a good run of salmon and a supply has been put in cold storage for the Hostel.

In The Yukon.

Up to the time of going to press we have really had some very fine weather. The snow fall so far has been light, so light in fact that we have not had enough for good sleighing and as a consequence the supplies of fuel have been somewhat limited. We have had one cold spell, the thermometer going well below the zero mark and registering 42 degrees below in Whitehorse. Curling and Winter sports are now getting under way, and if the weather man is not too severe we may hope for some very good sport during the long winter months. December 21st, will mark the passing of the shortest day and then we will see the days gradually lengthen out and a great part of the winter is broken, although as a general rule the worst is yet to come, as January, February and March are usually the coldest months. However Yukoners are a merry lot and will make the best of whatever may come their way. It is said that humour played an important part in the winning of the war and humour will play its part in passing away a winter however severe the laws of nature care to inflict upon us.

Dear Sir:

I beg to inform you that our Commission are recommending to our Executive Committee in Toronto that the Rev. W. Tinney be nominated to your Department for the position of Principal of our Carcross School. Mr. Tinney was for some time Acting Principal of the Mackay School, The Pas, Manitoba, where his services were perfectly satisfactory to our Commission. Since then he has had a three year's course in St. John's Divinity College in this City and has been Ordained by the Archbishop of Rupert's Land to the Diaconate in our Church. He will, in due course, be advanced to the Priesthood and hopes that he may be able to complete his Arts Course extra murally. Mr. Tinney is a married man with four young children and arrangements are being made for him to enter on his duties before the end of March. The Chooutla Indian School

I. HISTORY

The Indian Boarding School now known as the Chooutla Indian School, was first established at Carcross in the spring of 1906. For some years previous a small school had been conducted at Fortymile (below Dawson), under the personal supervision of the late Bishop Rossiter. The object at that time was to supply a home for orphans and neglected children, but the need for solid educational work was so pressing, that the advantages of the school were given to all that could possibly be crowded in.

The original Carcross School consisted of two 'shacks', one of which was of logs. This was not long, however, before the Government was brought to see the solid nature of the work being done for the Indian children of the Yukon, and persuaded that a better accommodation was a necessity. As result the present commodious building was erected by the Department of Indian Affairs, and, in the fall of 1911, placed at the disposal of the Church of England, to be used as a boarding and semi-industrial school for Indian children.

II. OBJECTS AND METHODS

The school has accommodation for thirty-five children. These are drawn from all parts of the Yukon, some from the immediate vicinity, some from the more northerly parts of the Territory, well within the Arctic Circle, and from many points between.

The Bishop (Right Rev. I. O. Stringer), in his travels through the Yukon, is continually seeking out suitable children. His aim is to get the best both in health and intellect, so that the graduates of the School may form in their several cases a foundation on which the missionaries can build, in their endeavours for the physical and spiritual benefit of the natives.

The Staff of the School had this object especially in view in drawing up its programme. One half of the day is spent in the classroom. There the children are given, whenever possible, an ordinary common school education. During the other half of the day they are taught the things most necessary to uplift them and their friends at home to something nearer the Christian standard of cleanliness and industry. The girls are housekeeping, sewing, etc., and the boys, gardening, rough carpenter and blacksmith work, and countless other things which will be useful in the kind of life that they will likely lead. Nor is it forgotten that mere cleverness without the Christian character will never save a man or woman.

The work is essentially missionary. Every member of the Staff is here because he or she is a missionary, and believes that the knowledge of Jesus of Nazareth and trust in Him, alone can save the decreasing Indians of the Yukon, and make them good and useful citizens of the greater Canada of the future.

III. MEANS OF SUPPORT

The connection of the School with the Department of Indian Affairs has created in many quarters a wrong impression. The idea seems to be spread that the School is supported by the Government, and is therefore in need of nothing. The Government supplies the buildings, some of the materials, pays the wages in repair, school books, the drugs, and gives a yearly per capita grant. The Church of England supplies the clothing, travelling expenses, and makes up the deficit, which is never less than $2,500 a year. No one, who has not lived in the North, has any idea of prices. A well known Yukon business man after hearing the annual report of the School, gave it as his opinion that he would not have believed it possible to run an institution of this kind so cheaply in any part of the Territory.

IV. NEEDS

There is one great limitation to all work of this kind and that is lack of ready funds. Again and again we have to consider how many necessary things we must do along without. There are branches of training that Indian children ought to have, but which cannot be included because we lack the means to procure the help and supplies. There are also special needs that, varying from time to time, cannot be definitely stated, but about which any one interested can receive information either from the Superintendent of the School, or from the Bishop, the Right Rev. I. O. Stringer D.D., Dawson, Y.T.

This work is worthy of support; first, because it is carried on in obedience to the command to "go into all the world and preach the Gospel to every creature," and secondly because it aims at turning into self-supporting and producing citizens, a race whose care is now a heavy expense to the Canadian Government.

Report on the Carcross Indian Residential School.

In June a visit was made to the above school. The school was on vacation owing to an epidemic of illness which has been prevalent since the beginning of the year, when all the pupils and staff were victims of Influenza which has been followed by an epidemic of septic pneumonia resulting in the death of two pupils. The serious cases were sent to Whitehorse Hospital for treatment. At the time of my visit I found the institution clear of the epidemics and all the pupils in good health.

The classroom being closed the usual examination was not held however I examined the written work of the pupils done the week previous to the closing of the classroom which showed marked progress during the past term. Two pupils, Alice Moses and William Chitze passed the entrance examination for High School, Alice gained 86% of the marks and William 56%. The questions set were the same as in the public School of Dawson.

The Staff appear to be unsettled, the Principal and the teacher have both tendered their resignations to the Indian and Eskimo School Commission, up to date neither of these resignations have been accepted. Miss Ostergarde R.N., recently arrived to fill the position of head matron and girl's supervisor has resigned and will be married in August to the Missionary at Carmacks. Miss Bertram, the kitchen matron is compelled to resign through a complete breakdown in health. The recently arrived Miss Doris Muir, boy's matron, has settled down to her duties and Mrs Thompson has been engaged as kitchen matron.

The cultivated land including the newly cleared portion was all planted and the crops showing up nicely, given a good season free of frosts the crops should be quite an increase over last years.

The stock is in fine condition, 5 head of cattle, 1 team of horses, 2 pigs and 30 chickens. A team of dogs is also kept for winter use.

Good stocks of warm serviceable clothing were on hand for the pupils and a further supply was received during my visit.
These Indian children are brought up chiefly on a meat diet in their native homes and do not thrive so well on a largely farinaceous diet. The meals supplied them at the school are good wholesome and plentiful but after consultation with Dr Wride a larger quantity of native meat was recommended to be given, it is felt that this would strengthen them and ensure more vitality and power of resistance when faced with illness.

Owing to recent discharges of pupils already reported the number of pupils is at a low ebb, it is confidently hoped that new recruits will be secured to fill vacancies.

Laundry equipment to supersede the hand machines now in use is needed. A washing machine and an extractor driven by a gas engine would be an ideal plant, will send an estimate of the cost of such an equipment to the Department later on.

Another need is a recreation room for the boys, they have to use the laundry as a play room in winter.

The Indian and Eskimo School Commission are asking for a chapel I do not consider such a building necessary for an institution of the size of the Carcross school.

The school has passed through a trying year, we hope when the new term begins all arrangements will be complete and a fresh start made.

Dawson, Y.T.,
July 9th, 1929

Dear Sir:

I have received your letter of October 1st, in which you refer to a communication received from Mr. Indian Superintendent Hawksley, relative to changes in the staff at the Carcross Indian Residential School, and in reply I beg to state that although certain changes have taken place in the personnel of the staff, the conditions are not, I think, quite so bad as they might appear when viewed from a distance, and in the light of the information you appear to have received from your representative.

In the first place, it is true that the Rev. W. Tinney resigned from the Principalship of this school at the end of September, but the appointment of the Rev. J. H. Byrne, which was made at short notice to fill the position of Acting-Principal, was intended to be a permanent appointment subject to the approval of your Department, and he has already signified his willingness to remain for one year at least. Mr. Byrne is a capable man and I trust it may be possible for our Commission to secure his services for an indefinite period.

Mrs. Byrne is a fully qualified teacher, and she will take the place of Mrs. Bentley who resigned. When Mrs. Bentley resigned, her husband, of course, severed his connection with the school also, but our Commission were fortunate in being able to secure the services of Mr. and Mrs. Thomson who entered on their duties immediately after the Bentleys withdrew, Mr. Thomson taking the position of Farm Instructor and Mrs. Thomson that of Kitchen Matron to succeed Miss Bertram.
The retirement of Miss Ostergaard, the Head Matron, upon her marriage to the Rev. C. C. Ashbee, left the Head Matronship vacant, but our Commission are appointing a Kitchen Matron so that Mrs. Thomson, who is a Graduate Nurse, may take over this position.

The frequent changes of staff agents at our Society's Indian Residential Schools are always deeply regretted by our Commission and they do their very utmost to prevent this. They regret the changes which have taken place at the Caroross School during the past year, but they believe that the work has not suffered to any appreciable extent in consequence, and I can assure you on behalf of our Commission that, despite the remote situation which this school occupies, the interests of your Department and of our Society are being very carefully safeguarded.

In a telegram just received this morning from Mr. Byrne, the Acting Principal, he points out the very urgent need of different items of equipment, etc., and our Commission have asked their bankers to place $100.00 immediately at his disposal to meet some of the more urgent of these. Amongst other things he asks to be supplied at once with a sturdy one-horse waggon, and it would be a great help to our Commission if your Department could authorize them to spend the sum of approximately $150.00 to provide this very necessary item of equipment. I sincerely trust that this help may be forthcoming in the immediate future, and will be obliged if you will kindly notify me by wire if this sum may be expended for the waggon mentioned.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary, M.S.O.S.

REPORT ON THE CARCROSS INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

The above school was visited last June. Arriving there on Saturday afternoon no work was undertaken until Monday morning when the examination in the class room. The work of both the senior and junior grades was very good and reflects much credit upon the teacher, Mrs J.H. Byrne. The daily register was neatly kept and quite up to date. The school material was not up to standard in the way it was kept, in fact it was in an untidy state.

The interior of the institution showed many signs of neglect, several doors were off their hinges, there were numerous broken windows and the walls of some of the rooms were very untidy, the pupils have been allowed to write their names on the blackboard and decorate it with other designs, unsightly stains of water streaked the walls in several places. A few of the rooms were kept neat but taking the institution as a whole it presented a general appearance of carelessness, a good deal of litter was lying around both inside and outside of the building. The pupils have been allowed to chalk upon the walls on the exterior of the building which does not add to its appearance.

The new porcelain bath and the 24 new taps that were, it was said, so urgently needed and were sent to the school last December, I found the bath standing in a room used as a bedroom and being used as a receptacle for soiled clothing, it has not been installed, six of the new taps had been attached the rest were stowed away.

The boys and girls no longer use the separate entrances provided but use both entrances promiscuously. Discipline is very lax, the pupils are very noisy, deportment is at a low ebb.

A great deal of time has been spent by the principal and his assistant and some of the elder boys in constructing a very crude flume and water wheel at the little waterfall at the back of the school, disfiguring the one beauty spot of the place and so far getting little benefit from it. The principal has an idea that the little creek at the back of the school can be made to do many things. Some years ago I took this matter up with a practical engineer. His opinion was that when the creek was at its highest level and discharging most water not more than 10 or 15 horsepower could be developed. In the winter this creek freezes solid and is utterly useless for any purpose. A dam was built across the creek by the Principal this was washed away by the first freshet. It appears to me that it is not worth while spending so much time and money on it.

Before leaving the school the principal asked me to write to the Indian and Eskimo Commission in reference to the food supplies sent in. I felt it was not within my province to do this but promised to bring the matter to the notice of the Department. I am now quoting his own words, "I requisitioned for 12 barrels of flour for the quarter June to September, I have received only 7 barrels. I asked for 150 lbs of rice and the same amount of white beans, I received only 50 lbs of each, there are no vegetables in the place. I am expected to make 1 lb of jam or 1 lb of lard spread 65 slices of bread; several other things were mentioned, however, are sufficient to show the difficulties he has to contend with. Among the white people and Indians there is a strong rumour that the pupils are insufficiently fed. Dr H.J. Munro of Whitehorse stated that he considers the pupils should have a more generous diet. From what I saw of the meals served to the pupils, they were sufficient in quantity but very monotonous.

Dawson, Y.T.

Sir;— I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your favor of June 28th. in reference to the rumours that have come to your knowledge regarding the elder girls of the Carcross Indian Residential School.

There is no doubt in my mind that there is no truth in the report that the girls get away from the school at night for the purpose of meeting the boys over in town. It is quite within the range of possibilities when they go over in the daytime. Owing to the school being understaffed the girls do go over to town without proper supervision.

Unquestionably the discipline here is very lax, I have brought this to the notice of the Principal. Naturally the Principal says there is no truth to all these rumours and I agree with him that things are not anything like so bad as represented but I do think that all the pupils are allowed too much liberty and that the general supervision is very far from what it should be.

You may, with confidence, send on the two pupils from Atlin as soon as convenient to you, the holidays make no difference to their reception.

Dear Sir:

I beg to advise the Department that I am informed by Mr. Harper Reed, Indian Agent, Stikine Agency, at Telegraph Creek that complaints have reached him from Indians of his Agency that conditions are not as might be expected at the Chootka Indian Residential School, Carcross, Yukon Territory. Letters received by Agent Reed are to the effect that the children at the school are not taken proper care of, are poorly clad, deprived of sufficient food, neglected as to their health and not properly supervised as to their moral conduct. It is further stated that the older female pupils are allowed their freedom in Carcross where they associate with white lads in the white community.

Agent Reed has referred to the visit to Stikine Agency, in August last, of Mr. Assistant Commissioner Perry to whom at that time similar complaints were made. Mr. Perry's official report of August 30th, 1930, pages 6 & 9, dealt with the matter and recommended that a special inspection of the Carcross school be made for reasons given therein.

The Department will be aware, of course, that Carcross, being in Yukon Territory, is not part of the jurisdiction of this office, but as one of our Agents complains with respect to British Columbia Indian children attending the Carcross School, it is thought that the matter might properly be brought again to the Department's attention, together with a suggestion that if the Department should consider an inspection advisable under the circumstances and there being no School Inspector, in all probability, in the Yukon, a visit may be made by the newly appointed School Inspector Barry, who is now attached to this office, sometime during the coming summer when he is in the northern part of the Province. This, of course, is simply a suggestion in case the Department may wish to have such an inspection and is not intended as desiring to in any way interfere with affairs now in the jurisdiction of another Commissioner - Mr. Hawkesly. It is quite possible that Mr. Hawkesly may have reported on the conditions at the School in which case representations made to Agent Reed by certain Indians might be considered in conjunction with such reports.

I may say that Mr. Barry, Inspector of Indian Schools for British Columbia, will likely be a busy man for some time with his regular work and might ill be spared for the trip to Carcross during the present - the first - year of his appointment, but if the Department feels that a visit by him to Carcross may have good results, no doubt this could be satisfactorily arranged.

Sir:

I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your letter dated February 19th, file No 166-1-1, in reference to the reported conditions at the Carcross Indian Residential School.

In reply I beg to say that reports and rumours carried by Indians are not always reliable. Some have really wonderful imaginations and can relate a very feasible story based on the very slimmest of facts. Forty-three years experience in dealing with these northern Indians has taught me this.

It is very true that under the late principal, the Rev J.H. Byrne, the school experienced a really serious decline in cleanliness, discipline, deportment of the pupils and care of the institution generally. These things were brought to the notice of the principal when I visited the school in June 1930. To my great surprise I found that the elder girls were allowed to spend the whole of Sunday at the Indian village, situated across the lake opposite the school. The parents or relatives of these girls do not live in Carcross. For the first time in the history of the school a young Indian from the village entered the girl's dormitory at night by means of the fire escape. Fortunately the offender was discovered, through the alertness of Miss Muir, Boys Matron, before any real harm had been done. No action was taken against the offender which, I think, was a great mistake. Mr Byrne did not report this during my visit to the school. At my request a stop was put to the elder girls visiting the Indian village nor were they to be allowed to visit the town of Carcross unless accompanied by some member of the staff. On my return visit to the school last September I found that matters in this particular point had very much improved. The Rev J.H. Byrne had left and Deaconess Topping was acting principal pending the appointment of a new man.

The Rev H.C.M. Grant arrived in November, since his arrival the conditions at the school have greatly improved.

Regarding the pupils being poorly clad, this certainly is not true. I inspected the clothing stores and found an ample supply of good, warm serviceable clothing suitable to our rigorous climate. There were also several bales of clothing that had not been opened. All the pupils were comfortably and suitably clothed and were neat and clean in appearance. Upon inquiry of the pupils as to whether they had enough clothing, their reply was "We have lots of it".
The question of food is not so satisfactory. It is not true to say that the pupils are deprived of sufficient food. During the past year I spent two weeks at the school, I visited the kitchen at meal times to see what was being served to the pupils. The quantity was sufficient to give each pupil ample for its need even though they had good appetites and generally there was some left over. If a pupil becomes hungry between meals they can always get something to eat by applying to the kitchen matron. It seems to me that the diet is not varied enough and the pupils tire of the sameness of the meals and that may be the reason why a pupil sometimes leaves the dining room without having complete satisfaction and possibly complains to others of not getting enough to eat. The staff can scarcely be blamed for this. The provision stores are kept down to what may be termed a dangerous limit. Several of the principals have complained about the requisitions that they have sent in to the Indian and Eskimo School Commission, Winnipeg, being cut down to the lowest possible limit. Surely a principal knows what provisions he needs to carry on with better than someone located so far away. This close cutting of supplies might prove serious if a blockade or breakdown occurred on the single line of railway that supplies the Yukon. I have known the line to be blocked for nearly one month at a time. An emergency supply of provisions should be kept on hand in case of accident. Instead of this the staff have to exercise the very strictest economy to make the supplies last out the quarter, even at that they sometimes run out of some items, especially if they happen to have some visitors. I make a practice of taking my provisions along when I visit the school. There is much room for improvement in the quantity and variety of the supplies sent by the Commission.

For a time the supervision of the pupils was not all that it should have been partly due to the school being understaffed and partly to the laxity of the late principal who certainly did not understand the nature and characteristics of the Indians. Under the present staff this defect has been materially remedied.

The health of the pupils is carefully watched. Dr Wride visits the school once a quarter and examines each pupil and is ready to go at any time when an emergency call is sent in. An ample supply of medicines is always kept on hand. A registered nurse takes care of the general health of all the pupils. The school is well ventilated and the staff see to it that there is plenty of fresh air.

Neither Indians or Whites are allowed to loaf around the school premises or grounds.

I had the pleasure of meeting Mr Harper Reed at the school last June, he had the opportunity of going over the school though it was not an opportune time for his visit, the workmen were busy.
In the improvements that were made last summer consequently the place was much upset. Mr. Reed made no complaints to me at the time but later wrote much on the same lines as your letter. I gave him an explanation of the whole case and assured him that he need have no hesitation in sending any prospective pupils he had for the school.

The Bishop of Yukon has recently visited Dawson, on his way here he visited the Carcross school, staying five days. He stated that it gave him much pleasure to see the marked improvement that had taken place under the new staff. The Bishop saw the school in April of last year when things were at their worst.

Referring to your request that I visit the school for the purpose of making a thorough inspection I wish to say that, in view of the improvement that has taken place, and taking into consideration the high cost of making a trip from Dawson to Carcross at this time of the year, the round trip would cost at least $350.00, and after consultation with the Gold Commissioner it was considered advisable to postpone the trip until the opening of navigation when the round trip will cost one third of the present rate. It is hoped that this will meet with the approval of the Department. It would be quite the middle of April before I could reach the school if I left here by the next stage. A thorough inspection will be made when I visit the school on the opening of navigation.

Your obedient servant,

John Hawksley,
Indian Superintendent.

A.F. Mackenzie, Esq.,

Sir:

I have your letter of the 25th ultimo, regarding conditions at the Carcross Indian Residential School.

In this connection I have to say that the Department is pleased to note that there has been a very decided improvement since the Rev. H. C. M. Grant took up duties as Principal. It is also noted that the pupils have an ample supply of good warm, serviceable clothing, also that there has been an improvement in the food supplied for their use. It is further noted that more strict supervision is kept over the pupils and that the older girls are not allowed to visit the Indian village on Sundays. You should inform the Principal that he is not to permit the pupils to be absent from the school overnight, unless for urgent reasons, and the girls should not be allowed to visit the town of Carcross if they are not accompanied by a member of the staff.

In view of the cost of making a special trip to the school, I have to say that it will be satisfactory for you to make a thorough inspection into the general conditions at the time of your next visit to the school, and you might again communicate with the Department.

The Department is communicating with Mr. Indian Agent Reed, Stickine Agency, informing him of the improvement in conditions at this school under the management of the new Principal and staff.

"Straightway"

"What madness this?" cried the fisher folk
By the Lake of Galilee,
When sudden and clear in their ears it broke,
A young man's "Follow Me!"
Straightway and swift as a homing bird
Flies up to the waiting nest,
They answered the call whose hearts were stirred
By a vision of Love's own best.

They left the nets they would need no more
In the old familiar toil,
They turned away from the friendly shore,
As men enriched by spoil.
For grave and sweet was their Leader's face,
And His eyes were full of cheer;
They would march at His bidding with resolute pace,
And challenge the menace of fear.

You who are young in the world today,
Have you heard that ringing call?
Are you ready to heed? Will you walk the way
That is bravest and best of all?
It is sounding down from the heights above:
It is Christ's word, "Follow Me!"
Ah, straightway answer the mighty Love,
His servants and soldiers be.

Margaret E. Sangster.

PEACE

One of the major problems facing the nations of the whole world today is international peace. Mankind has since 1919, made a half-hearted attempt to secure such a peace. Peace might be said to be the lack of war, but in reality it is something far greater than that. Peace is a complete harmony between every man. It calls for the knocking down of national, geographical and racial barriers. If man would gain such a peace as he demands or desires, he must build contrary to the manner in which he has built. His peace must be built upon the revelation of God revealed in the humanity of Christ.

J. B. Phillips says of peace: “People only see peace as an attractive state of things actually during a war. When they have peace, they do not value it.” In the light of the past decade this statement is exceedingly true to us. In the world struggle of 1914-18, the predominating desire of the world was peace. When that peace was obtained men promptly forgot about the economic distress, the loss of life and the maimed and incapacitated people left in the wake of the gigantic European struggle and set about creating an atmosphere of discontent and jealousy which has resulted in half a dozen minor wars in various parts of the world. These wars affected more or less isolated groups. They had no power of dragging the world powers into another general conflict.

After the Great War, we saw the birth of the League of Nations, which was a gigantic organization composed of the major nations of the world for the avowed purpose of establishing international peace and the prevention of war. In 1931-32 arose a condition calling for the League to exercise its authority. I refer to the Japanese invasion of Manchuria. Here was a nation making an apparent unprovoked attack upon another. Here was a nation throwing to the four winds of heaven the principles for which a large part of the world was working. The reply of the League of Nations to this challenge was a formal and solemn pronouncement of censure upon the aggressor. That is what we had labour for!

Now we are faced with a problem which is much the same except that the two nations involved, Italy the aggressor, and Ethiopia the invaded, are both members of the League of Nations, and both Christian. Both parties have covenanted to keep peace and to accept the findings of the League and if possible, to settle their dispute by means that will not cause the world at large to topple over—the way it did after war. But when nations within the organization fly at one another’s throats; when the terms of the covenants made are violated; when other nations withdraw or refuse to enter the organization so that they will not have to pass their opinion in regard to any infringement of the codes, how are we ever going to achieve the fondest of our dreams: World Peace?

The burden of the present crisis is falling upon three or four great nations. Many of our people are dissatisfied with the League of Nations and its work and openly make the charge that the League has failed in its purpose and its work. Recently Great Britain has been very severely criticized by different parties and by the press over her attitude to Italy’s invasion of Ethiopia. In the London Daily Mail appeared this extract:
