THE LEAGUE OF MISCHIEF

If Signore Mussolini, as the result of the present crisis, succeeds in ridding the world of the meddling, muddling, peril-to-peace League of Nations, he will have performed a great international service. He will also have relieved this country of a most dangerous entanglement, seeing that British Governments today have to spend a large part of their time in what they call "upholding the prestige of the League" and trying to keep it alive instead of attending to British interests.

In the Detroit News appeared the following:

UP TO BRITAIN?

The outstanding fact is that Great Britain can stop the war (in Ethiopia) if she has nerve enough to face the consequences, which necessarily would be troublesome.

As Archbishop Temple said recently in a broadcast in England: "First let us be quite clear that the will of God for mankind is peace and goodwill. War cannot break out except through some departure from His will." Archbishop Temple attributes this present failure of the world to gain peace to two sources, namely that we have not yet learned to apply our faith to this problem and that our worship of Jesus Christ is incomplete.

If we as professing Christians, individually and collectively as nations, could only see that war is a scandal to those who profess the faith of Christ, and if only we could see that Christian fighting Christian is nothing but a mockery of the Christian principles, there would be less talk of and fewer attempts at war, and greater strides made for world peace. If only we would stop playing the hypocrites if the members of the League of Nations would put away hypocrisy and acknowledge in word and deed that war is incompatible with Christian civilization, then we would see the dawn of world peace. I grant that it would require something that many individuals and groups of statesmen of the world are not ready to give, namely, themselves wholly over to Christ and to acknowledge that He has complete authority over all parts of life.

The only way the world will ever find peace is to find it the way that He proclaims. To find it by the way of love, and that can only be done by living the way The Christ called His disciples to live. That is the way of peace.

Let us then strive honestly, without hypocrisy as individuals and as nations, to do what St. Paul advised us to do: "Let us therefore follow after the things which make for peace and things wherewith one may edify another."

We profess to be Christians, to be civilized, to be progressive, to have raised our standard higher than it has been held by any previous civilization.

In the name of God therefore let us get down to facts; let us throw ourselves back upon his promises and His way and bring to pass the thing that we most desire in this present day—International Peace.

NOTES FROM THE MISSIONS

CARCROSS, Choontin School.—In July a wedding of great interest took place in St. Saviour's Church, Miss Dorothy Griffiths of Welland, Ontario, and Mr. H. S. White were united in Holy Matrimony. The Bishop of the Diocese performed the ceremony, the Principal was the best man, Corporal Kingston, R.C.M.P., gave the bride away and Miss M. D. Hoehn of Oak Lake, Manitoba, was the bridesmaid. The Church was suitably decorated with lovely flowers sent from Ben-My-Chree for the occasion. Miss Vincent sang a solo during the signing of the register. The bride wore a lovely ivory satin gown and carried a bouquet of delphiniums grown at the school, the first of the season. After the ceremony a reception was held at the home of the Principal, where friends of the happy pair gathered to wish them every blessing. The table was tastefully decorated with flowers, the centre-piece being a lovely three-tiered wedding cake. After the reception the bride and groom left for a short honeymoon in the district. Mrs. White is now the new staff of the school as Boys' Supervisor, a position left vacant when Miss Seale went on furlough.

During the holidays the younger boys spent an enjoyable time under canvas at Ten Mile while the elder boys were busy with the hay.

The Staff of the school have recently made a voluntary donation towards the Restoration Fund of $211.00. This is in addition to the amount subscribed by them during the past three years.

Three of our pupils returned to their home this year. These we commend to your prayers. One of them has been placed in charge of the Indian Day School at Old Crow and is reported to be doing very well.

We had quite a number of visitors during the summer months, among them being Rev. and Mrs. Jenkins and Mr. and Mrs. French of Whitehorse; Mrs. Johnson; Miss Vincent of Winnipeg; and Mrs. Wheatley of Manitoba.

We are glad to say that we have been able to start a Senior Branch of the W. A. among the Indian women of Carcross. They have their own officers and are running it on true W. A. lines with a little help from the school. Donations of deer skins, beads and wool were received in order that they might begin clear of debt. These gifts we thankfully acknowledge.

Bishop and Mrs. Geddes paid us a flying visit on their way out.

We have extended our farming a little, having added a couple of pigs to our stock. These are well housed in a pig pen erected by the Farm Instructor and the older boys.

Miss M. I. Dunn joined our Staff as teacher in August. She comes to us with ten years' experience of Indian School work. May her stay with us be long and happy.

CARCROSS, St. Saviours.—The Rev. H. C. M. Grant, Principal of the Indian Residential School, has conducted services in St. Saviour's Church, Carcross, during the absence of Mr. Vincent, who has been stationed at Teslin for the summer months. At this post the natives, about 120 in number, are all away at their hunting and trapping grounds throughout the winter.
WHITEHORSE, Christ Church.—Owing to shortage of space in the last issue of this paper we were unable to enter any notes concerning the parish of Christ Church.

During the Tourist Season, the Rector, Rev. C. H. Jenkins, gave twenty-six illustrated lectures on the Yukon and the work of our Church in this territory. Attendances at the lectures were very gratifying and were very much appreciated by those who attended them. It is hoped that next year we may have more new views to add to the collection we already have.

In the month of June the Annual Diocesan meeting of the W. A. was held in Whitehorse.

We are sorry to report that we have had a number of deaths recently in our little community. A few weeks ago Mrs. Thomas, an elderly woman, died here and died several days later in the hospital. Then one of the old timers of the town of Whitehorse, Mr. E. J. Hummacher, a well-known Northern photographer, passed away.

A few days after Mrs. Thomas, our oldest Indian, died at the age of 85.

On Sunday evening, November 16th, the annual Remembrance Service was held in Christ Church, the Rev. C. H. Jenkins conducting the service. We are very grateful to some of our members for their aid given that night to make the service successful. This service is the most popular of the year and was very well attended, there being 90 persons present.

All our branches of the W. A. are working steadily forward. Mrs. Jenkins at present is preparing her group of girls to present a concert at the latter part of this month or else in the first week of December.

Christ Church has lost two able workers in the persons of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Coulter, who left early in October to take up residence in Victoria, B. C.

We are glad to report that Mrs. W. S. Watson is improving rapidly after her operation. Mrs. Watson is at present in Vancouver, B. C.

DAWSON, St. Paul's.—The Rev. A. C. McCullum and Mrs. McCullum with their two little sons arrived in Dawson on August 2nd, which parish Mr. McCullum has recently been appointed to.

The Junior Branch of the W. A. had a very successful day on the 17th of August.

On August 4th, Rt. Rev. W. A. Goddes, D.D., Bishop of Yukon, ordained to the Priesthood in St. Paul's Church, Rev. Leslie G. Chappell.

Harvest Thanksgiving Services were held on Sunday, September 4th. The Church was beautifully decorated on this occasion by the Chancel Guild under the supervision of Miss Rhoda Swift. Special music was given, and all services well attended.

The programme for parish activities has now been completed and the various organizations hope to soon have their work under way. We trust that with earnest effort and cooperation on the part of all, the work of this parish will be greatly blessed and much good result.

Rev. L. G. Chappell kindly consented to take charge of the choir work for this coming season.

Rt. Rev. W. A. Goddes and Mrs. Goddes, with their little son David, left for the south on August 14th. We are indeed sorry to see them leave but trust that the Bishop's health will be greatly improved when they return to us in the spring.

FORT SELKIRK.—We were very happy to welcome Mrs. Ferrabee when she visited Fort Selkirk. Many of the members of the W. A. returned to the post to meet her, and a very pleasant meeting of the Branch was held at the home of the President, Mrs. Coward. Mrs. Ferrabee's visit was a great inspiration to us, and has made us feel that we have the Right Hand of Fellowship of the great Dominion-wide organization.

The Bishop, who was at Selkirk at the same time as Mrs. Ferrabee, administered the Rite of Confirmation on Monday, July 15th. Three candidates were presented and immediately after Confirmation they received their first Communions.

Your prayers are asked for these three persons, that they may prove themselves Christians.

The Church Bell has now been removed to the Belfry in the Church. Hitherto it was outside the Mission House on a scaffolding. Messrs. Lar- kins, Larson and Lehland, trappers from the Macmillan River, very kindly undertook this work, and we are very grateful to them.

These three men also repaired the sidewalk of the Mission House.

Carmacks Mission was opened during the months of July and August. The response to our efforts here was most encouraging and it was with regret that we had to leave.

The Selkirk W. A. report a very successful year and at present are making plans for the forthcoming Winter. Sunday, October 6th, was observed as W. A. Sunday. The Selkirk Branch celebrated the Jubilee of the Organization. The members had a Corporate Communion at 8 a.m. and at Matins a special address on the W.A. was given. The attendance showed that there is no lack of enthusiasm for the W. A. among all the people here.

The Church at Fort Selkirk now has a very beautiful Font, a Memorial to Mrs. Bompas, the wife of the first Bishop of Yukon. This is a gift from the Diocesan W. A. and our thanks go to that generous Society.

We also thank the Yukon Diocesan W. A. for the gift of a Service Book for use in the Church at Selkirk and the Moosehide Mission for the Lectern which they sent us.

The Ministers recently made a journey down the river North of Selkirk to visit the people along the way before the freeze-up. These lonely woodcutters and trappers and the small band of Indians need your prayers.

Will you pray for them?

DAWSON, St. Paul's Hostel.—Very favourable reports on the school work of the children were sent us by the teachers at the close of the summer vacations. Two-thirds of the boys being first in Grade VII, while two girls took second and third places in Grade VIII. In the Junior W. A. competitions also the girls were a great credit to their branch, two of them taking first prizes, one for knitting and one for sewing, and another girl received the special prize for the study book. In addition two of the three prizes awarded to the Rev. D. E. for the best work in history at school were won by Hostel children.

At the close of the school year in June a few of the children returned to their homes for the summer months, and those who remained spent a week each in the Church Camp at Rock Creek, the boys being in charge of the Rev. A. Anderson, and the girls under
the care of Miss Swift. During the remainder of their holiday, the boys assisted in the cultivation of the garden and spent much of their leisure time swimming in the many ponds among the 'tailing piles'.

While on a tour of the Yukon, we had as our guest, Mrs. Ferrabee, Dominion President of the W. A. The staff and children quickly learned to love her for her charming personality, and for the keen interest she displayed in the work of the Hostel.

On August 6th, Mrs. Johnson with Margaret and Charlie, left Dawson on their way to Toronto, where they are making their home. The children gave Mrs. Johnson a 'nugget' serviette ring as a token of love for their retiring Matron, and all were present at the dock to wave them farewell and wish them every happiness in their new home.

On Discovery Day (August 17th) the children were given an opportunity to take part in the procession through the streets. Dressed in old-fashioned attire and complete with their bundles and 'babies', they became the passengers on an old-time overland stage to their own delight and the amusement of the spectators. Later, several of them won prizes in the children's races, and all enjoyed the afternoon entertainment provided by the Pioneers.

Though a few children left us during the summer, our numbers remain unaltered with the coming of new arrivals. All of them are well and back at school, where we hope they will continue to be a credit to themselves and to the Hostel.

CHOUTLA INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL: The school which is attended by Indian children from all parts of the Territory is situated a few miles from Carcross. The Rev. Mr. Grant is the principal and there are 48 pupils in residence at present. I inspected this school four times during the year and found evidence that the school is being conducted according to the requirements of the Department.

Fire drills are held at irregular intervals and the pupils thoroughly instructed as to their actions in the event of fire. The new fire escape stairs are a decided improvement over the old iron ladder fixed to the side of the wall. The buildings were all found in good condition and I would draw your attention to my report of July 2nd, 1937, in regard to requirements at this school. The school is too small for the amount of pupils, and the question of alterations or extension should be given attention as soon as possible and in this regard I would draw your attention to paragraph 4 of my report of July 2nd.

The repairs to the workshop mentioned in paragraph 1 of that report has now been completed and found very helpful, especially in regard to the cellar which was properly fixed for storage of winter vegetables.

In regard to the conduct of the school, I found the food supplied at the school to be good and wholesome and the meals varied so that the children do not get the same food too often. An ample supply of fresh vegetables are grown at the school every year. All the children were found to be well and warmly clothed and the pupils receive good training in manual work, the girls being taught cooking, laundry work, knitting and sewing, while the boys are taught farming, care of stock, carpentry and shoe repairing. The training in school is good, a good
average of marks being obtained by the pupils in the various subjects. The health of the children during the year has been good, no epidemics. A resident nurse looks after the health of the children, medicine being supplied by the Department and if hospitalization is required the patient is sent to the Whitehorse General Hospital. The principal and staff are to be congratulated on their work in this school, everyone appears to have the welfare of the children at heart and are trying to instill the idea of good citizenship into the minds of the children.

(Sgd.) G. Binning,
A/Supt.,
Department of Indian Affairs.
The Chooutla Indian Residential School was first established at Carcross in the spring of 1903. It then consisted of two shacks, one of which was constructed of logs.

For several years previous a small school was conducted at Fortymile, under Bishop Bompas, who made it a matter of personal concern. Mrs. Bompas also took a deep interest in the work.

For several years it was carried on as a home for orphaned and neglected children. After Bishop Bompas had visited Caribou Crossing (now called Carcross) and had resided here for some time, in 1901 and 1902, he realized that this place had many advantages as a location for the school and in the spring of 1903 he removed the institution from Fortymile to Carcross. Miss Ellis, who was in charge of the school at the time, accompanied the children up the river, there being eight or ten children in the school.

A small house in Carcross was procured from P. H. Poole and here the school was comfortably established. In 1908 the staff was composed of Bishop Bompas, as teacher, and Miss Ellis, matron. Bishop and Mrs. Bompas lived in a log building, on the opposite side of the water, formerly erected as a roadhouse.

In order that the school children might be closer to the mission, the bishop in 1904 exchanged the school building for a log house occupied by the detachment, and originally used as a telegraph office. This was the first of the school until recently erected communal buildings located two miles from the school.

Dear Sir:-

Some time before the fire which destroyed the school and workshop on April 17th 1939 there was quite an epidemic of stealing in the school. The articles stolen by the pupils consisted of tools, food and the personal belongings of the staff. When these cases of theft were first reported to me the culprits were strapped on the hands and all the scholars were told that if stealing did not cease more severe measures would be taken. The scholars were told that if there were any more cases of theft the guilty one, whether a boy or girl, would be laid across the classroom desk in the presence of the whole school, clad only in their night attire, and strapped on a different part of their anatomy than their hands. Stealing still went on. Those, about whose guilt we had no doubt were dealt with in this manner. So severe was this strapping that the child had to be held down by the Head Matron and Farm Instructor. I naturally thought at the time that this form of punishment would bring about the result desired. It didn't. Stealing still went on. Realizing that corporal punishment had little or no effect the staff member suggested a course of action that had been followed in another school. In this case, though, it was used to prevent girls from running away from school and it consisted in cutting off all the hair off the head of the offender. It was suggested to me that possibly this form of punishment would bring results. Accordingly all children were warned what would happen if anything else was stolen. It was only a matter of a few days before this form of punishment had to be used. It checked stealing at once.

We did not have much to contend with stealing until after the fire. I might mention that at the time of the fire a considerable number of articles that were taken out of the burning buildings were carried off by the onlookers. The Head Matron saw one Indian woman, the mother of one of the school girls, going home after the fire with a staff bath towel. Articles that the men on the staff were sure had been taken out of the burning buildings could not be found and the only conclusion that could be arrived at was that they were stolen by the Indians.
One article of value that was stolen whilst the fire was in progress was a diamond ring the property of the Head Matron. She stated that its value was approximately $100.00. A week or so after the fire it was found in the possession of one of the Indian school girls.

Since then there has been one case of theft after another and the staff and Principal have been at their wits end to know the best way to deal with the problem. We tried to avoid hair-cutting as we were aware that this form of punishment was resented by the parents of the children. I would like to bring the following cases to your attention:

1. Last summer two of the school boys were out herding cattle. Corporal Pearson of the R.C.M.P. received a complaint about the theft of two tins of tobacco out of a house occupied by a carpenter working for the Northern Airways Limited. It was found out that these two boys were the thieves. The officer of the R.C.M.P. talked to the boys about their conduct and advised them strongly to behave themselves in future. The action I took was to make these two Indian boys pay for, out of a small salary they were earning, two tins of tobacco and give same to the person they had robbed.

2. A school girl stealing boy's clothing out of the boy's residence. She was strapped on the hands for this offence.

3. Mr. Matthew Watson, General Merchant of Carcross informed me that school boys were bringing in notes bearing the forged signatures of some Indian residing in Carcross or vicinity. These notes called for groceries, candies, etc. On investigating the matter it was found that 4 school boys had been engaged in this practice. They were given corporal punishment.

4. A short time after this incident Mrs. Takamatsu (Indian) came to my office and reported that some boys had taken a One Dollar bill out of a drawer in her house. I paid her the amount that was stolen and punished the two school boys concerned by depriving them the privilege of having a permit for two months. When they would otherwise be playing they were given work to do.

5. A white resident of Carcross, whose house is quite near the Boy's Residence, reported to me that during his absence one night some person had entered his house and stolen cigarettes and a bottle of vanilla extract. Even though he did not say that he suspected school boys I had an investigation. The only result obtained was that one Indian boy accused another of this theft.
6. On the first night our present Farm Instructor was at the school he informed me that a package of cigarettes was stolen out of his room. The boy who took these was found out and the cigarettes recovered.

7. Before the present Farm Instructor arrived his predecessor reported that a bottle of beer was stolen out of his room. The boy who took same was let off with a warning. It was his first offence.

8. About three months after the theft of a bottle of beer, Mr. Matthew Watson, General Merchant of Carcross let me know that one of the school boys (the same who took the bottle of beer) brought a mink skin in to be sold. After questioning the boy as to where he got the skin Mr. Watson told him to call in the next day. In the meantime another Indian came to the store and stated that someone had stolen a mink skin out of the house in which he was living. On hearing these facts I questioned the boy and he admitted the theft. He realized that this time he could not be let off with only a warning.

9. Another boy about this time broke into our Store House and stole a can of pears. His guilt was established, the pears recovered, and as a punishment he was given a very close haircut. After this theft all the children in school were told that the next child or children, be they boy or girl, who was caught stealing they would be given a very close hair-cut.

10. Quite recently the Head Matron advised me that the Kitchen Matron was having difficulty in making the bread she baked last as long as she thought it should last. Our reserve supply of bread is stored in a locked building just behind the building used as a Kitchen and Dining Room. The Kitchen Matron was advised to count the loaves of bread one evening and check same in the morning. Seven loaves of bread were missing. We have not been able to find out who was the thief.

11. On February 1st 1940 the Head Matron phoned me up to say that two school girls (Lilly Johnson and Rowena Baum) had been caught red-handed by the Kitchen Matron stealing bread. The amount they were in the act of stealing was approximately one loaf. Both these girls had the hair on their head cut off.

12. Today, February 5th 1940, the Kitchen Matron advised me that some of her clothing had been stolen and there seems to be no question but that the theft was committed by one or more of the school girls.
From the aforementioned cases you will see that not only have various articles been stolen but that different methods of punishment have been used. Insisting that the supervision of the children be of a more exacting nature did not bring the results desired. Reprimanding a child accomplished nothing. Corporal punishment was also useless. The only thing that has brought results was cutting of their hair.

As quite a bit of resentment has arisen amongst the Indians regarding this form of punishment it would be appreciated if you would advise whether such a procedure meets with your approval. I would be glad to receive any suggestions that you might care to make on how to handle this most difficult situation. Some of the Indians claim that if the children were given enough to eat they would not steal. I make a point of going into their Dining Room nearly every day and have noted that they are given an ample supply of good and wholesome food. The absurdity of this claim of the Indians is shown by the fact that food is by no means the only articles stolen.

Yours truly,

H.C.M. Grant,
Principal.
Dawson, Y.T.

Dear Clarence:

Referring to your letter of October 17th perhaps the following information will be of use to you. No doubt it is all available from your own files but you may not have it in summarized form.

I have not had an opportunity of inspecting the residential school at Carcross, nor do I know much of the results which are being achieved by it. My general observation of the work of such institutions in the north, however, is that they do little to equip the Indian for the type of life which he must of necessity live in this country. Rather they make the Indians dissatisfied with the way of life to which he must almost inevitably return. However I realize that this is a controversial question and the schools appear to be conducted in accordance with departmental policy.

The Hostel which is maintained by the Anglican Church at Dawson is for half-breed children. I do not think there are any full blood Indian inmates. The children in residence attend the local schools. I note that it has been suggested that the school at Carcross might be closed and a consolidation effected with the Hostel at Dawson, making use of the old residence of the Commissioner, for accommodation.

Bishop Geddes has not been in the Territory since my arrival so I have had no opportunity of discussing this suggestion with him. However it appears to me that the idea is open to many objections, perhaps the chief being that the cost of maintenance of an institution at Dawson would be much higher than at Carcross because of higher freight rates on supplies, the increase in cost of fuel etc. There is not sufficient adjoining ground available to grow potatoes or other root crops to assist in maintenance or to train the native children in agricultural pursuits. Moreover the building itself is most unsuitable and the remodelling, which would be necessary before it could be so used, would be very expensive.

It may be that a lengthier experience will result in qualification of some of the views herein expressed, but in the meantime you have my present reactions to your letter. You will appreciate that I have written quite frankly in this connection and also as regards the more personal matters which are the subject of separate correspondence.

J. E. Gibben,

Sir:

Your letter of July 8th not having been sent
Air Mail has only recently come to hand.

Although I see Bishop Geddes frequently he has not
mentioned to me as Indian Agent the desire of the Church
for the transfer of the residential school from Carcross to
Dawson. However, before receipt of your letter I had learned
that efforts were being made to secure the former Court house
for school purposes. I may say that the contemplated move has
been the subject of discussion in many quarters and I have
heard much criticism.

I have not seen the Carcross school site but understand
that it is situate some two miles from town, that there is
good water available and that there is adequate acreage for cul-
tivation close at hand. The present location is close to the
railroad and at the same time is in a district where there is
ample fish and game available. Furthermore I am told that fuel
is obtainable at far lower cost than in the Dawson area.
Carcross is situate in the Southern part of the Yukon Territory
where the greater proportion of the Indian population is to be
found.

Dawson is some three hundred and fifty miles from
Carcross as the crow flies and much further than that in terms
of freight haul. Obviously the cost of supplies is much higher
in this area. I question whether the climate is any more severe
here but fuel costs are much higher and are on the increase as
dealers have to go farther afield for wood.

There is no acreage available for cultivation (where root
crops etc. could be raised) in the near vicinity to either of the
Government owned buildings mentioned.

These buildings are located right in the City of Dawson
in close proximity to a resident white population and within
easy access to the business district and the waterfront. From my
observations in the N.W.T. and in Dawson itself I am of opinion
that the Indians are much better off when kept away from close contact with the white population. Indeed as Indian agent I am at present concerned over the situation which exists here by reason of the presence in town of many of the natives from the Moosehide settlement.

As regards the buildings themselves I understand that these are all under the control of the Federal Department of Public Works. The building which Canon Dixon speaks of as Government House is the former official residence of the Commissioner of the Yukon Territory and has not been occupied as such since 1916. Mr. G.A. Jeckell, the Controller of the Yukon Territory, advises me that plans of this building and full particulars with regard thereto are available in the Department of Public Works at Ottawa. Mr. Jeckell, Bishop Geddes, and the writer inspected this building in February last and certainly the conclusion which the Controller and I came to was that the cost of remodelling it for school purposes would be very high.

Formerly all maintenance charges for Government House passed through Mr. Jeckell's hands. He has looked up his records and now advises me that in 1914 and 1915 the last two years in which the house was occupied for the full twelve months the fuel costs were respectively $3,938.34 and $3,332.71. The price of fuel in Dawson has increased from thirty-five to fifty per cent since the period of these figures.

Your letter perhaps did not call for this reply, but the local opposition to the proposed project which I have noted, has prompted me to set these matters before you.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

For some time past I have been considering the step which I now am taking with reference to the Chooutla Indian Residential School at Carcross, Yukon.

I have felt that the present facilities for sanitation and hygiene were inadequate, but at the same time I have realized the valuable work the school was doing and hence I did not wish to see it discontinued. Certain developments have made it clear to me that some action should be taken. These are:

1: The increased incidence of communicable disease due to the large influx of population.

2: The occurrence of an epidemic of measles at the school and in which every child was affected with but one exception. There has been one fatality due to the epidemic.

3: The lack of skilled nursing personnel and the increasing difficulty of keeping a nurse at the school under the present living conditions.

Under the present arrangements the school does not remotely satisfy the usually accepted standards of sanitation. The dormitories are overcrowded, the water supply is unprotected, and the lavatories and toilets are wholly inadequate. For example the boys' dormitory has 22 boys sleeping in a room 16 x 22 x 10 feet; this in addition to a large drum heater. The girls dormitory is not so congested but does not give an adequate amount of cubic-footage of air space per person.

This state of congestion can and will only lead to an increase in the incidence of communicable disease and I believe that it is not in the best interests of the children to live under such conditions.
I have therefore decided to condemn the buildings of the residential school as unsuitable for their purpose. A copy of my declaration is enclosed. I am certain that this is in the best interests of the children and at the same time it may stir the Church or the Departmental authorities into doing something to improve the conditions in this school.

Yours very truly,

"F. Burns Roth, M.D."

Dear Sir:

I wired to you from St. John, N.B., with reference to the critical situation which had arisen in the school at Carcross. I have since received a copy of Mr. Hoey's letter of October 21st to Dr. Westgate informing him that it had been decided to reduce the pupilage in the school from 40 to 20.

The per capita rate for the Carcross school is $250.00. With the discharge of 20 pupils this means a corresponding annual loss in income of $5000.00. While there will be some savings on items like food and clothing, the major items of expense, namely staff and overhead, will remain unchanged. Memorandum:

DOCTOR MCILL

Re: Operation of Carcross Residential School

I am sending forward herewith copy of a letter received by this Branch from the Reverend Canon L. A. Dixon, General Secretary of the Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada.

When the Carcross Residential School was destroyed by fire on April 17, 1935, an assurance was given to the Anglican Church authorities that the school would be rebuilt just as soon as the funds necessary for this purpose could be secured, and that in the interval funds would be provided to rent two or three houses that appeared available at that time for the conduct of classes and for dormitory accommodation. These houses have recently been condemned as insanitary by the Medical Health officer of the district, who issued an order that the building be closed. Later, however, the building was re-opened with an enrolment of 20 rather than 40 pupils.

I am not at all sure that we are justified in spending at this particular time, or indeed at any time, the sum of $10,000 on the education of 20 pupils. This per capita grant does not include money paid for a night watchman or for incidental expenses such as repairs, the purchase of textbooks, etc. I am disposed to think, without knowing much about local conditions, that this money might be more profitably spent in the establishment of one or two day schools at certain centres and in the employment of a nurse, qualified to give instruction in dietetics, etc.

Mr. Phelan and I have spent the last week in carefully reviewing the requests received for the repair and general upkeep of our residential school buildings. The appropriation available in the 1942-44 estimates is sufficient to meet no more than 50% of the amounts requested. In addition to these requests, however, there are requests for new buildings, particularly from the Anglican Church, and requests from all the churches for the new buildings necessary for the promotion of vocational instruction. Therefore, unless the Government is in a position to provide the funds necessary to meet these requests, I am of the opinion that it would be sheer folly to build additional residential schools anywhere in the Dominion. The policy of the Government in respect to the construction of Indian day and residential schools has never been clearly defined at any time since I entered the Department. In this connection I should like to
refer to my memorandum to you on the operation of residential schools, dated May 31, 1940. In view of the fact that representatives of the churches have made arrangements to meet the Minister toward the end of December, with the object of discussing with him the desirability of a substantial increase in the present per capita grant allowances, it has occurred to me that the policy of the Government in respect to the building of residential schools and the operation of these schools might very well be reviewed prior to the Minister's interview with the representatives of the churches.

In respect to the request submitted by Canon Dixon, my recommendation is that a special grant be made to the Carcross school to enable this school to operate without loss during the present academic year and that this grant be made on the understanding that the school will cease to operate on the 30th of June next. I recommend, also, that the Church be told definitely that it is not our intention to rebuild the residential school in the Yukon Territory at any time during the years immediately ahead of us.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare and Training.

Dear Dr. McGill;

I thank you for your letter of October the fifteenth dealing with the subject of Indian Education in the Yukon, with particular reference to the Carcross Residential School and the question of Indian Day Schools in the Yukon.

I note that you hope to obtain from the American Army some of the buildings now being built by them in the southern Yukon, the lumber from which could be used in the erection of a new School after the war. From what I have seen, even if we only secured a small fraction of these buildings we should have ample for our need. I should like to suggest that with the buildings you should also endeavour to secure one of the many portable sawmills that they have as well as one of the smaller Diesel Caterpillar tractors of which there are hundreds in Yukon. There will be some material required for the larger building that will not be found in the smaller ones but with the additional equipment I have suggested we should be able when the time comes to erect the building at very little cost.

In May last I suggested to Dr. Westgate, that an effort should be made to secure one of the two large buildings situated in Dawson, and owned by the Government, to house our school. Unfortunately that effort did not succeed. I know that there is considerable opposition on the part of the authorities to having the School in the Town of Dawson, and if the School were to be located here permanently I too would oppose, not because of any antipathy to the Indians but because I believe that the School can best fulfill its purpose outside the town. But as an emergency measure solely for the duration of the war it was unjust to refuse us one or other of the two buildings. The only other building in the Territory is also owned by the Government and located at Mayo. It was until this year used as a Hospital. It is smaller and not so suitable as either of the others.

With the intense activity now going on in southern Yukon I feel strongly that we should move the Carcross School further north for the duration of the war. I should also like to point out that the epidemic, which was the occasion of the drastic action taken by Dr. Roth, affected Champagne, Whitehorse, Teslin and their environs far worse than
Regarding the question of Indian Day Schools I am convinced that if we could provide sufficient day schools we would best meet the needs of our Indian population. But to place Education within the reach of every Indian Child by this means would entail an expenditure more than ten times what we are spending today. To my mind the only feasible solution is to have one Residential School together with a number of day schools located at those centers where a sufficient number of children can be had to make the teachers efforts worthwhile.

If the Indian Affairs Branch wishes to have one or more Indian Day Schools opened in the Yukon and will provide the salary for the teachers I shall be quite willing to endeavour to secure suitable teachers and arrange to have the schools established. There are several possible areas for such schools, viz., the Indian Village near Mayo; "Big Lake" west of Carmacks; Carmacks; Teslin; somewhere in the Champagne area, west of Whitehorse; Ross River; and possibly Whitehorse.

I think it was most unfortunate that your Branch three years ago withdrew the grants from our seasonal Indian Day Schools. No expenditure that your Branch made in Yukon brought better returns for the small cash outlay involved than the Seasonal Day Schools. At these centers during the summer months it was possible to get together as many as 30 children in some instances. We may not have been able to take them very far on the Educational Highway but they were learning to read and write, a little arithmetic, and perhaps even more important, the elements of Hygiene, Sanitation and Health habits. All this was cast aside for a saving of less than $250.00 per school.

Nothing can now be done until next summer about moving the Carcross School. By March next we should be in a better position to judge what the year 1943 will be bringing to us in Yukon and I should then like to submit to you a definite proposal regarding this School for the duration of the war.

If you should decide to proceed with the opening of one or more new Indian Day Schools in the Yukon I shall be glad to hear from you as soon as possible, for while it will not be possible to do anything about the actual starting of the school till the first of June next, yet it will take some time to secure suitable teachers, and also the material for the construction of the necessary buildings.

You will already have been made familiar with the measures taken to deal with the situation at Carcross for this winter. I think it was the only possible solution. We could not have sent all the children home for some of the children have no home.

Yours very truly,

Dear Bishop Geddes:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of November 11 and to thank you for the information contained therein.

I am disposed to think that some misunderstanding has arisen in respect to the operation of seasonal schools in the Yukon Territory. There is nothing on file here to indicate that the grants usually made to these schools have been withdrawn at any time. In the estimates of this year I note that provision has been made for the operation of the following schools: Champagne Landing, Old Crow Village, Rampart House, Teslin Lake, and Whitehorse, in addition to the two more or less regular schools at Moosehide and Selkirk. The total amount set apart for the operation of these schools is $2,790.

In recent years when our estimates have come up for discussion, the desirability of keeping seasonal schools in operation throughout the Dominion has been very fully discussed. There is a feeling amongst a number of our officials that unless qualified teachers can be secured for the operation of these schools, the expenditure made to keep them open and in operation is a sheer waste of money. However, we have never definitely decided to close them.

We are experiencing at the present time, and have been experiencing for the last 10 or 12 years, the utmost difficulty in securing the funds necessary to keep our residential schools in a state of repair and to provide the money necessary for their operation. In view of existing conditions, this difficulty is likely to confront us for a great many years to come. I doubt very much, therefore, the wisdom of continuing to erect additional residential schools unless we can see our way clear to keep these schools in a reasonable state of repair.

MEMORANDUM:

Deputy Minister,

You will find attached a memorandum dated November 16 submitted to me by Mr. Hoey and dealing with the operation of the Carcross Indian Residential School.

The facts set forth and the observations made by Mr. Hoey have a much wider application than to the question of the Carcross school itself. Mr. Hoey refers to his memorandum dealing with the general question of residential schools dated May 31, 1940. I have carefully re-read this memorandum and have discussed the matter with Mr. Hoey and Mr. Phelan.

I am in full agreement with the views held by the officials in charge of Indian education that the time has come when a definite decision should be reached regarding our policy in respect to residential schools. I hold, and have long held the opinion that the educational requirements of the great majority of Indians could be met by day schools to the decided benefit of the Indians and to the financial advantage of the taxpayer.

As it has been pointed out very plainly by Mr. Hoey many times, both verbally and in writing, our vote for several years past has not been sufficient to keep these buildings in a proper state of repair. A steady deterioration is taking place in our physical equipment and the question must be decided whether we are to go forward in developing a residential school system or to direct our efforts in another direction.

Lately I have been disagreeably impressed by a number of police reports concerning truancy from these schools.

In Mr. Hoey's memorandum of May 31, 1940, mentioned above, you will note his recommendation that a number of dilapidated residential schools that are costly to repair and operate be closed and Indian day schools be substituted therefor. On page 3, paragraph 2, of the same report you will note the figures he gives showing that the amount saved in one year in per capita grants through the closing of certain residential schools would almost meet the cost of building Indian day schools to take care of the pupils affected.

(over)
I am in full agreement with Mr. Hoey's recommendation that a number of these residential schools be closed and day schools substituted therefor. I would suggest that as soon as war regulations regarding building materials permit, the building of day schools and the closing of certain residential schools be proceeded with, in accordance with the plans and recommendations made by Mr. Hoey and outlined above.

Several days ago, a letter was received from Bishop Geddes of the Yukon, dealing with the Carcross school and carrying the suggestion that a system of day schools might be introduced into the Yukon.

1. Sir: FORWARDED 2-2-43. On the night of 23-12-43 two coloured United States soldiers named Cpl. A. JONES and Pte. J. L. JAMES, feloniously entered the Indian residential school at Carcross, Y.T., with the assistance and connivance of the following three Indian female children who are residents of the school:

Mabel Sidney aged 12 years
Grace Smarch aged 10 years
Emma Sidney aged 8 years.

Pte. James went to bed with Mabel Sidney and Cpl. Jones went to bed with Grace Smarch. In the early morning of 23-12-43 they were detected by the principal of the school who informed the R.C.M.P. Police who arrested the two men and turned them over to the United States Military Authorities. It has come to light that these two men have done the same thing in the school on previous occasions.

2. It is stated by the girls and their statements supported by competent medical testimony of Captain Faison, United States Army, that the girls were not seduced, no penetration in the slightest degree having taken place. Nevertheless, the offences committed by these two men amount to indecent assaults upon females.

3. The two soldiers are to be tried by a United States Army Court Martial. They have both been transferred from Carcross to Haines, Alaska, with their Company. We are to be advised of the result of the Court Martial.

The writer immediately proceeded to this school, accompanied by Cst. MacDonald.

On arrival at the school we found the Rev. H.C.M. Grant, the above mentioned Principal of the school, on guard outside the girls dormitory, the door of which he had locked. Mr. Grant advised that some short time previously he had made a check of the girls dormitory, during his rounds as night watchman in the absence on account of sickness of the regular night watchman, and upon checking this dormitory he had noticed that some of the girls, there being nine girls altogether in this dormitory, had gone to bed with their day clothes on, which is strictly against the rules of the school. Upon discovering this he had made a check of all the beds, and upon opening a corner bed, the occupant of which was covered up with bed clothes, he had discovered a Negro soldier in bed with one of the main girl students of the school. He had asked the soldier what he was doing there, and then thinking the soldier might be armed, he had left the dormitory, closed the door after him, and had then sent Miss. Oke for the police. He was quite sure that this soldier had not escaped, as there was only one way he could get out, unless he broke through the door, which was locked from the outside.

After Mr. Grant had imparted this information, the writer proceeded into the dormitory, leaving Cst. Donald to watch the outside of the building. The dormitory was thoroughly searched, it consists of only two rooms, a porch at one end. No trace of this soldier could be found. None of the windows had been tampered with, so it was certain that he had not made his escape in that manner. The rest of the building was then searched but without result. Mr. Grant suddenly thought of the attic, which is situated above the dormitory. This trapdoor was pushed back, and the writer heard in the attic. The writer climbed on the roof of the dormitory and looked through the trapdoor, seeing two soldiers of the U.S. Army coloured troops lying on the floor, and another one hiding behind a box in the same attic. These soldiers were arrested, and taken to the Detachment. On the same date they were handed over to the authorities.

When you were here recently we discussed St. Paul's Hostel at Dawson very fully and I undertook to advise you on certain points after discussion with the Acting Deputy Minister. It was decided -

(1) That the responsibility for the care of indigent white and half-breed children in the Yukon Territory is not with the Indian Affairs Branch but rests with the Yukon Council.

(2) That the rate of $250 per annum charged for each white or half-breed child accommodated at St. Paul's Hostel is not exorbitant.

(3) That parents who can pay for the care of their children should do so.

(4) That Council responsibility for the care of any child in St. Paul's Hostel should begin only when the Controller has approved of the admission of the child.

(5) That there is no reason from a departmental standpoint why Dawson children whose parents can house and feed them should be cared for in St. Paul's Hostel, especially when they are attending Public School.

I am informed that the Indian Affairs Branch is discussing with Bishop Geddes a suggestion that arrangements be made for accommodating in St. Paul's Hostel a number of the Indian children who could not be accommodated in Carcross school. No doubt advice of the decision reached will be sent directly to the Indian Agent at Dawson and will probably reach him before you return there.

(over)
I am to request that you bring to the attention of the Yukon Council the responsibility of that body for the care of indigent white and half-breed children in the Yukon Territory and the facilities offered by St. Paul's Hostel.

Dear Sir:

Bishop Geddes, who visited Ottawa on the 16th, 17th and 18th of this month, discussed very fully with the officials of the Welfare and Training Service and with myself the existing educational facilities for Indian children in the Yukon and additions or extensions that might be made to these facilities in the immediate future.

In view of the fact that this Branch is no longer assuming responsibility for the payment of an annual grant to the St. Paul's Hostel, the proposal first made by the Director of Lands, Parks and Forests, that a number of 'teen age Indian girls might be given a certain amount of training in the hostel in house-keeping and elementary domestic science, was fully discussed with the Bishop. We can see no objection to this course of training for Indian girls. The age of such girls, however, should not exceed 16 and they should be admitted to the hostel only after medical examination and with the usual departmental approval. We do not think that the number of these girls at any stated period of time should exceed 10.

Re: Carcross Indians.

While at Whitehorse last week I proceeded by train to Carcross where I had some discussion of Indian Affairs with Rev. H.C.M. Grant, and Constable W.J. MacDonald.

The stone basement seemed to me to be in a good state of repair. There is a sawmill with local lumber close at hand and it would seem that the construction of a building could be undertaken at less expense there than in most places in the Yukon Territory.

In conversation with Rev. Mr. Grant, he advised me that all the cattle belonging to the school had been sold, but they still have two horses, four pigs, five piglets, and some twenty-eight chickens. With reference to Mr. Hoey's letter of August 3rd which only recently arrived might I suggest that where an early reply is desired letters should be sent by Air Mail as otherwise receipt of the letter is often delayed for a matter of weeks.

You ask my opinion with regard to the opening of new day schools in the Yukon Territory. I find that I am not in a position to make any recommendation. Aside from a few hours visit to Carcross and a few minutes stopover at various Indian settlements along the river I have had no opportunity of acquainting myself with actual conditions among the Indians, with the exception of those in the immediate vicinity of Dawson, Mayo, and Whitehorse. The only enquiries that I could make would be from the Church and from the Police. No doubt you have suggestions from the former body. I would not place much value on recommendations received from R.C.M. Police Detachment members in outlying districts, who for the most part have not been in the country very long.

My own limited experience would indicate that Indian Day Schools as presently functioning in the Territory are of doubtful and varying value. For instance the school at Moosehide Indian village has a reasonable average attendance and the missionary in charge according to the curriculum which he has shown me is making a systematic effort to teach. On the other hand he is handicapped by cramped and inadequate quarters and poor lighting.

At Selkirk settlement the Quarterly Returns indicate a very low average attendance. My own opinion, strengthened by confidential reports which I have received from reliable sources, is that the Government is not receiving value for its monthly outlay at this point.

I discussed this matter with Bishop Geddes the day before he left Dawson presumably to go eventually to Ottawa.
while his views and mine will probably not entirely coincide he has this advantage, that he has personal knowledge of the various Indian settlements in the Territory.

Dear Doctor Alderwood:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of March 30, in which you discuss the rebuilding of the Indian Residential School at Carcross, Y.T.

We have given a great deal of careful consideration to the suggestion contained in your communication, that an annual rental be allowed by the Department for the use of the new building. The request for the payment of rent at a permanently established residential school presents, in our judgment, a great many administrative difficulties that cannot be easily adjusted. Our records here indicate that rents have never been paid for the use of residential school buildings, except in an emergency, such as the emergency that existed at Carcross immediately following the destruction of the school by fire, and the condition that now exists at Prince Albert following the destruction of the Onion Lake Residential School.

We have at this date 76 residential schools. Of these, 27 are church-owned. At none of these, however, are we allowing rent for the use of the building. Dear Mr. Hoey:

Re: Carcross School

I am replying separately to your letter of May 5th but now desire to make a formal application for an increased pupilage in this school.

You will recall that we have previously made application for a continuance of the rental which was being paid by the Department for the temporary buildings used until June 1943, in the village of Carcross. As our Missionary Society has been faced with the necessity of an expenditure of at least $20,000 in order that the work of this school may be continued, we felt that it was reasonable to expect the Department to continue the assistance they had given by way of rental. I submitted this request to Mr. Clarence Jackson and was advised that it could not be granted in the present instance as so many other religious bodies were concerned in Indian Education, and many similar requests would probably be received if such a precedent was established. Meanwhile, the work of building the school is going forward and there is every prospect that it will shortly be completed.

In discussing this question with Mr. Jackson when in Ottawa recently, the question of adjustment of per capita grants came up. I pointed out that whereas we receive $250 per pupil at Carcross, which is the largest amount given for any of our schools, we were never able to maintain the work without drawing upon Church funds. This arises, of course, not only from the fact of the very high cost of operating such an isolated school but from the low pupilage authorized. I pointed out the possibility of rendering a better service when the authorized pupilage is larger and the fixed overhead only slightly increased. This seemed to me to be a fair solution of our present Carcross difficulty and I suggested that if the Department could authorize us to admit a larger number of pupils it might enable us to improve our financial position. I, therefore, on behalf of our Commission beg to make formal application for an authorized pupilage of fifty in the new Carcross School. My information is that we can readily secure this number of children and I am confident that the building can be enlarged to take care of this number if we are assured that they will be authorized. In view of the fact that our Church is making this
heavy capital expenditure, by reason of the fact that the Department is unable to carry out its own plans for a permanent school at the present time, it would seem fair that we should not be asked to continue to operate at a loss but should have the opportunity of receiving a higher annual income.

I shall await with interest the decision of the Department in this matter and shall be grateful for some early reply as the work of construction is now going forward.

With kind regards, I remain,

Yours sincerely,

H. A. Alderwood
Secretary.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER.

I am sending forward herewith copy of a letter received by this Branch from Dr. H. A. Alderwood, Secretary of the Indian and Eskimo Residential School Commission of the Church of England in Canada.

Dr. Alderwood has on more than one occasion discussed with me the proposal he now submits in this communication. He was for a time anxious that the Department should pay rent for the use of the Carcross Residential School. I reminded him that it had not been the policy of the Department to pay rent for residential school buildings except in an emergency and then only for a limited period of time. I expressed the opinion that any departure from this practice would lead to endless confusion and dissatisfaction. Dr. Alderwood then suggested an adjustment, either in the pupilage or in the per capita grant payments. I assured him that any proposal submitted by him for such an adjustment would be carefully and sympathetically considered by the Minister.

The Carcross Residential school had, at the time of its destruction by fire, April 17, 1939, an enrolment of 40 pupils, for which per capita grant amounting to $250.00 was allowed. Incidentally, this is the highest per capita paid at any residential school in the Dominion. In view of the urgent need for residential school accommodation in the Yukon territory, it would appear to me to be sound, from an educational standpoint, and reasonably equitable and fair to the Anglican Church authorities, who have constructed the school at Carcross without cost to this Department, to allow an additional 10 pupils, or a total authorized pupilage of 50 at this school.

Acting Director.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Carcross Indian Residential School.

In April, 1939, the above Residential School, at that time Government-owned, was lost by fire. It had an authorized enrolment at that time of 40 pupils. As the Department, due to war conditions, was unable to replace the structure, the M.S.C.C. erected a temporary building at a cost of $24,000.00. The building was not sufficiently large for permanent use and it was thought that at the conclusion of hostilities the Government would replace the temporary structure, erected by the Church, with a larger building suitable for permanent use.

We have now received a letter from Canon Cook of the M.S.C.C., reading in part as follows:

"The present situation at Carcross is most unsatisfactory. The school is authorized to carry sixty pupils but dormitory and other accommodation allows for no more than forty-five. Staff members are inadequately quartered and the principal is finding it necessary to live in a built-over chicken house. All, staff and children alike, suffer from the cold and draughty buildings during the winter time and there is the ever constant fear of fire from the use of many stoves.

"At the moment, the Administration is in the unhappy position of losing the services of an excellent principal unless better accommodation can be arranged for his family before next winter.

"Less than one hundred miles from Carcross the Government is constructing a large modern school for the..."
Roman Catholic Church. The Administration feels that our needs for more adequate facilities at Carcross ought to have had prior consideration.

"In the light of the above, I would respectfully submit for your consideration the following:

(a) That a suitable building for the Principal and his family be constructed this summer at the Carcross Residential School.

(b) That the Indian Department have its engineers visit the site of the Chootla School with a view to their making recommendations to enlarge the school to suitable proportions for adequate accommodation of at least eighty pupils and the necessary staff.

(c) That a sufficient sum be included in the 1949-50 appropriation to allow for the renovations or rebuilding recommended by the engineers."

In view of the representations made above by Canon Cook, it is recommended that the following action be taken:

(a) That a Prefabricated Bungalow be ordered from Prefabricated Structures, Limited, of Vancouver, B.C., for shipping to Carcross by July 15. Mr. Indian Agent Meek advises that a prefabricated building of this type would be satisfactory and the Principal of the School will also accept such a building. If you concur in this recommendation, we attach a requisition covering the purchase of this building.

(b) That approval be given to having one of the officials of the Lands and Development Services Branch visit this school with a view to making recommendations concerning the enlargement, as mentioned by Canon Cook.

Director.

Dear Sir,

During our visit among the Southern Yukon Indians this summer, I found there is a desire on the part of some parents to place their children at the Chena Residential School at Carcross. The present accommodation is insufficient, and I have to warn them that it may be a little time before they can be taken; there is a waiting list.

Again in view of the greater contact which the Indians of the Southern Yukon have with the "whites," through the Alaska Highway and other transport facilities, I venture to submit that they should be encouraged to send their children elsewhere than to the occasional day school, where they seldom reach even beyond Grade 2. They will benefit our Canadian life generally and be benefited...
if they are given such educational opportunities, as will enable them to become fully serviceable Canadian citizens, able to read and write with ease, and continue through raising their mental and manual development. For those who are likely to spend their lives in remote parts, education is often a wasted asset, but within 150 miles or so of White Horse, the Indian children should be given greater chances than they now enjoy. An average school, enlarged to take 80 children, which I feel is quite a conservative estimate, would help to this end. Except at the Residential School, I doubt whether the majority of children attend even as many as 100 school sessions in the year—that is in Yukon.

Our Anglican Church will cooperate as fully as possible, if we can have increased accommodation.

I have the honour to be

Your obedient servant,

Walter Hudson (Bishop)

On December 30, 1948, I accompanied Const. G. Lawrence, R.C.M.P., to Carcross in connection with complaint of theft by M. Watson, trader. Suspected was John Wally, 15, pupil of Carcross Indian Residential School. No information could be obtained that date, but later Const. Lawrence obtained a confession from John Wally that he had broken into M. Watson's store and stolen money and goods.

On February 8th I appeared with John Wally before J.A. Simmons, J.P., Judge of Juvenile Court, at Carcross. He was charged with theft of money and goods to value of $74.00, on December 17th, 1948. Rev. J.W. Ellis, principal Carcross Residential School, stated he had difficulty with the boy for some months and wished him expelled from the school. After hearing all the evidence Wally was adjudged a juvenile delinquent.

Final disposition suspended on condition that John Wally be placed on probation in the care and custody of Rev. H.I. Lee, director of Whitehorse Indian Mission School, for an indeterminate period during which time John Wally was to report to R.C.M.P., Whitehorse, daily. Rev. Lee stated he was willing to accept Wally for a probationary period of one month at the rate of $50.00, and if the boy was satisfactory, he will revert to normal charges. There is no R.C.M.P. at Carcross. No Indian foster home could be found for John Wally in Whitehorse. He is an orphan, with only very distant relatives living at Fort Selkirk. Dr. Duncan recommended John Wally not be sent there as the Roberts family is T-B, one child having died recently.

John Wally was found as an infant abandoned in an Indian camp. He was brought to Whitehorse Hospital where he lived for a year or so, then he was sent to Carcross Residential School where he has remained since 1938. When case comes up for final disposition, a further report will be submitted.

Dear Canon Cook:

In reply to your wire received last night I submit the following information. Before compiling it I spent several hours with Mr. Meek and Mr. Drury Jr. Unfortunately Archbishop Adams was not in Whitehorse so I was not able to consult him. Mr. Drury, by the way, has a store at Carmacks and is well acquainted with the village and the surrounding district.

Whitehorse: As you are aware there is one Protestant School in Whitehorse taking care of about one hundred Indians and half-breeds. At the present time they are having considerable difficulty in maintaining discipline, especially amongst the older girls. This situation is aggravated by the number of troops now stationed in Whitehorse on Exercise "Sweetbriar" but such a condition has always existed, and in my opinion will continue.

Relationships with the R.C. Church. To my mind comes the possibility of opposition if two Protestant schools are established in Whitehorse. I feel sure that strong objections would be raised and plans for ourselves might easily be delayed on that account.

Gardening Possibilities. The soil in Whitehorse and surrounding district is very poor. It would be necessary to go at least fifty miles in order to find suitable land for gardening on the scale we require.

Utilities, Hospitalization, Freight. One of the great advantages to Whitehorse come under this heading.

Carmacks.

Situation: Carmacks is located on the Yukon River, 120 road miles from Whitehorse. As you advised in your letter an all weather road will be completed this year. It is fairly central to the following points, to the north, Dawson, Stewart and Selkirk. To the south, LeBerge. To the east, Mayo. To the west, Aishihik. The total Indian population of these points being about 650.

Gardening, Fuel, Water Supply. The land is good and has been successfully cultivated on quite a large scale. There is an ample wood supply easily available. There is also a coal mine two miles from the village, and the coal is recommended especially for automatic stokers. From information received the water supply is more than adequate. (wells) There is a saw-mill located at Minto, thirty miles north and also one at Mayo, 120 miles away, but both are on the highway.

Utilities, Hospitalization, Freight. Regular weekly plane service is maintained during the winter. During the summer months it is served by boat at least once a week. A government telegraph station is maintained, also a nursing station. A scheduled bus and trucking service is expected to operate this
summer. Hospitals with doctors are maintained at Whitehorse and Mayo. Carmacks is midway between these two points. Freight rates from Whitehorse by boat are fairly reasonable. A good deal of the freight is shipped from Vancouver to Haines and then hauled to Carmacks by truck, a distance of about 250 miles. This I believe is the cheapest way as handling is kept to a minimum.

There is a reserve of 330 acres situated about a mile from the village. The white population of the village together with the mine employees number about 50. In a situation such as this, some changes would be necessary in the Wabasca plan for a school. I would suggest that provision be made for at least a six bed sick bay, and also the refrigerator space be large enough for a six months supply.

Personally, if we have to move, I am in favor of Carmacks. The children would have much more freedom with less danger of interference. It would take the majority of them closer to their homes, which would enable them to go home for the summer holidays. I do think it a mistake to keep them from their parents and families for a too long period. However, I do not think my own personal opinion should influence the decision too much, so I trust the foregoing information will give you an adequate picture of the situation.

If a change is made from the present location consideration will have to be given to classrooms, I would suggest three. Provision will also have to be made for garage, workshop, powerhouse and numerous other small buildings. Last, but not least, the principal's residence and greenhouse.

With best wishes for your success in negotiations with government.

Yours sincerely,

Joe W. Ellis,
Principal.

The Principal was asked for his comments on Superintendent R.J. Meek's report and the following was received in a letter from Mr. Ellis this morning.

"The report submitted by R.J. Meek to Indian Affairs Branch outlines the situation fairly well, but the following details, very important from my point of view, have been omitted.

(a) From December 28, 1948 when the theft was committed, until the hearing, February 8th John Wally broke into a warehouse at the school and also my house. In both instances food and other articles were stolen and he was assisted by other boys. In both cases when confronted with strong evidence John admitted planning and persuading the other boys to take part in the escapade. Neither of these boys, have in the past, misbehaved in this manner. I reported both these cases to R.J. Meek and after the second offence asked for a discharge for John Wally.

(b) After waiting several weeks without action being taken by the R.C.M.P. I made a special trip to Whitehorse and in consultation with Mr. R.J. Meek and Mr. J.A. Failing that he would be sent to the Reform School at Vancouver. However upon the recommendation of Dr. Duncan it was found inadvisable to send him to the only relatives he appears to have. Lawrence, Whitehorse. I am informed by R.C.M.P. that you receive Police Reports direct from their Headquarters at Ottawa. Const. Lawrence covered several of the points which the Rev. J.W. Ellis first made his complaint aggravated the situation considerably as far as he was concerned.

I interviewed Magistrate Simmons who informed me he had no intention of sending John Wally to an Industrial School in Vancouver. The Magistrate has many years of experience with Indians and has lived almost all his life in the Yukon; he considers it unwise to send Indians of John Wally's type to white institutions. He expressed himself as satisfied with present arrangements.

Corp. R. Kent, N.C.O. 1/c R.C.M.P., Whitehorse, informed me that he was opposed to sending Indian Juvenile Offenders Outside. It is inferred he instructed his constable to make this recommendation to Magistrate Simmons. Corp. Kent stated he was satisfied with conditions under which John Wally is placed.

Before the case was tried I was instructed by Magistrate Simmons to suggest all arrangements which could be made; Dr. Duncan opposed sending Wally to his distant relatives who were suffering from tuberculosis. The other two alternatives were to send the boy to an Industrial School Outside, or to place him under proper care in the Yukon. No foster home could be found for the boy in this area. Mr. Simmons then suggested the Indian School of Rev. Lee, the latter heard the case before agreeing to take him in charge.
The Rev. Ellis knows how difficult Wally is to handle and still maintains that he should be sent to an Industrial School. However, when Magistrate Simmons gave his decision, the matter was considered closed. The statements contained in Rev. Ellis' report are matters of private opinion and he wishes them to remain as such.

Final report of disposition of this case has now been received from R.C.M.P. Paragraph 3 states:

"In view of the favourable reports on the boys' behaviour during the probationary period, His Worship deemed that the corrective measures already taken were sufficient and the said Juvenile Delinquent was reprimanded and released. It might be mentioned that he is continuing to attend the Indian School which is supervised by Rev. Lee."

The files have now been closed at the R.C.M.P. Detachment on this case.

Dear Miss Evans:

Referring to your letter of the 20th inst. enclosing the June Quarterly payment for the Carcross school.

Mr. Phelan's statement places the average pupilage at forty which was the old sanctioned pupilage. You will recollect however that in a letter from Mr. Hoey dated the 29th of May 1944 No - 166-1-1 a pupilage of fifty was sanctioned after the opening of the new school. Archdeacon Grant's return for the June quarter shows that the average attendance of pupils amounts to 48.13 and our checking of his return concurs with this figure so that apparently instead of the earning for the June quarter being $2500.00 it should be $2820.63.

It is possible there may be some explanation for this discrepancy but I thought it well to draw your attention to the fact that the pupilage had been increased from forty to fifty.

Yours faithfully,

E. W. Mermagen,
Assistant Secretary-Treasurer.

CHIEF, EDUCATION DIVISION

Carcross Residential School

Payment of Grants for September, 1950 Quarter

Reference is to correspondence item No. 15161 being a circular addressed to Principals of Residential Schools under the direction of the Anglican Indian School Administration.

There is a minute from Canon Cook to Colonel Neary that indicates that the monetary matters referred to in the circular were a subject of previous discussion and agreement.

The Quarterly Return from Carcross School, however, is probably being audited at a reduced amount that falls considerably short of the amount which the Principal is entitled to claim and has claimed, although he may have to some extent changed the manner of making the claim.

May I suggest that this Division anticipate the receipt of any reproach. Carcross is a small-pupilage school which has fixed administrative expenses and probably operates at a deficit. I recommend that an assurance go forward that the amount to be paid for the September Quarter will more nearly approximate the amount that has been claimed.

C.A.F. Clark,

Sir:-

I have the honor to report that the electric lighting plant at the Carcross Indian Residential School is now in good working order and that with ordinary care should give no further trouble.

The plant has been moved from the furnace room to the print shop which is kept locked up thus preventing pupils from interfering with it. Mr Gray, the electrician, had to wait five days for a train to return to Whitehorse so he filled in the time by moving the plant without increasing the cost as he would have charged his time while detained at the school.

Enclosed herewith is a copy of the letter of the Manager of the Yukon Electrical Co giving details of the nature of the breakdown. The account has not yet come to hand.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,

I am enclosing herewith invoice in triplicate from the Yukon Electrical Co. for repairing and moving electric plant.

I would like to enclose a summary of the work done and the time taken.

Friday Jan. 8th started work on plant and got it running.

Saturday Jan. 9th. Worked on plant repairing same and charging batteries which were very low.

Sunday Jan. 10th. Charging batteries.

Monday Jan. 11th. Moved plant into Print Shop and got it running and in perfect order.

Tuesday Jan. 12th. Left for Whitehorse by afternoon train.

I have set forth these items so that you may have a better idea of how matters actually were, otherwise the items on the invoice are rather misleading. We must understand that Mr. Grey said that he would charge for his time while absent from Whitehorse that is from Friday Jan. 8th. to Tuesday Jan. 12th. incl.

Therefore the cost of moving the plant was practically nothing.

Trusting these few remarks will help to explain matters.

I am,

Sir:

I have the honor to enclose herewith the account of the Yukon Electrical Co of Whitehorse for repairs to the electric lighting plant at the Carcross Indian Residential School. Also the report of the Principal on the daily work done by the electrician.

Moving the engine from the furnace room to the print shop is undoubtedly a wise move and, as pointed out by the Principal, it has been done without extra cost to the Department. Trains from Carcross are running on Tuesday and Friday only therefore the electrician was compelled to stay from Friday to Tuesday and would have charged his time if he had not moved the engine. We hope this will meet with the Department's approval.

Enclos.2.

Dear Mr. Hawksley:

I regret very much that I am unable to remain over until your arrival, as I should like to have the pleasure of meeting you, in addition to having an opportunity of discussing with you certain matters pertaining to this School. A number of engagements, however, have been booked for me in British Columbia and in order to keep these I must leave Skagway this evening.
