The staff with the exception of the Principal, where a change is under contemplation, appears to me to be fully competent, and I am hopeful of good results in all future work.

I am strongly of the opinion that more accommodation and equipment should be provided not later than next year, and if your Department can provide these I shall be very deeply obliged. Our Society will endeavour to provide the staff rooms with rugs, and certain other furnishings, but the question of providing (1) a boys' recreation room (2) a chapel which could, with the sanctuary shut off by folding doors, be used as an assembly room (3) modern laundry equipment (4) full sized doors and windows and netting for the same (5) a bridge across the creek and a road around it, is one which involves too heavy an expenditure for our Society to undertake. Mr. Barshaw will give you my suggestion with regard to the location of the boys' recreation room and chapel.

Sir:

I have the honor to enclose herewith copy of letter received from the Rev Dr Westgate in reference to certain improvements and requirements at the Carcross Indian Residential School.

In the first place I may say that his estimate ($10,000) to cover the cost of the improvements mentioned in his letter would not be sufficient if all the suggestions were undertaken. The cost of labour and material is very high in the Yukon.

Before undertaking any of the suggested improvements may I be permitted to call attention to some necessary repairs to the interior of the building. There are still a number of rooms and all the corridors with a quantity of loose plaster some of which occasionally falls off. I consider the removal of this and replacing it with beaver board the first and most necessary expense to be undertaken.

Now that the school has electricity it would be a great help and a saving of much time and labour if electric washing machines and wringers were supplied.

A recreation room would be a very useful addition, the boys have to use the laundry as a recreation room which is not very convenient for such a purpose. I do not consider a chapel necessary for such a small institution (36 pupils). There is a good church in Carcross which the pupils attend on Sunday. The walk from the school to the church is good for the pupils and I have every reason to believe that they enjoy it. The schoolroom can be and is used for the daily prayers this, I consider, meets the need.

A bridge across the creek would be a convenience though I would not call it a necessity. From November to April the creek can be safely crossed on the ice.
New screens are needed for the windows. I would suggest a supply of sliding screens, such as were supplied some years ago would meet the need. I think the cost was 50¢ per screen.

In conversation with the Rev Dr Westgate I gathered that it was his desire to make the school a show place because a number of tourists visit the school during two or three months of the summer. I am inclined to think that is not the policy of the Department. I take it that it is to be a practical educational centre for the Indians of the Territory.

Your obedient servant,

John Hawksley,
Indian Superintendent.

Revd and Dear Sir:

Following my telegraphic report of yesterday I beg to make the following supplemental report re the fire which broke out in the hospital ward of the school here on Thursday evening.

I was sitting in the office talking with one of the other members of the staff when we smelt smoke as we arose to investigate we were informed that there was fire. The alarm was immediately turned in and the children and other members of the staff responded in a most splendid manner. There was no panic and everyone went directly to their posts, which fortunately had been allotted to all the day before, we having had fire drill on that day. One cannot speak too highly nor highly enough of the splendid efforts of all.

The flames apparently started in a trunk which was in the ward, it was near to a hot steam pipe but not in contact with it. The flames apparently originated inside, so perhaps we should be far wrong if we were to suggest that Internal Combustion was the cause. Practically no material damage was done to the school, the board itself was absolutely gutted and of no further use so it was torn out, the flames spread to the bathroom upstairs but were quickly extinguished.

Miss Ridgeway is the chief loser as she lost nearly all her personal effects including a large quantity of brand new clothes, a fur coat as well as a fur lined coat so I should say she has lost several hundred dollars of personal property. I should like to take the liberty of recommending that she receive some compensation.

As soon as I felt sure that the fire was out, I allowed the children back to their dormitories after hot cocoa was issued and vigil was kept in order to take no chances of it starting while all of the staff were asleep.

I am sure that I am not wrong in saying that a great debt is owed to the General Assistant, Mr. Storey, Miss Cameron and Miss Ridgeway for their splendid efforts in preventing what might have been a very serious disaster at the school over the week end on account of the
accident and I was very much relieved to have been on the spot at the time. By the time that I return home I shall have been at the school for ten days. Shall be home a week and then return every week so as to keep fully in touch with the work. The present staff are entirely competent and reliable.

May I also take the liberty of suggesting that you as the head of the Commission write a letter of thanks to the children of the school as the way they acted was simply splendid and I have seen nothing better in that way in any school including white schools.

Trusting that this is a full and satisfactory report.

I am,

Yours faithfully,

(sgd) W.H.L. West.
Acting Principal.

Sir:

I have the honor to submit the following report on the recent fire at the Carcross Indian Residential School taken from a letter recently received from the Rev W.H.L. West, acting principal.

"At eight o'clock last night smoke was discovered issuing from the hospital ward which was at the time unoccupied, it was found that the room was on fire, an immediate alarm was given which was promptly answered, all the staff and pupils having had fire drill only the day before. The pumps were promptly manned and in a very short time the fire was subdued. Some damage was done to the walls of the ward, the prompt and efficient work of the pupils and staff undoubtedly saved the building. I wish to commend one and all in the highest terms for their splendid behaviour.

The origin of the fire is somewhat of a mystery it apparently having commenced in a trunk packed with the personal property of Miss Ridgeway. There was apparently nothing of an inflammable nature and the only conclusion I can reach is that it was started internal combustion probably helped by the fact that a hot steam pipe runs through the cupboard in which the trunk was stored although the trunk was not touching the pipe as far as I can ascertain. I am of the opinion that no blame can be attached to any one.

I believe that I have given you all the information available regarding what might have been a disastrous fire. I shall be glad to answer any further questions you may see fit to ask."

No particulars were given regarding the nature or the amount of damage done to the walls of the room. I have written to the Principal for a report on this.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,

I wish to draw your attention to a phase of the education given to the children of this school which used to be emphasized here but which of late years appears to have been more or less abandoned. I refer to the carpentry.

My special subject when teaching in white schools was manual training and I hold a certificate qualifying me to teach the same. In my opinion carpentry and forge work is a most valuable training for the Indian children and I am anxious to re-establish the work here.

We have a good shop with a number of tools for both branches of the work and we have been making use of them by starting a class on Friday afternoons. Not having any proper material we used gasoline cases and made some lockers for the use of the children in their dormitories. We are building a root cellar for storing our surplus of vegetables, and we have in view the building of an ice house and an addition to the chicken house, both to be built of logs, as a part of the training.

We are lacking a few tools and some material for small models and I should like you to give the matter consideration and if the department approve help us to re-establish this important aspect of our work. I am attaching a list of the requirements, and I sincerely hope the matter will meet with your approval and assistance.

I have the honour to be,

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I have your No. 2335-5 of the 22nd ultimo, reporting on the improvements at the Carcross Indian Residential School. I note that at a later date you will let me have information regarding the beaver board required.

I am today placing an order with Simmons, Ltd., Montreal, for 40 mattress casings, which will be suitable for the beds at the school. These are being shipped freight prepaid to the school, and the account, in triplicate, will be forwarded to you, together with freight receipt attached.

You speak of electrical power at the school and the possible use of an electric washer and pump. If you are referring to the Delco lighting plant which generates electricity for lighting the institution, I have to request that you will see that no machinery is run by it. Our experience at Indian residential schools, where they generate their own light, has made it necessary for us to forbid the attachment of any electrical appliances whatsoever.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

Referring to your letter of July 5th, file No 166-1-5, regarding certain repairs at the Carcross Indian Residential School.

I beg to submit the following information. The painting of the workshop and the outside toilets with two coats of paint and staining the shingle roofs of the same will cost $200.00. This work has been put in hand.

If the Department decide to carry out this work will you please be good enough to notify me by wire.

Your obedient servant,

MISSIONARY SOCIETY OF THE CHURCH OF ENGLAND IN CANADA

REQUIREMENTS WHICH THE SOCIETY DESIRE THE DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS TO FURNISH DURING THE YEAR 1928.

1. CARGO33

(a) Two storey annex to rear side of main building, the upper storey to be used as chapel and assembly room, and the lower storey as a laundry. At present this school has no chapel, no special laundry room or modern laundry equipment, and no recreation rooms. Where the winters are so long all of these are very necessary. A room in the basement has to serve as laundry and Boys' recreation room. The girls use the sewing room as a recreation room. Estimated cost $10,000.

(b) Battleship linoleum for corridors. (This will save a bigger expense for wood floors later on). Est cost $350.

(c) Beaver board for all rooms in main school building not yet completed in this way. Estimated cost $500.

(d) A motor launch (see Departmental letter Aug. 3rd, 1927, 165-1-5). Estimated cost $500.

(e) Change in water pumping system. The Principal states in this connection that the hand pump is extremely hard work and much too heavy for any of the boys at the school, with a result that the Principal himself and the General Assistant have to help with the pumping. The capacity of the tank is also inadequate and should be enlarged. Estimated cost $800.

(f) A cold storage room for meat and fish in summer. Estimated cost $500.

(g) One strong team of horses $300.

Total estimated cost $12,950.

Dear Sir:

Re: FREIGHT CANOE FOR THE CARCROSS SCHOOL

With further reference to your letter of August 3rd 1927, No. 166-1-5 relative to the purchase of a freight canoe for the Carcross Indian Residential School, I beg to enclose herewith a copy of a letter embodying a quotation in this connection recently received through the Rev. W. Tinney, Acting Principal of this institution, and will be glad to have your decision in connection with the same.

In his covering letter, Mr. Tinney writes in part, as follows:

"The three horse power engine and eighteen foot boat will suit us. I am of the opinion, however, that you might get a special rate from the Kermath Co. who have an agency in Winnipeg and Turner of Vancouver would probably instal the engine and supply the boat with a reduction in our case. Should you be able to get that advantage I would suggest that you supply a 4-5 H.P. engine in the place of the 3 H.P. The same boat carries it quite easily.

It is advisable to have Turner instal the engine in Vancouver, although there is a much lower freight rate on the boat and engine shipped separately. It would cost more than the saving in freight expenses for installation charges here."

Dear Sir:

I beg to report that the water pump for the main building is in such a state of repair that it can no longer be depended upon for any length of time. As you are aware it has been a constant source of trouble and expense since its installation. Since my appointment I have done all that is in my power to keep it together. We have employed whatever local help is available at no little expense to the school. The washers have been renewed, the stuffing box repacked time and time again, not only by ourselves but by those employed recently by you to overhaul the plumbing. In spite of all efforts the basement is continually flooded and the pump seldom in use for twenty-four hours continuously without giving trouble.

The worst feature of the difficulty is the labor required to fill the tank with water. It is exhausting work for all the bigger boys, the general assistant and myself, three or four times a day to keep just sufficient water in the tank to keep the building going. At times we are compelled to raise water from the well by hand to fill the boiler. There is no little risk incurred as the sanitation, heating and fire equipment depend upon the water supply.

In putting in new equipment I beg to suggest once more that there appears to me to be only one solution of the difficulty that is, to enlarge the present well-house and install a gas engine, pump jack and compression tank.

I would earnestly suggest that you give the matter your immediate attention.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Principal.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of 14th inst. as to general welfare.

You will have received a medical report on the last inspection of Dr Elvin. We are very pleased to be able to say that the general health of the pupils is very satisfactory. With the exception of Walter and Anna we have practically a clean bill of health. In connection with the last two named we are grateful to be able to say that there is a decided improvement. There is every prospect at the present time that they will both outgrow the chronic gland condition. Both are happy and in a good state of nutrition.

With reference to the staff we are sorry to report that Miss Winterburn's health necessitated her immediate return to her home and her brother took care of her on the journey. We are therefore a little handicapped at present but we are expecting their places to be filled very soon.

In regard to the condition to the school plant there is a great deal of improvement required. We have nearly completed the repairs to the storm sashes. Materials have cost in the neighbourhood of one hundred dollars. Many of the sashes were completely smashed, a number of them were being used at the cottage. I have had them all replaced which leaves the cottage without sashes. The materials for the screens are on hand and we have made enough screens for the ground floor in two carpentry classes.

These ground floor screens are whole screens of $2\frac{1}{2} \times 1$ in fir with lath over the wire and brazed at the corners with triangles of tin over the half lap joints.

The pump has been out of condition for some time; it has become necessary to have all the holes re-tapped and new pins made. Matthew Watson has sent the whole thing to Whitehorse to get it fixed and the cost will be included in his account for repairs to the plumbing. We have worked at it constantly in the nine months I have been here and I feel that no further time can be wasted upon it.

We have been expecting the electrician from Whitehorse to inspect the Delco Engine. He will probably be here shortly.
J.E. French has not yet made the repairs to the hospital ward but we expect him very soon.

The repairs to the root cellar are very satisfactory. It is not necessary to keep a fire in the shop in fact we have had no fire there this winter so far except for the carpentry classes. A coal oil lantern is all that is necessary in the cellar to keep the temperature around 35 degrees. I am now assured of our experiment with the proposed new root pit.

You will be interested to know that we have five fine dogs which we expect to break to harness this winter.

Our Christmas time was a very happy one for all. The pupils put on an excellent programme and carried it through in a very remarkable way. Nearly all the people from Carcross were at the school and expressed their surprise at the performance and the talent and delivery of the children. On Christmas Eve the school went in a body to the Indian village and sang Christmas Hymns and Carols. The surprise and pleasure of the Indians was very evident.

Your obedient servant.

(Signed) W. Tinney.

In reply I beg to say that since writing to the Department regarding the above enquiries have been made about a suitable plant to meet the needs of the school and to afford greater fire protection.

Dear Sir:

Re: Repairs to the Carcross School

The Rev. W. Tinney, Acting Principal of our Society's Indian Residential School at Carcross, has directed the attention of our Commission to the necessity of repairs to the interior walls of this institution, and I beg to submit the same to your Department for your sympathetic consideration. Mr. Tinney's letter reads in part as follows:

"The building is seventeen years old, and in need of repairs to the interior finishing. The plaster is coming off throughout the building. We have attempted to repair the broken places with new plaster but it is beyond patching. In some cases a whole wall is loose, in others there are holes two or three feet in length. The staff sitting room has been patched, but does not hold. The halls have large places where the lath is bare. The basement is perhaps the worst. The laundry and furnace room are in very bad condition and is a very depressing place.

I believe it is the intention of Mr. Hawksley to have the plaster taken off and beaver board put in its place. That has been done in the large dormitories and the hospital room.

We should like to request that application be made for a special grant for this purpose. We consider that at least the halls, sitting rooms and office, those places that are most public ought to be done at once. There are four or five rooms which could stand over another year if sufficient funds are not available for the whole thing."
In the light of the above information it is obvious that an effort should be put forth immediately to effect the improvements suggested.

In the list of requirements submitted by our Society to your Department last autumn, beaver board for all rooms in the main school building which had not yet been repaired in this way, was included, and it would be a great comfort and encouragement to the Principal and his staff, as well as to the children in the school, to have the loose plaster removed and the beaver board installed instead.

In the same list of requirements, a two storey annex to the rear side of the main building was also included, and steps should be taken to have this provided at the earliest date possible, as the building as it stands at present has no chapel, no special laundry-room or modern laundry equipment, and no recreation rooms.

I commend these requirements to your sympathetic consideration and remain, Sir,

Sir:-

I have the honor to enclose herewith two accounts from Matthew Watson of Carcross for material and labor supplied to the Carcross Indian Residential School.

Regarding the lumber, screen wire and other necessaries for making the screens for all the windows and doors at the school, the purchase of these was authorized by the Department. The screens have been made by the carpentry class during the winter and are now ready for use.

Referring to the account for piping and other fittings for the bath rooms. When I was at the school last September it was noted that the waste water from the bath rooms was running down the walls of the office and the hospital ward, the latter was on the point of being beaver boarded to repair the damage caused by the fire, before putting on the beaver board it was imperative that the leakage in the bath rooms should be stopped. An effort was made to clear the waste pipes but they were difficult to get at being embedded in the walls. It was decided that the only sure remedy was to put in new piping with the plumbing exposed and easy of access in case of future stoppage and thus prevent damage to the walls of the lower rooms.

It was necessary to put the work in hand at once therefore I ordered the work to be done which I hope will meet with the approval of the Department. Watson has been very dilatory about sending his account, it should have been here long before.

Sir,

I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of letter dated May 10th, file No 166-1-5, in reference to the installation of a 1000 gallon water tank at the Carcross Indian Residential School.

In reply I beg to say that I do not consider the tank is necessary. The 400 gallon tank in the attic is large enough to supply the daily needs of the school and when the new power pump is installed it can be kept filled with little trouble.

It is quite probable that the Principal, when asking for the tank, had in mind a reserve supply of water in case of fire. Apparently he has overlooked the fact that there is a direct connection with the well that is used in case of fire, by the simple act of closing a valve on the pipe that conducts the water to the tank in the attic the water passes directly from the well through the hose.

The average depth of water in the well, which is four feet square inside measurement, is from ten to twelve feet with a free seepage. Some years ago when 10 feet or the school roof was burned out two hose were in use with six men manning the pump which was working steadily for two hours on sounding the well after the fire was put out it was found that the depth of water had been lowered only three inches.

Under the circumstances it does not appear necessary to install a new tank, it would be rather an expensive item. I do not feel justified in recommending the suggested tank as, in my opinion, it is not needed.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

J.D. McLean, Esq.

Dear Sir:

Re: Larger Water Tank, Carcross School

With further reference to my letter of May 1st, and your replies to the same on May 10th and June 25th (76-166-1-5) relative to the request of the Principal of the Carcross School that a water tank to hold 1000 gallons be installed in this building to take the place of the existing tank which has a capacity of only 350 or 400 gallons, I beg to state that this important matter received very careful consideration by our Commission, at a meeting held on the 3rd inst., and I was instructed to inform you, that it is their very decided opinion the larger tank should be installed.

When considering this matter, our Commission had before them, the joint report of Archdeacon Tims, and the Principal of the Old Sun School, on destruction of this building by fire on the evening of June 26th, and as the lack of an adequate supply of water to combat the flames was stressed in this report, the members of the Commission felt it was their duty to advise you of the great necessity of taking any measures possible to prevent a similar situation from arising at any other institution.

In the case of the Carcross School they are of the opinion that the installation of the larger tank requested, would furnish the measure of protection and safety required, and they earnestly desire you to give this question further sympathetic consideration.

Mr. Superintendent Hawksley in his report to you, as quoted in your letter of June 25th, refers to the direct connection which can be established, in case of fire, between the well and the hose. With a sufficiently powerful engine, and a sufficiently large water tank, however, the School Management and the pupils will feel a sense of security which they do not at present enjoy, and our Commission hope that your Department may be able to supply these this summer.

Dear Sir:

Major Mermagen, the Assistant Secretary-Treasurer of our Commission, in his report on his recent visit to the Carcross School, refers to the urgent need of the following improvements at this institution:

(a) a new rubberoid roof for the Principal's residence. He states that the present roof is patched in places, and in other places the rubberoid is completely worn off. The whole roof is in a bad state of repair.

and I shall be very glad if your Department can authorize this expenditure.

I commend this request to your sympathetic consideration, and beg to add that I discussed the need in question with the Deputy Superintendent General during his recent visit to Winnipeg, and am presenting this statement in fulfilment of a promise made to him at that time.

Rev and Dear Sir:

Enclosed you will please find accounts in triplicate for the installation of the pumping plant by Matthew Watson of Carcross.

The work has been done very satisfactorily and the plant is a splendid acquisition to the school. The furnace room has a dry floor for the first time since my arrival. The old printing gear has been removed to Whitehorse so that we shall now have an engine room free from useless obstructions.

Dear Sir:-

I beg to direct your attention to the condition of the lighting system at our Carcross School. In a letter just received from the Acting Principal, the Rev. W. Tinney, he writes, in part, in this connection, as follows:-

"The plant was installed early in 1924 in the boiler room next to the old pump. A local firm had the contract. I am of the opinion that the battery would not have stood inspection at the time of installation. The Bruce Robinson Co., Vancouver, informed me that they supplied the engine but not the battery. The plant was moved to the print shop where greater care could be given. The anchor bolts were placed in the thin shell of cement of which the floor is made instead of in a substantial concrete block some inches above the level of the floor. In March 1927 the engine was in a bad state of repair partly as a result of vibration, and the battery seriously depleted as a result of irregular and improper charging.

Since that time the engine has been put on a new base and all the damaged parts replaced with the exception of the cylinder block. We have oversized rings on hand to put in but a new block will have to be got sometime. The engine however is now in pretty good repair and has been running without trouble all the winter except for fouling caused by worn cylinder oil pumping. The Indian Dept. has supplied the major repairs, crank-case, piston crank-shaft etc. amounting to approximately $200.00.

The battery on the other hand is beyond repair. It is composed of 56 thirteen plate cells. The positive element is disintegrated, completely filling the sediment spaces thereby..."
short circuiting the plates. Such condition means a complete new set of plates and refill of electrolyte. In most cases the plates are fallen apart. There is only one cell of the required specific gravity, the others will no longer respond to charging.

We require a new set of 56 K.X.G. 13 plate cells, 160 ampere hour, and a refill of electrolyte. The cells should be assembled with posts and straps and the electrolyte to the required specific gravity of 1280. The work can be done by the staff. I have no price list on hand but it will probably cost $500.00. The glass jars are in good repair. The Bruce Robinson Electric Co., Vancouver, are the nearest agents."

As it is obvious from the above that batteries are required, I shall be obliged if you will either place an order for the same, or authorize me to do so.

Your prompt attention to this important matter will be deeply appreciated.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

Dear Sir:-

In a letter dated April 30th, the Principal of our Society's Indian Residential School at Carcross, Yukon, directs my attention to the very urgent need of "a laundry and equipment and of a bath and bathroom for the use of the staff". For the year 1927, 1928 and 1929, a two storey annex to the main building to serve as chapel and assembly room and laundry has been included in the list of requirements which your Department was asked to furnish, but up to date this very necessary accommodation has not been provided.

During the recent visit of the Supt. of Indian Education to Winnipeg, I discussed this matter with him, and he agreed that careful consideration would be given to this matter in the preparation of the estimates for 1930. The situation, however, at present is so unsatisfactory that the Principal has informed our Commission that if they are to retain the services of the splendid staff agents they have at present, some immediate remedial action must be taken, and I was instructed to lay the situation before you, and ask if you would authorize our Commission to provide a bathroom and bath for the staff and some light laundry equipment such as hand-worked washing machines and wringers, or if you would arrange to have this equipment provided through your representative at Dawson. I may state for your information that during the interview referred to above, the Supt. of Indian Education expressed the opinion that some light laundry equipment might be provided to help the staff in the management of the School until the permanent improvement which the annex would furnish had been supplied. I shall be glad to know, therefore, what help you may be able to render in this important matter. The need, which has been very urgent for some time, has recently been intensified through the outbreak of illness at the School when three pupils fell seriously ill with what the Doctor at White Horse has diagnosed as septic pneumonia. All three pupils were taken to the hospital at White Horse.
where one of them - Martha McLeod, has since passed away. At the time of writing the Principal states that small hope was entertained for the recovery of the two others.

In addition to this very sad and very serious matter, the Principal states that there were 62 cases of measles in White Horse, and although the town was under quarantine, the disease was spreading, and they feared it might reach the School at Carcross. For these reasons you will see the urgent necessity of giving our School management at this centre the best accommodation and facilities possible under the circumstances, and I beg to strongly recommend that action be taken with the least possible delay to provide the bathroom and bath for the staff and such laundry equipment as will enable the School management to carry on their work until permanent and fully modern laundry equipment can be supplied.

I have the honour to be, Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

Dear Mr. Hawksley:

During my visit to this school I have made a careful examination of the heating, lighting, water and drainage systems, etc., and have prepared a list of requirements which I purpose submitting to the Department immediately after my return to Winnipeg, and asking that they be supplied at the earliest date possible. The Department have already authorized the installation of a bath for the use of the staff agents, and I will place an order for this, along with the necessary connexion pipes, when I reach Vancouver about the beginning of December.

I find also that the taps in the pupils' wash-rooms, also a few others, are worn out and must be replaced at once to prevent the heavy leakage, and so reduce the consumption of gasoline for pumping. New washers alone will not meet the case. I am undertaking to order these also in Vancouver, as they are not obtainable in Whitehorse, and I trust you may see your way clear to support my request that the Department meet the cost of the same.

I understand from the Principal that you undertook to send new radiator valves. These have not yet come to hand, and as they are much needed I hope you may be able to send them at an early date.

Several T joints are required for the radiators which have corroded right through the metal in different places, and are leaking badly. I will order these in Vancouver and ask the Department to meet the cost of the same. The corrosion is undoubtedly due to the action of the well water. To prevent a recurrence of this difficulty I am asking the Department to arrange for the water from the mountain-stream near by to be piped to the school, and also to the Principal's residence. Should they agree to this, the radiators in the school may last for a few years longer. Failing this, it seems to me that it will not be long before complete new heating and water systems will be required.

The chief need of this school is, I consider, modern laundry facilities, and our Commission have included in their list of quitements, to be included in the Departmental estimates for next year, an annex to the main school building which will provide a laundry in the basement, and a chapel or assembly room above it. The lack of a recreation room for the boys is a serious handicap to the school management in many ways, and the provision of the additional space suggested and requested would overcome this. I trust this matter may have your hearty support.

A boat-house, an ice-house, and an implement shed, are also required. I am securing an estimate of the cost of these from a local contractor, and will submit the same to the Department for their consideration.
The question of shortening the road from the school to the town of Carcross, has also been receiving my attention, and I am submitting to the Department estimates for providing a bridge across the arm of the lake in front of the school, or, as an alternative, the cutting of a road around the foot of the hill which encircles this arm. Either improvement would shorten the distance by approximately three-quarters of a mile.

I am submitting to the Department certain recommendations with regard to the lighting system, the drainage system, and the system of irrigation. The difficulty in securing hay and green feed for the stock is quite a serious one, and I am asking the Department to allow a grant of about $500. -- to clear some more ground, and to lay on an irrigation ditch. I am hoping you may, from your expert knowledge of the conditions here, be able to support the applications which are being made for these improvements. I should have liked to have been able to consult you in person with regard to all of the above, but this has been impossible, and I did not feel justified in going to the expense of telegraphing.

I trust that you keep well, and with very kind regards,

Believe me,

Yours very truly,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

Dear Sir:

During my recent visit to our Society's Indian Residential School at Carcross in the Yukon (Nov. 12th to 23rd), I made a careful examination of all the buildings and equipment, and made a note of some of the most urgent requirements. As your representative, Mr. Hawksley, was in Dawson over 500 miles away, I was unable to confer with him personally with regard to these requirements, but I wrote him a letter in this connection and enclosed herewith you will find a copy of the same for your information. The heating, lighting and water systems, for instance, demanded in many particulars, immediate attention, and I placed an order with the Hudson's Bay Co. in Vancouver, immediately after my return to that city for the following items:

- 3 plugs or caps ½ inch
- 2 plugs or caps 1¼ inch
- 16 spring taps for wash bowls
- 8 turn taps for wash bowls
- 1 inner section of a 15 coil radiator 3'6" x 2'3".
  (If the section cannot be secured separately, then send the radiator complete with "T" joint attached.)
- 1 radiator "T" valve 1 inch
- 1 radiator "T" valve handle
- 1 Union, ½ inch -
  - 30 feet ½ inch metal piping
  - 10 elbows ½ inch
  - 1 "T" ½ inch
- All galvanized.
- 50 feet metal piping ½ inch
- 6 caps or plugs ½ inch
- 24 tap washers ½ inch for above taps
- 30 feet (10 ft. lengths) 1½ pipe, 2 Ts.plugs, 3 Elbows

I asked the Hudson's Bay Co. to furnish me with an estimate of the cost of the above items, and they promised to do this immediately, but so far, their estimate has not come to hand.
I was given to understand, however, that as none of the items were very expensive, the total, apart from the freight, would probably not exceed $50.00, and I shall be obliged if, under the circumstances, your Department will pay the bill, including the freight, when it has come to hand. You will note from my letter to Mr. Hawksley that I was informed he had undertaken to send some new radiator valves, but these had not come to hand at the time of my visit. Moreover, when the heating system was put in operation in the late autumn, other serious defects were noted, such as leaking radiators, defective taps, etc., and it was absolutely necessary to have the repairs effected at the earliest moment possible. In your letter of June 1st last #156-1-5, you authorized the expenditure of $100.00 towards the cost of providing a bath room and bath for the staff, and $75.00 for hand washing machines. On my return to Vancouver from the Carcross School, I placed an order for the bath with fixtures, and was informed that the total cost apart from the freight, will not exceed $50.00. As the staff agreed to carry on with the hand washing machines they have at present, in the expectation that a modern laundry and laundry equipment would be provided next year, the expenditure authorized for hand washing machines will not be incurred, and this amount could be applied towards meeting the cost of the items enumerated above.

The freight on the Steamship is not very heavy, even as far as Skagway, but it amounts to a good deal over the 68 miles of the White Pass and Yukon Railway from Skagway to Carcross. I shall be obliged, therefore, if you will authorize me to forward to you the bill from the Hudson's Bay Co. for payment when it comes to hand.

As there were only 26 pupils in residence at the time of my visit, instead of a capacity enrolment of 40 as allowed by your Department, you will readily understand our Society's difficulty in meeting unexpected expenditures of this sort. Immediately after my arrival at Carcross, I wired to Bishop Stringer at Dawson, to ascertain if either he or Mr. Hawksley could undertake to provide more pupils immediately. In his reply which was despatched after he had consulted Mr. Hawkley, the Bishop stated that Mr. Hawksley had authorized the Agent in charge of the Telegraph Creek Agency to recruit 12 pupils for this school, and advised me to get in touch with the Indian Agent at that centre. I immediately wired to Mr. Reed, the Indian Agent there, and in his reply he stated as follows:-
Telegraph Creek B.C. Nov. 16th. 1928

T.W.R. Westgate,
Carcross YT

Your wire first intimation received here too late, transportation impossible, everybody trapping Frank Williams children Jessie and Billy Atlin maybe have wired them letter follows and will send more children later.

Harper Reed, Indian Agent.

It would appear from this telegram that some slight misunderstanding occurred somewhere, and even if the pupils are admitted in the spring, our Society will sustain a very considerable loss in revenue between now and then owing to the comparatively small enrolment. I am furnishing you with this information in the hope that your Department may find it possible to meet the small expenditure which I consider it so necessary to incur before receiving a specific authorization from you direct.

At the time of my visit to this institution, I noted the improvements which had been effected since my last visit, namely, in August, 1926. These included the replacement of the plaster walls of some of the rooms by beaver board, the conversion of the pantry into a staff dining-room and the laying down of a board floor in this room as well as the kitchen. While these improvements add greatly to the staff and pupils, there are still about a dozen rooms with plaster walls and I beg to recommend that these be equipped with beaver board at the earliest date possible. I also beg to recommend that a board floor be placed in the children's dining-room. If the material is provided, the school management can lay the floor in this room.

As the board floor in the girls' recreation room is badly worn, I beg to recommend that a new floor be laid on top of the old one, and the whole covered with linoleum. The linoleum by itself would not be sufficient as the floor is so worn that it would soon wear out.

The chief requirement, however, of this school, in my opinion, is the provision of recreation rooms for both boys and girls and of a fully equipped laundry. As a special note has been made of this in the list of requirements already sent forward to you, for incorporation in your estimates for next year, I do not consider it necessary to make further reference.
to the same in this letter. I beg, however, to direct your attention to the urgent need of an implement shed, a boat house, and also of a house for storing ice. So far as I am aware, none of these buildings have ever been provided for this school, and the school management have been inconvenienced accordingly.

A further need, and one to which I directed the attention of your Department after I visited this school in 1922, was the building of a bridge across the arm of the lake which lies between the school and the town of Carcross. The provision of this bridge would shorten the journey between the school and the town by at least three quarters of a mile, and would eliminate the dangers and fatigue which have now to be encountered in travelling over some steep and difficult hills. Enclosed herewith you will find the original of an estimate which I secured for the construction of this bridge from a local contractor. It is possible, I think, to have a roadway cut around the base of the hill which surrounds this arm of the lake, and although it would not shorten the journey so much between the school and the town, the cost would probably be a little less than the cost of the bridge.

In view of the large number of tourists, many of whom are from the United States, and who visit this school each year during the summer season and make comparisons between our schools and those in their own country, frequently to our discredit, I trust that your Department may find it possible to improve the approach to the school for this reason, as well as for the relief of the school management. Other requirements which were noted and which should receive immediate attention are as follows:

(1) To have all the exposed wires in connection with the lighting system enclosed in metal tubes. It is estimated that approximately 75 yards of tubing will be required for this purpose, as the lighting system has been extended to the barn, the workshop, the Principal's residence, etc., and all should be protected as much as possible against danger from fire.

(2) To have wall switches installed and enclosed in metal cases. At present, there are but a very few of such switches, and in many cases the lights have been placed so high that they cannot be reached without standing on a stool or chair.

(3) To have lights with double sockets and 60 watt bulbs installed as follows, instead of the plain lights which are very hard on the eyes, and are injurious to staff and pupils when the nights are so long during the winter months;—class-room 4; main corridor 1; basement corridor 1; staff dining-room 1; staff sitting-room 1; infirmary 1; office 1; kitchen 2; pupils' dining-room 2.
(4) To have two tables with linoleum tops, each table to be 14' x 3'6", and also eight benches for the same, provided for the pupils' dining-room.

(5) To have a cement floor placed in the furnace room (24' x 16'), also in the room used as a laundry (21'x 16') and in the basement corridor (7'x 55'). Cement can be procured locally and the school management, with a little help, could do the work, if the cement is provided.

(6) To have an asbestos-lined, tin or zinc fire pad (4'x 9') provided to protect the walls in the furnace room nearest the chimney.

(7) To have a new door provided for the furnace (Gurney's #935) with automatic connection with a pressure valve, also an assortment of 1/2" and 3/4" nipples for the furnace boiler.

(8) To have new treads placed on the stairs leading to the basement.

(9) To have battleship linoleum placed on the main corridor and halls leading thereto. The measurements are as follows:- (7'x 43' also 4'x 12'), and (5'x 16') and (4'x 4').

(10) To have a larger water tank installed in the attic. The present tank is only 3' deep by 5' wide and 7' long, and is quite insufficient for storing the school's daily supply of water, or for providing sufficient protection against fire.

(11) To have strong wire protection screens provided for all basement windows (16 size 3'6" x 4') and ½ size for those in the girls' recreation room (4 size 5'x 4'). All these screens should be placed on hinges.

(12) To have a refrigerator provided for the main school building. There is none there at present and so far as I know there never has been one.

(13) To have paint provided for the Principal's residence and the workshop, and creosote for the roof and walls of the stock barn.

(14) To have 2 Fahrenheit thermometers provided, also 2 wall clocks for use in the main school building.

(15) To have the drainage system thoroughly overhauled and placed for all time on a satisfactory basis. I was informed that only 3" piping was laid down between the school and the septic tank. This should be replaced by 5" or 6" piping, as the
present system is frequently blocked and gives the school management unnecessary labour and annoyance.

(16) To have the fire hose installed in the girls clothes-room brought out to the two end corridors, as the clothes-room must be kept locked and any delay in opening it in an emergency might have serious consequences. Some piping with the necessary connection and an additional hose would be required to do this.

(17) To have a filing cabinet provided for the Principal's office.

(18) To have a railing placed on both ends of the front door steps which are frequently so icy in winter that they cannot be used with any degree of safety.

(19) To have 15 mattresses supplied for the beds in the boys' dormitory to take the place of the palliasses now in use, also 2 dozen pillows. Where hay is so difficult to obtain, it is impossible for the school management to keep the palliasses properly filled, and I am convinced that the mattresses are an absolute necessity.

(20) To have approximately five acres of land cleared along the arm of the lake in front of the school for farm and garden purposes. This land could be cleared, and made ready for cultivation for a sum of about $500.00. As it could easily be irrigated if piping were provided, it would be a great help to the school management in solving the difficult problem of securing the necessary vegetables for the school and the green feed and fodder for the stock.

The above items may appear to your Department to be very numerous, but I trust that you may also see that they are very necessary, and take immediate steps to provide them. On my recommendation, our Commission and the Dorcas Sec.-Treas. of our W.A. have already undertaken to supply various other needs amounting to a very considerable sum of money. They have not found it easy to do this but they have made a special effort to meet every essential requirement, and are doing this to the full limit of their power. I trust, therefore, that your Department may be able to provide the various items I have mentioned.

While dealing with the needs of this institution, I further beg to recommend that careful consideration be given by your Department to the possibility of making greater use of the water power which is available. Summer and winter there is a stream of water flowing through the school grounds, capable of developing at all seasons of the year not less than 75 H.P. and in the summer season double that amount. If a dam, approximately 100' long,
35' deep were thrown across this stream at a place where it enters the gorge, and only about 300' from the school, a small turbine could be operated which would furnish all the power required to light the school, and even the neighbouring town of Carcross, if necessary. It would also afford all the fire protection necessary, and provide an abundance of water for the school's daily use, as well as irrigating the farm and garden. The cost would not be prohibitive, and the benefits to be derived would abundantly justify the same. I learned from missionaries of the American Church in Alaska that they have made use of Hydro-Electric power in connection with a number of their Indian Schools in that country. I also examined the Hydro-Electric system installed at Skagway in Alaska, and am convinced that the same could be done at our Carcross School. I commend this important matter, therefore, to your careful consideration, and would recommend that provision be made in your estimates for next year to meet this undertaking. But whether the suggestion I have made be vigorously taken up and put through, as I earnestly hope it may, I desire to make it quite clear that the school's supply of water, for daily consumption, should be drawn from the stream instead of from the well as at present. The corrosion which is taking place in the boiler and radiators and heating system, will soon necessitate complete new heating plant.

If the Hydro-Electric power which is now going to waste is not utilized, then, I see no reason, why a large reservoir made of cement should not be constructed close to the main school building, and water laid on to the same from the stream close by by gravitation. This, of course, would not eliminate the daily process of pumping from that reservoir to the tank in the attic of the school, a process which would not be necessary if the dam were constructed. I see no reason, either, why the water from the stream should not be conducted by pipes to all the land between the main school building and the arm of the lake in front, as well as to the Principal's residence. The cost would not be very much as only about 400 yards of 2" piping would be sufficient for the whole system, and I shall be glad to know if your Department will come to the assistance of the Society by helping to solve the numerous problems with which they are confronted in the administration of this school, by supplying all the improvements I have enumerated above and thus help to make the work which we are both so deeply interested at this important centre, a credit to all the parties concerned.

With the compliments of the season, I remain, Sir,

Yours very truly,

Rev & Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of yours of 21st ultimo, dealing with what you consider the requirements of the Carcross Indian Residential School and stating that you propose submitting the same to the Department of Indian Affairs.

In reply I beg to say in reference to the new taps needed in the various rooms, the principal had already sent in a requisition for these steps being taken to secure these as I consider that they are badly needed. As you are ordering the taps in Vancouver I am taking no further steps in the matter. Will recommend payment if called upon to do so.

New valves for the radiators were ordered by me from M. Watson of Carcross; the Principal was asked to get these and install them where required.

After my visit to the school last June in my report to the Department written on July 7th, I called attention to the need of modern laundry equipment and a recreation for the boys. It is hoped that these items may be included in the estimates for the coming year. I have the figures on a suitable equipment also the shipping weight.

Referring to the implement shed, I consider there is room in the barn for all the implements owned by the school. I sometimes wonder why it is not used for this purpose. I have seldom seen them housed there.

The question of shortening the road from the school to the town of Carcross was taken up some years ago. A bridge across the lagoon was proposed and an estimate of the cost of lumber and construction was obtained ($4200.00) being the lowest estimate submitted. It was considered that the limited amount of traffic between the school and the town did not warrant such a large outlay. A road round the foot of the bluff was then suggested. I sent in a tentative plan of the road but when a personal inspection was made of the location it was found to be impracticable except at a heavy cost. You may have noticed that for quite a distance the bluff is almost perpendicular which would entail the removal of an enormous amount of earth before a satisfactory
road could be made. Both these plans were dropped. It was felt that there was no urgent need for these costly undertakings the amount of traffic being so slight. The conditions are about the same now. Some grading done on the trail that goes up the hill just beyond the barn would be a material help to make the road easier for anyone walking over it. There is usually a bridge of ice across the lagoon from November to April.

As to piping the water from the creek nearby to the school and the Principal's residence, what do you propose to do in the winter when the creek is frozen to its bed and should there be a supply of running water in the creek what plan have you for keeping the water from freezing in the pipes. I have not the slightest hesitation in saying that I consider this neither feasible or practical.

With reference to the grant of $500.00 that you propose asking the Department to make for clearing more land, I am wondering where you propose clearing. My knowledge of the place, having lived there for three years, and frequently visited it since, leads me to the conclusion that it is not worth while clearing any more of the land surrounding the school, it is valueless for the purpose of cultivation. The Anderson field, which adjoins the school land, was properly cleared and fenced in and a great deal of time and labour spent to make it productive but proved a total failure it produced practically nothing. The field now used as a golf links and the plot of land on the opposite side of the school to the Anderson field were cleared by Mr Simmons, a windmill was erected upon it for the purpose of pumping water for irrigation, these two plots did not produce enough to feed his family. All three of the above mentioned fields have long since been abandoned. The land that was cleared last year for which the Department paid $200.00 did not produce anything although much time and labour was spent upon it. For two years an effort was made to grow green feed at the school the result was almost nil. I believe that more intensive cultivation of the land that is now cleared would be more beneficial than getting larger spaces that with your limited staff cannot receive the attention needed. Three hundred bushels of potatoes have been produced from a smaller plot of ground than was planted last season which produced only 23 bushels. I do not think it worth while to clear more of the land round the school as I fell convinced that it is unproductive.

Under the circumstances, the difficulty of getting hay and green feed, it would appear that there are too many animals to care for, 4 cows, 2 calves, 1 bull and a horse. Two cows would, I think, be sufficient to supply all the milk required. If your idea is to carry on productive farming with a view to producing revenue I fear you will be disappointed. There is no market for
the produce in the vicinity.

May I suggest that it might be a wise plan to either lease or buy some of the hay land at Ten Mile Point, this is about the only place in the vicinity of the school where hay is obtainable.

The need of a chapel at an institution the size of Carcross school, in my opinion, is neither urgent or necessary.

You do not state the nature of the recommendations you are submitting to the Department regarding the lighting system, the drainage system and the plan for irrigation. It is noted that you express a hope that I will support these schemes. It is only fair to say that I cannot very well pledge myself to support any scheme the details of which I know nothing at all.

A new floor is badly needed in the pupils dining room, and a further grant for continuing the work of removing the plaster and replacing it with beaver board in the rooms upstairs, lumber for making necessary repairs and a supply of paint for painting the beaver board are all urgently needed and for which I am on the point of sending a requisition to the Department.

Your obedient servant,

John Hawksley.
Indian Superintendent.

Sir:-

A letter from Dr. T.F.R. Westgate recently received contains rather a long list of what he deems the needs of the Carcross Indian Residential School, asking me to support his appeal to the Department.

The need of modern laundry equipment and a recreation room for the boys was brought to the notice of the Department in my latter of July 7th. A new floor is required for the pupils dining room, a further sum of money for completing the work of removing the plaster and replacing it with beaver board on the walls of the upstairs rooms, and a supply of paint or calcomine for the walls that have already been done.

The plan of piping the water from the creek to the school is not worth considering; it would be expensive and would be useful during our short summer. The creek usually freezes solid in the winter. The reason stated that the well water is responsible for the corrosion of the radiator pipes is a fallacy. It is common knowledge in the engineering trade that distilled water is destructive to metal, about seven years is considered the average length of time a metal pipe will last that is used for conveying water that has been through the boiler. The water from the creek would have to pass through the boiler before it could be used for heating purposes therefore the conditions would be the same as the use of water from the well.

A copy of my reply to Dr. Westgate is enclosed herewith which will give the Department my views on what he considers the needs of the school.

Your obedient servant,

J.D. McLean, Esq.
Acting Deputy and Secretary.

Sir:-

I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of January 2nd, file No 166-1-5, in reference to Dr Westgate's letter concerning the needs of the Carcross Indian Residential School with a copy of your reply to him enclosed.

In reply I beg to say that I am enclosing a report on the items enumerated in your letter, I am not able to roughly estimate the cost of each item. It would take some time to get in touch with various firms to obtain prices, to avoid delay I am sending a fairly conservative estimate of the cost of the whole of the proposed work.

In view of the fact that there are no skilled workmen in the small town of Carcross men would have to be brought from Whitehorse, and that all the required material would have to be brought from Vancouver, that freight charges and wages are high, my own estimate for carrying out all the items mentioned is from $15,000 to $20,000 inclusive.

Referring to the suggestion of the Department taking advantage of the water power available near the school. Some years ago I discussed this matter with a practical engineer who definitely said the scheme was not practical. The creek freezes almost solid to its bed during the winter, it is only a shallow stream. If the school was dependent upon the water power to supply its needs they would be without power or at least water from November until April. Dr Westgate has not seen this creek in midwinter.

You may have received a copy of my reply to a letter sent here by Dr Westgate, which was forwarded to the Department. From that you will gather my views on the question of clearing more land and the construction of a road between the school and the town of Carcross.

May I suggest that instead of supplying paint for the Principal's residence, that a supply be provided for painting the beaver board already in place on the interior walls of the school.

Your obedient servant,

Report and Recommendations on the Items Enumerated in Letter.

No.1. Beaver boarding those rooms now plastered.
This is a very necessary improvement, the cost of doing all the rooms and the corridor would be from $1000.00 to $1500.00, as near as I can estimate without getting prices from contractors.

No.2. Conversion of pantry into staff dining room.
This work was carried out last year.

No.3. New flooring for the above mentioned room and in the kitchen.
New floors were put in both these rooms last year.

No.4. New flooring for children's dining room.
This is really needed, the cost would be about $250.00 for the material and labor.

No.5. Flooring for sewing room and a linoleum covering.
This floor needs renewing and would cost say $150.00. Varnishing the new floor would be more sanitary than linoleum, dust and germs are likely to accumulate under linoleum, the cost would be from $2.50 to $3.00 per square yard. I do not know the size of the room.

No.6. An implement shed.
I do not consider that this is needed, there is room in the barn for the few implements owned by the school.

No.7. A boat house.
There is only one boat. I would suggest that if a house is desired, the staff at the school should, with the help of the boys, build this. It would be good training in manual work for the boys.

No.8. An ice house.
There is, or was, an ice house at the back of the school. If still in existence it may probably need some repairs.

No.9. Enclosing all exposed electric wires in metal tubes.
I do not consider this essential, it would be rather expensive.

No.10. To install wall switches and enclose in metal cases.
Undoubtedly this would be very convenient but by no means essential. An electrician would have to be brought from Whitehorse and in addition to the material used his charges for labor would be $10.00 per day from the time he left Whitehorse until the day he returned.

No.11. Drop lights with better bulbs in main rooms and the corridors.
I would suggest that 100 watt frosted bulbs and 60 watt bulbs
the latter for use in rooms and corridors and the former in
the schoolroom and office. Drop lights with the size of bulbs
that these would entail would possibly put too great a strain
on the electric plant.

NO.12. Two new tables and 8 benches for the pupils dining
room.
This is a much needed requirement.

NO.13. Cement floor in furnace room, present laundry and
basement corridor.
The concrete floor in the above mentioned places is much worn,
a good coating of cement over them would meet the needs.

NO.14. Asbestos lined zinc pad to protect the walls in the
furnace room nearest the chimney.
This is not necessary. If the plaster is taken off the wall
"Gyproc" instead of beaver board could be put on this wall
instead of beaver board. It is non-inflammable and costs about
the same as beaver board.

NO.15. New door for furnace with automatic connection with
a pressure valve and nipples for furnace boiler.
It is presumed that the door that closes the draught is what
is meant in this case, probably this is broken and needs a new
one. There is a pressure valve on top of the boiler, I suppose
that a chain and weight to connect the door with the valve.
This valve blows off at a pressure of 3 lbs of steam, the usual
pressure required to heat the school in cold weather. When I was
at the school last fall there was a chain and weight attached
to the valve and the door. If this is broken then a
renewal is essential. The old chain and weight might be used
if it can be found. I do not understand what the nipples are
that are said to be required for the boiler.

NO.16. New treads on basement stairs.
These do require renewing, they should be of B.C. red fir, native
lumber is not sufficiently hard for this purpose.

NO.17. Linoleum for main corridor and halls leading thereto.
This is quite unnecessary. All that is needed is the floors
revarnishing.

NO.18. Larger water tank in the attic.
The present tank holds 400 gallons when full which means a net
weight of two tons in addition to the lead lined tank. A larger
tank would mean extra weight. I do not consider it advisable to
increase the weight, it might have some effect on the building. The tank can be filled in less than 10 minutes with the power pump they now have at the school. It would be an expensive item to put in a larger tank and I do not think it is really needed.

No. 19. Wire screens on hinges for the basement windows. Material was supplied last year by the Department for the purpose of making screens for all the windows in the building and the doors. These were made at the school. It would not be difficult for them to put hinges on these screens if required. I do not see why they need hinges as the basement windows all open inwards.

No. 20. Refrigerator. This is not a necessity. The well house is a cool place and has been used as a refrigerator in the past. For about seven months out of the twelve our difficulty is to keep things from freezing. We have a natural refrigerator in the north.

No. 21. Paint for the Principal's residence. This building is not the property of the Indian Department. It was purchased from the Diocese of Yukon by Dr Westgate. My idea is that it is up to the Indian and Eskimo School Commission to take care of their own property. The workshop was painted two years ago; it does not require repainting.

No. 22. Cresote for the exterior walls and roof of stock barn. Cresote for the exterior walls of the barn is needed, the roof is corrugated iron and does not need anything.

No. 23. Overhauling drainage system and enlarging pipe between school and septic tank. There appears to be no need to overhaul the drainage system; it was working satisfactorily when I was at the school. The pipe leading from the school to the septic tank is earthenware 6 inch pipes, quite large enough to carry off the drainage. Four inch pipes are in use in all the large buildings in Dawson including the school with some 100 pupils and the Hostel with with as many pupils as the Carcross school these pipes have and are giving satisfaction. The danger of larger pipes lies in this, the fall or grade from the school to the tank is not deep. If a larger pipe is put in the drainage from the school, which is not very great in volume, would spread out and become shallower in the pipe and the flow move slowly thus allowing the solid matter to settle in the bottom of the pipe and choke up the drain. I do consider it advisable to change the size of the pipe.

No. 24. Filing cabinet for Principal's office. This would be useful but is not necessary.

No. 25. Railing for front door steps.
This seems to be unnecessary, the steps are wide with plenty of room, the pupils do not use this entrance, the staff use the side entrances much more than the front it is not worth while to incur this expenditure.

No.26. 15 mattresses and 24 pillows for boys dormitory. Until some account is given of the use made of the 40 mattress cases shipped to the school by the Department some two or three years ago I would hesitate to give a further supply. These cases or bed ticks were made of good strong ticking in suitable size for single cots, they were to be filled with hay at the school. The idea in following this plan was because some of the pupils are troubled with incontinence especially when asleep, the hay could easily be removed when soiled and the ticking washed and refilled. Unless there is some improvement in the pupils in this particular the mattresses would soon be ruined. Pillows are needed.

Regarding the fire hose in the girl's clothes room I would rather defer any action until I visit the school in spring. I do not feel quite sure that this can be done and get efficient service from the hose.

Dawson.Y.T.
January 31st, 1930.

Sir:-

I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your letter dated March 8th, file No 166-1-5, in reference to the proposed improvements at the Carcross Indian Residential School.

In reply I beg to say that the following items are considered to be the most urgent requirements. Laundry equipment consisting of Washing Machine, Extractor, the necessary pulleys shafting and belts and a gasoline engine to operate these. There is a fine washing plant at the Hostel here, a similar plant would fully meet the needs of the Carcross school. I would suggest that the machinery be installed in the room in the basement now used as a laundry and play room for the boys. Enamel wash tubs are fixed to the walls connected with the drain, hot and cold water taps are over each tub. The cost of the plant would be approximately $2500.00.

A Recreation Room for the boys, to be erected at the back of the school. A one story building would affect only one window of the first floor, if a two storey structure is erected it will affect the dormitory windows unless built as a separate unit which would mean a separate heating plant.

The plaster remaining on the walls of one of the hospital wards, the basement corridor and several rooms on the upper floor, be removed and replaced with beaver board and all the beaver boarding that has been done be either painted or calcomined.

A new boarded floor in the pupils dining room. The concrete floors in the basement to be faced with a layer of cement. New treads on the stairs leading from the basement to the first floor. The wood shed lined with two inch rough planking and new treads on the stairs leading to the yard. New flooring in the stalls of the barn. All these should be done with imported lumber, preferably B.C. red fir, native lumber is too soft and wears out quickly.
Have written to the principal asking that he be good enough to send a sketch of what he would suggest for the proposed improvements, and to give dimensions of the rooms and height of the building that he may think is needed, also to what part of the present building he would suggest the addition to be made. I do not know what plans he has in mind.

The work could be done by day work under the supervision of a competent carpenter. May I suggest that I believe the better plan would be to give the work to one of the firms in Whitehorse. There are no skilled carpenters in Carcross. Either one of the firms in Whitehorse would supply the materials and the labour and would work by the day.

It will be quite three weeks before I hear from the Principal, his plans and suggestions will be forwarded promptly upon receipt.

Your obedient servant,

John Hawksley,
Indian Superintendent.

Dear Sir:

The Principal of our Carcross School in the Yukon has forwarded to me for any further action necessary, the following request which he had received from Mr. Indian Supt. Hawkesley of Dawson:

"Will you please be good enough to send a rough plan giving your ideas on the proposed addition to the school, giving length, width and height of rooms desired. The matter is urgent, please send the plan as soon as possible upon receipt of this letter."

On page 3 of my letter addressed to you on Dec. 16 last, you will note that after my visit to this school last autumn, I pointed out that its chief requirement, in my opinion, was the provision of recreation rooms for both boys and girls and of a fully equipped laundry. I assume, therefore, that Mr. Hawkesley's request is in connection with this requirement.

At the present time, the school is without a recreation room for either the boys or the girls. The boys make use of the place in the basement where the laundry work is done, and the girls make use of the room on the first floor which is intended for a sewing room. Where the winters are so long this arrangement is very trying for both staff and pupils. Further, there is no chapel or assembly room, and up to the present, either the class-room or the children's refectory have to be used for this purpose. This again, is not at all satisfactory.
On each occasion when I have visited this school, I have looked carefully into the matter, and reached the conclusion that the only satisfactory way to meet the need I have indicated, would be to either (1) add to the length of the main school building on the end shown in the enclosed photograph, by approximately 20', or (2) to build a semi-detached room approximately 50' x 30' at the corner I have indicated in rough tracing. The objection to the first method is the difficulty which presents through the exclusion of light from the rooms inside the windows shown. This appears to be insuperable. By adopting the second method, the window marked (1) could be converted into a doorway into the basement of the proposed addition which would serve as a laundry, and the window marked (2) on the first floor could also be converted into a doorway into the chapel or assembly room. If the added building were given another storey, this storey could be used as a sewing room, and in this way all the accommodation required would be provided. I was informed that the present heating plant would be sufficient to heat the extension, but I myself have some doubt in this connection. I am of the opinion, that the added building should be in line with the main school building, and not at right angles to it running out towards the rear. From the photograph you will observe that there is an embankment about 30 ft. from the rear side of the main school building, and if the extension were built in that direction it might inconvenience the school management in the matter of conveying the wood to the furnace room. The cost in each case would be about the same.

The depth of the basement below the bottom of the windows shown on the ground level in the photo is approximately 6'. There is sufficient field for good drainage down to the lake in front of the school.

I am sending a copy of this letter to Mr. Indian Supt. Hawkesley and another copy to the Principal of the School, but if there is any further information which I may be able to give you in this connection, I shall gladly furnish the same on receipt of your request.

Believe me, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

You will recall that on page 6 of my letter of December 16th last, I recommended that careful consideration be given by your Department to the possibility of making greater use of the water power which is available within 300 yds. of our Carcross School. The Principal secured a water wheel and has installed the same at the dam, and this is now being used to pump water across the garden near the School. In his telegram dated June 12th, he requests that the following equipment be supplied immediately:

3 whirling sprays at $2.00 each.

Sir:

I wish to refer to your letters, No. 2335-5 of April 5th and January 31st, last, concerning improvements at the Carcross Indian Residential School. In view of the various minor improvements, some of which are quite costly, the Department has been forced to postpone the erection of the proposed addition. In any case, the correspondence with your office and with the church authorities leaves the Department somewhat in doubt as to what rooms should be provided in the new addition. You recommend that the laundry be continued in the basement of the present building. Dr. Westgate is of the opinion that it might be well to include the laundry in the new building. It is agreed that recreation rooms for both boys and girls are needed in the new building. The church officers are asking that a chapel or assembly room be provided. During the next few months, it is desired that the Rev. Principal and yourself, representing the Church and the Department, prepare a joint recommendation concerning the uses to which the new building should be put and prepare a rough sketch, indicating the best position for it. Your joint recommendation and report could then be reviewed by the Department Architect. I shall take steps to see that Parliament is asked to provide funds for the addition next year.

At the present time, funds can be found for the other improvements, and I have to authorize you to make arrangements to supply and install laundry machinery, recommended in your letter of April 5th, last, at an approximate cost of $2,500. The plaster remaining on the main building should be removed and replaced with beaver board and all the beaver board painted or calcimined. A new floor may be laid in the children's dining room and in the sewing room. The new floor in the sewing room should be varnished. The Department does not consider linoleum necessary. Reverend Sir:

I wish to refer to your letter of the 13th ultimo, with reference to the proposed addition and the other improvements at the Carcross Indian Residential School. Mr. Hawksley's recommendations regarding improvements other than the addition are so extensive and in some cases so costly, that the Department is forced, because of lack of funds, to postpone the addition until Parliament provides additional funds.
