Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of June 18th last, enclosing a copy of your letter of the same date to Mr. Hawksley, authorizing an expenditure on improvements at the Carcross school of over $6,000.00, and requesting me to notify you of any other really urgent improvements not enumerated in your letter to Mr. Hawksley, I beg to state that in a letter just received from Deaconess Topping who is filling the position of Acting Principal of this school until a permanent appointment to this position has been made, has directed the attention of our Commission to a number of requirements, all of which she considers very urgent. The following is an extract from her letter addressed to our Commission on Sept. 3rd last:

"Needs of building. The carpenters arrived today and started on repairs, beaver-boarding etc. Among the things I note, is need of locks and keys for all outside doors. I do not feel safe without some way of locking up nights. A great deal of glass is needed. About 60 panes of different sizes; may have to order some before hearing from you, as weather is turning very cold now. No clock in the building is going, can we have one or two? If we could have a linoleum rug for dining room (staff) and some paint, it would save that floor. Also kitchen needs linoleum in centre. If we had some paint and varnish believe Mr. Ginn and the boys could help fix up staff rooms unless the department are doing it in their contract. We need for staff rooms, blinds, rugs, at least one comfortable chair, some white enamel paint for beds. The children's beds need painting, but so many springs are broken, no good, seems a waste of paint to touch them. Need some new furniture for..."
infirmary, room is empty at present, and if illness came have no place to isolate a child. A rummer on main hall, would save both floor and labor, if one to wax. Staff need some new furniture for sitting room especially chairs."

It has occurred to me that Mr. Hawksley might find it possible to provide many of the requirements mentioned by the Deaconess out of the grant you have already sanctioned. He would not, of course, feel free to take such action without an authorization from you, and I shall be obliged if you will furnish him with this at your earliest convenience.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

Sir:-

I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your letter dated October 9th, file No. 166-1-5, in reference to the improvements at the Carcross Indian Residential School.

In reply I beg to say that when I was visiting the school in September enquiries were made about the broken windows, I was informed that the necessary glass for repairs had been ordered and was expected any time. I note that you authorize the purchase of 80 panes of glass. Am I to understand that these 80 panes are to be purchased over and above the glass that the Church authorities were sending to the school?

All the doors and locks were examined by me, after noting the condition of them instructions were given to the foreman carpenter to make the necessary repairs, and where necessary, to put in new locks and keys and handles. You will find an account for these along with other accounts that I am forwarding to the Department.

As already reported, paints, etc., have already been purchased and the account forwarded. In view of the large amount of painting to be done and the school understaffed, it was considered advisable to engage the services of a painter to do the work before the new wood and beaver board became soiled. The greater part of the interior of the institution had to be done and only one man on the staff, with his other duties it would have taken a very long time to do the painting and floor varnishing. I am hoping the Department will approve the action taken.

Regarding the furnishings I am asking the Acting Principal what is most urgently needed, the size and number of cots required and the size of the blinds and number wanted. These things will be ordered as soon as I hear from the school, keeping in view the amount appropriated for this purpose.

Your obedient servant,

John Hawksley.

A.F. Mackenzie, Esq.
Secretary.

Dear Sir:

Re - Addition to Carcross School.

With further reference to my letter of May 13th, 1930, and your reply to the same on June 18th, 1930, relative to an addition to our Carcross school, I beg to state that in a letter just received from the Principal he informs me that Mr. Simpson, a contractor at Whitehorse, was instructed by Mr. Indian Superintendent Hawksley to visit the school and to submit two plans - one for an annex to the main school building, and the other for a detached building to be used solely for a recreation room for the boys and girls. The Principal states that a detached building to serve merely as a combined recreation room for boys and girls would not meet the needs of the case, and I fully agree with him.

The Principal also states that Mr. Simpson favours the building of a three story annex to the main school building at the rear corner of the building, and extending in the direction of the work-shop. The annex will be 23' wide, and at least 24' long, (I think it should be at least 30' long). This building could be heated from the central heating plant, by adding one or more units to that plant. The plant is such that this can easily be done. The full sized basement of the annex could be used as a boys recreation room with an outside entrance, as well as with an inside entrance through the laundry. The window in the basement of the room used as a laundry at present, could easily be converted into a doorway.

The first floor above the basement could be used as a chapel and auditorium, entrance to the same being through a small room used as a mending room.

The third story could be used as a dormitory for the younger children.
Mr. Simpson is of the opinion that the only alternative to this plan of providing the additional space required would be to extend the whole of one end of the main school building. To do this one end of the building would have to be taken out completely, and the cost would be a great deal more than if the annex were built as suggested above. It would also spoil the symmetry of the building, unless an extension were made at the other end as well. If an appropriation is available to extend the building at both ends the plan is worthy of careful consideration. If funds are not available I would strongly recommend that the three story annex at the corner be built. A detached building, without a basement, to be heated by stoves and to serve as a combined recreation room for both boys and girls as suggested by Mr. Indian Superintendent Hawksley will not, I trust, be seriously considered by your Department.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Rev. and Dear Sir:-

Acting on instructions received in your letter dated Dec. 19th. 1930 Mr. Rose, Machinist, of this town was urged to get to work and instal the new laundry equipment. This has been done and it is now in operation. Statements in triplicate showing the cost are enclosed. In order to connect up the washer with the hot and cold water system in the school certain pipe fittings were necessary; others were needed in order to connect up the overflow from the washer and extractor with the sewerage system and pipe fittings were also needed for the exhaust on the engine. I may say that no pipe fittings were sent in with the machinery and it was necessary for Mr. Rose to obtain them locally. In many cases they were hard to get and it was necessary for him to spend a certain amount of time locating what was needed. I feel sure that when you see the work you will, like myself be very satisfied with what has been done. Mr. Rose was instructed to put a pipe railing up in order to keep the children away from the moving belts. The pipe for this purpose was found at the school with the exception of a 12' length and 4 - 1" flanges. I trust that the putting up of this safeguard will meet with your approval.

The enclosed letter indicates that the Teacher here is sending out report cards to the parents on the children's progress in school. It also shows that the parents appreciate hearing regularly from their children whilst at school. As stated in a previous letter the evening of the 2nd. Tuesday in each month is set apart for letter writing.
We were pleased to have a visit from Bishop Stringer. He arrived here on Jan. 28th, 1931 and stayed until Feb 2nd, 1931. Whilst he was here we conducted our February Fire Drill. The children were in bed when the bell rang and the time it took them to get out of the building was as follows:

Boys, 3 minutes
Girls, 4 minutes.

Physical Drill Classes for the boys and girls are in full swing. We are however, somewhat restricted in what we can do through lack of equipment such as boxing gloves, dumb-bells, Indian Clubs etc. It would be much appreciated if your Department could do something to supply this need. Personally I am a great advocate for Physical Drill for Indian children and I feel that anything done along that line is of great benefit to the scholars.

Trusting that you will give the matters in this letter your usual considerate attention,

I remain,

Yours respectfully,

A.C. Grant
Principal.

I have the honor to enclose herewith vouchers from Matthew Watson of Carcross, Y.T. for window glass and labor and material used in installing the new kitchen range at the Carcross Indian Residential School.

Sir:—

A report has just come to hand from the Carcross Indian Residential School which states that on December 13th, when the Principal was starting the pumping engine situated in the basement of the school, it burst into flames, the gasoline in the tank apparently becoming ignited by the backfiring of the engine. For a time it looked as though a very serious fire would result. Fortunately the fire started in the afternoon, it only took one and a half minutes to get all the children out of the school. After all were removed to a place of safety attention was given to fighting the fire which was then burning fiercely, it looked as though the gasoline tank would explode any minute. However, by means of one of our Gardene fire extinguishers, the fire was got under control with practically no damage done to either the engine or the building.

The next morning the Principal and the Farm Instructor made some alterations on the gasoline tank which will prevent a similar occurrence in the future. These alterations consisted in placing the opening through which the gasoline tank is filled in a more accessible place and fitting this opening with a suitable plug. In the past we had some difficulty in filling the tank and, no matter how careful one was, a certain amount of gas would run over and the danger of it igniting from a backfire was considerable as we now realize.

It is gratifying to us as I know it will be to you to know that the damage caused is negligible and that the pumping plant is working very satisfactorily.

Your obedient servant,

John Hawksley,
Indian Superintendent.

Rev. Sir:-

Enclosed you will find our Quarterly Return for the last Quarter in 1931. We trust that you will find it in order.

During your visit to the school last fall certain items of equipment were discussed as being essential to our work here and it was decided that such were to be applied for to the Department through you early in 1932. We do trust that you will do all in your power to urge the Department to supply our needs and that allowance will be made for them when the estimates go before Parliament. They are as follows:-

One 14X15 Horse Power Hay Press. In a letter recently received from the McCormick Deering Farm Implement Co., 1905 Main St., Vancouver B.C. we are informed that this hay press would cost $626.00 F.O.B. Carcross. If this press is equipped with a self feed attachment $60.00 must be added to the above price. Whilst such a self feed would be useful yet it is not essential. The main thing is the hay press. If we had one of these items of equipment I feel sure that we would have no trouble in obtaining sufficient hay for our needs each year. As you know there is very little hay close to the school and to endeavour to bring loose hay any distance takes a great deal of time and is very wasteful. We do trust that you will regard this hay press as one of our prior needs.

Dental Work on the Children's Teeth. Last year a grant of $100.00 was made in this connection. We trust that a similar grant can be made for 1932 or even better for the Department to enter into a contract with Dr. Williams for a period of three years at $150.00 a year. Under such a contract Dr. Williams would visit the school twice each year and do all necessary dental work. The $100.00 grant made last year was not sufficient to permit the dentist to do all
the work that should have been done.

A Ram to be installed in the Creek. I cannot give you much information concerning this but I believe that Mr. C.F. Johnson of Dawson in the past went into the matter carefully and can supply all the necessary particulars.

Of the above three requirements we would ask you to give the purchase of a hay press priority. As you know the Commission are supplying us with another horse and consequently more hay will be needed next winter than this. The problem of getting hay home, which has to be cut some distance from the school, will be solved if we are fortunate enough to obtain a hay press.

Feeling sure that you will do all you can for us regarding the above,

I remain,

Yours respectfully,

H.C.M. Grant.
Principal.

Sir:-

I have the honor to enclose herewith vouchers for the charges in connection with the overhauling and repairs to the Delco lighting plant at the Carcross Indian Residential School.

The principal reports that when the engine was taken down all the parts were carefully examined and some were found to be badly worn and had to be replaced; these new parts had to be purchased in Vancouver from the Delco Agents.

While the work of overhauling the engine was in progress it was noted that the wall of the cylinder was cracked. Fortunately this crack has not become serious enough to put the engine out of commission. It is only a matter of time before this crack will penetrate and cause an opening in the cylinder wall. It was also noted that the wall of the cylinder was badly scored which causes a low compression.

The principal goes on to say that acting on the advice of the engineer, Mr Rose, he has ordered a new cylinder from Vancouver. Mr Rose will put the new cylinder in without further charge.

These repairs were both urgent and necessary and he expresses the hope that the Department will approve of what has been done.

Dear Sir:

Your letter of December 5th received regarding the cracked and scored cylinder on your 3 K.W. Delco plant. The piston pin is of the full floating type and should have aluminum buttons on each end to eliminate the condition you mention.

Regarding the installation of a new cylinder, we do not believe that this would be very satisfactory without the installation of a new wrist pin and piston, as there is bound to be considerable wear. Your present piston would make a poor fit in your cylinder and cause you considerable difficulty with oil pumping etc.

We are therefore taking the liberty of shipping you a rebored cylinder, new piston and rings, cylinder head and cylinder base gaskets.

These parts are all fitted and we are supplying them to you for $39.50 f.o.b. Vancouver. We believe you will find this a very satisfactory and reasonable replacement, as a new cylinder lists $37.50, piston $15.00, 3 rings - $1.00, Piston pin - $3.25 head gasket - 25¢ and base gasket 15¢, making a total of $57.10 f.o.b. Vancouver.

You will, therefore, note that we are making the entire replacement for only $2.00 more than the cost of a new cylinder. To make this replacement it is necessary for us to ask you to return your used cylinder as it would be necessary for us to have this re-operated to make us another replacement assembly.

The return of this cylinder, of course, depends on whether the crack you mentioned is on the surface only or into the cylinder walls. Should this crack be in the cylinder wall itself the cylinder will be of no further value, and we would ask you to scrap it.

(Signed) G.W. Hambling - Sales Manager.

Dear Sir:-

Batteries for Lighting Plant at Carcross School.

Writing on the 10th instant, the Rev. Principal Grant of our Carcross School in the Yukon, directs the attention of our Commission to the need of new batteries for the lighting plant at this institution, and I have been instructed to refer this urgent need to your Department for consideration and the necessary action. In his letter the Principal states that the school records show the present batteries were installed in the Spring of 1929. As batteries do not usually last beyond four years, it seems to our Commission that the time has fully come when a new set is required, and they sincerely hope you may be able to provide them. The Principal's requisition for gasoline for the current quarter is 10 cases above the average, and he states that at the present rate of consumption (Nov. 10th) an extra 20 cases will be required "to see us through to the end of the year". As "the ammeter shows that the generator is generating at its usual rate", he is convinced that the batteries are nearly worn out, and should be replaced. He is being instructed by our Commission to reduce the load as much as possible, but our Commission greatly hope you may be able to supply new batteries at an early date, as they consider it would be a serious matter for a school so remotely situated to be left without light during the long, dark nights of winter.

Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

Dear Sir:-

Colonel Mermagen, Assistant Secretary-Treasurer of our Commission has recently returned from a visit to the Carcross School and has furnished a very satisfactory and encouraging report on the work being accomplished by this institution. In his report he embodied a list of urgent requirements, and our Commission at a meeting held on the 18th instant authorized a very considerable expenditure on behalf of the Principal's residence for such items as linoleum with under-felt; steel bath tub; stove, etc. They also authorized an expenditure of $125.00 for heavy bob sleighs for use next winter. The equipment which our Commission felt your Department should supply is as follows:

- 2 new beds; 21 new bed springs; 45 mattresses;
- 2 Singer sewing machines, and 1 hay press.

While writing about the requirements of the Carcross School, I may say that there are many similar requirements at all our schools, most of which have been embodied in the comprehensive list sent to your Department last October, and our Commission thought it would save a great deal of correspondence and enable them to carry out improvements during the summer months if they were informed of the amount of the grant which would be available for each school, and they were authorized to incur the necessary expenditure up to the amount authorized on the most urgent improvements and items of equipment.

Trusting both these matters may receive your early and sympathetic consideration, I remain,

Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary M.S.C.C.

Re: Indian Residential School - Carcross, Y.T.

1. I have the honour to report that on August 7th, 1934, I inspected the above mentioned School and found everything in order, and every evidence to indicate affairs were being conducted in accordance with the Department's wishes.

2. The School is now full, 40 pupils, the number the Department is willing to allow the per capita grant, and during my visit I found that every precaution was being taken for their safety and to guard against epidemics. Those present appeared to be well nourished, well clothed, and in every way happy and contented.

3. Upon examining the main building I found most of the woodwork of the exterior badly in need of paint, particularly the shingles of the roof and at the gables and base, they are commencing to warp and unless some action is taken next year to repaint these I am afraid they will have to be replaced later on.

4. Several small outbuildings are in need of a coat of paint to preserve the woodwork; the icehouse is of new lumber and has not received a coat of paint since it was erected.

5. Upon inspecting the dormitories I found them clean and well ventilated, the bed linen was in good condition and properly laundered, but I found the steeds sadly in need of paint; they are badly chipped and look very unpresentable, and a primary coat of white paint with enamel finish would vastly improve them.

6. Upon inspecting the wash rooms in both the boys and girls dormitories, I found the two baths in each compartment in need of replacement, the linings are of zinc, they are old and appear to me to be very unsanitary. My recommendation is that white enamel linings should be installed, or at least new zinc ones.

7. To place this Institution in a good state of repair I attach hereto a list of requirements, quoting approximate cost of material and labour, which I respectfully recommend for consideration, and if approved that the work be done next spring.

Your obedient servant,

[T.B. Caulkin] A/Supt.,
Dept. of Indian Affairs

Memorandum: The Honourable the Superintendent General,

A telegram has been received this morning advising that serious leaks have appeared in the low pressure sectional boiler used for heating the Carcross Indian Residential School, Yukon.

Same has been examined by a qualified Engineer who advises the immediate installation of four new sections at an estimated cost of $200.00 for materials and $150.00 for labour. The labour will be performed by the local engineer who is postponing a trip outside awaiting instructions to commence work. He is the only local man qualified to undertake same.

In dismantling the boiler to install the new sections it may be found so badly corroded inside through the use of hard water that a new boiler will be required.

The present boiler has been in use for 23 years, and is the only means of heating the school. I would recommend for your consideration that the School be authorized to purchase the new sections and if the boiler can be repaired to install them. If beyond repair to install a new sectional boiler. It will be necessary to wire instructions as soon as possible on account of the lateness of the season.

[Signature]

Sir:

Enclosed herewith you will find confirmation of telegram sent to you on the 28th inst. relative to the breakdown in our heating plant. Your reply was received authorizing the new sections etc., to be purchased; the work of installation to be done at an estimated cost of $150.00 and is necessary the purchase of a new boiler. As soon as the necessary authority was received telegram (copy of which is enclosed) was sent to Alcock, Manning and Wright Co. Ltd. of Vancouver. A copy of the reply is enclosed and from it you will see the advisability of ordering a new boiler instead of new sections. A copy of the wire ordering a new boiler is also enclosed merely for your information. The decision to order a new boiler was urged upon us by the following considerations which I am sure will commend themselves to the Department of Indian Affairs and to you as their representative:

1. Winter is here and whilst we have had no cold weather yet such may be expected any day.

2. If new sections were ordered and they would have to come from Toronto they would not likely reach us until after December 18th which would be leaving things rather late.

3. If when taking the old boiler apart to install the new sections when received in the latter part of December, it was found other parts would be necessary it is almost certain that these also would have to be obtained from Toronto which would mean a further delay of over a month. The risk of having such a delay at such a time was felt could not be taken.

4. It will be noted from one of the telegrams enclosed that the cost of four new sections is almost $400.00 F. O. B. Vancouver. Comparing this with the price of a new boiler $655.20 F. O. B. Vancouver it seems more economical to invest in a new boiler rather than to patch one up that has been in service twenty-three years.

5. The engineer of the White Pass and Yukon Railway who examined the boiler felt that the interior was badly incrusted with scale so that it was this scale that was responsible for the sections cracking and leaking. Of course the real state of the boiler cannot be ascertained until the boiler is taken down and this cannot be done until we have the wherewithal on hand to carry out the repairs necessary or a new boiler on hand ready to be installed. The furnace is going too hot but only a slow fire can be kept which is just sufficient to keep a certain degree of warmth throughout the building at this time of the year. Of one thing the examining engineer was convinced and that was that it would not be safe to carry on through the winter with the boiler in the condition it is. It might give way during the cold weather when more or less heavy firing is imperative.
The foregoing is respectfully submitted for your information and it is hoped that the action taken in ordering a new boiler will meet with the approval of the Department of Indian Affairs which you represent.

I am enclosing herewith application for a refund of $9.50 this being the amount expended to date on telegrams to Vancouver concerning the breakdown in our heating system.

Thanking you for the promptitude in which you have dealt with this situation,

I remain,

Yours respectfully,

(signed)

H. C. M. Grant,
Principal

Labour Installing Boiler............................. 150.00

$1138.04

Mr. J. Rose has requested that the cheque in payment of his labour be mailed to him in Vancouver. Will you kindly pass on this request of his to the Department of Indian Affairs at Ottawa.

Every effort has been made to keep the cost of this work as low as possible. Mr. J. Rose was charging at the rate of $1.50 per hour and in order to cut down the number of hours three men on the staff including myself worked with him all the time. Then in order to cut down expense further we undertook to cover the boiler with asbestos without Mr. Rose's assistance.

To support my action in purchasing a new boiler I beg to quote from a letter received from Mr. J. Rose, dated Nov. 1st:

"I note that you have ordered a new boiler which I consider is the best way out of this matter, seeing that the price of your new sections come to such a high figure, and also that when a thorough examination of the remaining sections is made..."
we may find them in an unsafe condition and it would be poor business to install three or four new sections to the remaining old ones.

In considering the question of ordering new sections for the old boiler or a new boiler the possibility occurred to me that if four new sections had been ordered for the old boiler at a cost of $400.00 F.O.B. Vancouver and they could not be fitted to the old boiler so as to give a reliable and safe heating-plant then we would have on the premises material costing considerably over $400.00 the disposal of which would be a problem.

It is doubtful if the shippers would permit the four sections being returned seeing that they would have been a special order (the old boiler Gurney #939 is now off the market). If they were returnable then without a doubt the Department of Indian Affairs would be expected to meet the freight charges both ways which would be considerable judging by the freight charges on the new boiler one way. ($215.65). Sooner than take the risk of having such a situation arise which might have meant useless and unnecessary expenses to the Department of Indian Affairs a new boiler was ordered.

Trusting that all the enclosures reach you safely and prove to be in order,

I remain,

Yours respectfully,

(signed)

H. C. M. Grant, Principal

REPORT ON NEW BOILER INSTALLED AT THE CARCROSS INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL 1934.

The new boiler S-30-9 Gurney New Bright Idea has now been in operation for approximately three months and has given every satisfaction. As we have had, during this time, some very cold weather, the coldest being -48.6, the boiler has had a good testing out and its capacity seems quite adequate to heat the school.

There is one good feature of this boiler worth noting and that is the rapidity with which steam can be raised. This will be a decided advantage in the fall and spring of the year when constant firing is not required.

At Carcross the Chooutla Indian Residential School is located and I made a tour of inspection of this school last August, finding everything in order and every evidence of the school being conducted in accordance with the Department's wishes. Regular fire drills are maintained and a very competent staff is in charge of the pupils, who appeared to be well nourished and clothed, and everything possible done for their welfare. In regard to this School I would refer to my Inspection Report of August 30th, 1934, wherein I recommended that certain repairs were considered necessary for the proper maintenance of the buildings, which I hope the Department will be able to approve this coming summer.

The pupils attending this school are gathered from all points in the Agency, the girls being trained domestically, and the boys in farming and other useful occupations and the progress made amply justifies its existence.

1. I am in receipt of the following communication from the Principal of the Residential School at Carcross Y.T.

"One of the most pressing needs at this school now, and it has been so for many years, is the need of a Horse Power Hay Press. It would be appreciated if you would bring the need of this item of equipment to the attention of the Department of Indian Affairs and urge them to sanction the purchase of one before this year's hay cutting season commences. Most of our hay has to be cut at a considerable distance from the school and brought from that point to the school by water. Such a means of transportation certainly indicates strongly that the hay must be put up in bales. For the last few years we have managed to get the loan of a home made hay press the property of the man upon whose meadows we are permitted to cut hay. The fact that this hay press does not work at all satisfactorily and is often needed by the owner at the time we need it, makes such an arrangement decidedly inconvenient especially seeing that the time, when navigation is open, is very short. Such a Horse Power Hay Press as is urgently needed would cost approximately $600.00 F.O.B. Carcross."

2. I expect to be in Carcross in the very near future and will take this matter up with the Principal, but am forwarding this request for your consideration and would recommend that if at all possible, a Hay Press as asked for should be supplied to this School.

Your obedient servant,

G. Binning, A/Supt.

July 17th

re:- Carcross Indian Residential School

I beg to report that I visited the Indian Residential School at Carcross Y.T. on June 30th, and the following is a report of conditions found.

Buildings.
These consist of the main school, workshops, and barns and are all the property of the Department. The Principal's residence which is just outside the fence surrounding the school property belongs to the Church authorities. All buildings were found in a good state of repair, except that the roofs and doors require painting, authority has now been obtained for these to be done.

MEALS.
The meals served appear to be wholesome, varied and well cooked. I was present when meals were being served and all the pupils appeared to enjoy their meals. Excellent bread, both white and whole meal, is made at the school under the supervision of the kitchen matron. The store room and kitchen were found in very clean condition, as also was the pupils dining room. The store room was well stocked with provisions, an ample supply of fresh vegetables is produced generally sufficient to carry them through the winter. Milk and fresh eggs are obtained from the stock kept at the school.

CLOTHING.
The pupils are well and warmly clothed and very neat in appearance. There was a good supply of clothing in the store room, both for boys and girls.

TRAINING.
The pupils receive good training in manual work. The girls are taught cooking, laundry work, knitting and to make and repair their clothing, also personal cleanliness and in their surroundings. The boys are taught the first principles of farming, care of the stock, carpentry, shoe repairing and some sewing to enable them to repair their own clothing if necessary.

CLEANLINESS.
Every room and dormitory in the building was closely inspected and all found to be spotlessly clean and everything neatly in its place. Each pupil has a small rack in the washroom for the tooth brush, soap and tooth brush, and all pupils clean their teeth at least twice each day under the supervision of the matron. The grounds surrounding the school are kept free from litter of all kinds, the pupils being taught to bring in all their sports equipment and put them in the places reserved for it, so the grounds are always tidy.
HEALTH.

The general health of the pupils has been good during the past year, with the exception of a mild epidemic of influenza in the spring; every pupil suffered from this and it was necessary to close the school for a short time. Several minor accidents happened to the pupils during the year, but all made good recovery. Every care is taken by the staff to ensure as far as possible the health of the children under their care, close attention being paid to proper ventilation and other hygienic matters.

Training in School.

It was reported to me that the pupils are very attentive in the school room, a good average of marks being obtained in the various subjects. I was shown samples of writing and other work and it was very creditable.

DISCIPLINE.

The discipline of the pupils is excellent, they are orderly, obedient and attentive and their deportment is very good; this is very evident in the fire drill, they are quick and respond to the alarm in an orderly manner. The staff and pupils appear to be familiar with what each should do in case of fire.

REQUIREMENTS.

I went into the matter of requirements very closely with the Principal, these were kept as low as possible but the following are considered essential.

1 Singer Sewing Machine, to replace one badly worn out and which is causing lots of trouble in doing necessary work.

4 White Enamel Bath Tubs, to replace 4 old tin bath tubs at present in use, these are unsanitary and unsightly, and nothing can be done to them to improve them, these bath tubs are urgently required.

1 Team Hay Mower is required, this would cost approximately $100.00 and would be very useful.

Iron fire escape stairs should be installed instead of the present perpendicular iron ladders now in use. These ladders are in my opinion unsuitable for use with so many young children and consideration should be given to installing proper fire escape stairs. I am unable to estimate what the cost of alteration would be.

Repairs to leaking steam pipes, would cost approximately $20.00.

Set of Fire Backs for McClary Hotel Range No 29-41.

20 yards Light Brown Battleship Linoleum for table tops in the dining rooms.

Repairs to piping in Laundry, approximately $15.00.
GENERAL REMARKS.

I am satisfied that the Principal and staff are doing all in their power to make the life of the pupils comfortable and instill into them the necessary training for their future. Some of the girls appeared exceptionally smart at their work in the kitchen. The number of pupils has been well maintained, and it may safely be said that the school has had a successful year and is doing splendid work. There appears to be a growing appreciation of the school among the Indians generally.

Your obedient servant,

G. Binning,
Supt.,
Dept Indian Affairs.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

I desire to direct your attention to the very urgent need of increased accommodation at our Choutla School at Carcross in the Yukon. You will recall that for some years past our Commission have referred to this need in the comprehensive list of requirements submitted to your Department towards the close of each year in the following terms:

"Two storey annex to the rear side of main building, the upper storey to be used as a chapel and assembly room, and the lower storey as a laundry. At present this school has no chapel, no special laundry room or modern laundry equipment, and no recreation room. Where the winters are so long all of these are very necessary. A room in the basement has to serve as laundry and boys' recreation room. The girls use the sewing room as a recreation room.

Estimated cost $10,000.00.

N.B. (In connection with this requirement the Society's Field Secretary desires to direct the attention of the Department to the interview which he had with the Supt. of Indian Education on May 15th, 1929, and on Sept. 17th, 1930, when the same was considered, and the Supt. requested that a special note be made in our list of requirements of the urgency of this particular need. See letter June 18th, 1930, #166-1-5, addressed to Mr. Indian Agent Supt. Hawksley by the Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.)
In a letter recently received from the Rev. H. C. M. Grant, Principal of this school, and dated Carcross, July 24, 1934, he writes, in part, as follows:

"I would like to draw the attention of the Commission to the fact that the accommodation at this school is not adequate for the number of children seeking admission nor for the number that could be obtained. Bishop Geddes informed me yesterday that he could have obtained 25 new children for the school during his travels this summer but that nothing could be done for them seeing that our accommodation is taxed to the uttermost. Three children were brought down from Ross River to Fort Selkirk, a distance of 250 miles, in the hope that they would be taken in here but when the Agent (Captain G. Binning, R.C.M.P. of Dawson) was wired he had to reply to the effect that the school was full. At the present time there are 40 children in residence allowing for those who have been and will be discharged this year. As there are several children whose applications for admission have already gone in it is likely that the school will have an enrolment of 45 during the next academic year.................. A month or so ago this school was inspected by Colonel Pragnell who is Inspector of Indian Agencies for B.C. He felt that this school was by no means large enough for the area it has to serve. I believe that he intends to embody this view in his report to the Department. Bishop Geddes also feels that the accommodation of this school should be increased. In view of the situation that has arisen it is to be sincerely hoped that something may be done in this connection soon."

If the enlargement of the existing school building cannot be undertaken this year, owing to lack of funds, or for any other reason whatever, our Commission would very earnestly request that the official capacity of the school be increased from 40 to 45 pupils, in order that we may be able to provide help for some of those Indians who desire their children to be admitted to this institution.

Your careful and sympathetic consideration of this important matter will be duly appreciated by me and by our Commission, as well as by all others directly concerned.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

In a letter, dated Carcross, Yukon, August 29th, the Rev. Principal H. C. M. Grant, directs the attention of our Commission to the difficulty he is having in securing sufficient moose meat for his school. It would appear from the Principal's letter that the chief difficulty arises from the fact that an Indian in the Yukon is not allowed to sell meat unless he has a Commercial License which costs $25.00 a year, and as scarcely any of the Indians can afford to pay this amount they have no market for their meat.

The Principal states that he had learned from the Rev. J. Hawksley for some time Superintendent of Indian Affairs in the Yukon, that during his ten years of office a special permit was granted the Carcross School to buy meat for its own use from any Indian whether he had a commercial license or not, and he suggests that a similar permit might now be secured for the same purpose by your Department from the Department of Justice.

As the school has no cold storage facilities, there is a possibility the school might be offered more meat at a time than it required, and the Rev. Principal Grant suggests, as an alternative to the arrangement mentioned above that it would be better to have the permit issued to Mr. Watson, a local merchant in the town of Carcross, as he has cold storage facilities, and the school could secure moose meat from him as required.

Our Commission will be obliged if you will give this important matter your careful consideration, and take whatever steps may lie within your power to help the management of our Carcross School in securing a regular and adequate supply of the meat so much needed for the Indian children in residence.
Your obedient servant,

T.B.R.W./W

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C

P.S. As an alternative to the suggestion made above may I refer you to your letter to me on June 24th, 1930, No. 600245; re a somewhat similar situation at our Moose Factory School. T.B.R.W.

Sir,

I acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 15th ultimo, File 3029, enclosing correspondence relative to a request from the Principal of the Carcross Indian School, to secure fresh moose meat under certain conditions.

It is noted that in the copy of the letter from the Field Secretary, M.S.C.C., to the Secretary of the Department of Indian Affairs, it is stated:

1st. That the chief difficulty in securing a sufficient supply of moose meat for the residential Indian School at Carcross arises from the fact that an Indian in the Yukon is not allowed to sell meat unless he has a hunter's license which costs $25.00.

2nd. That the Principal of the School has stated that he has been informed that during the period of ten years when Reverend John Hawskley was Indian Agent for the Yukon, a special permit was granted the Carcross School to buy meat for its own use from any Indian, whether he had a hunting license or not.

3rd. That owing to the fact that the school has no cold storage facilities, and since Mr. Watson, a local merchant in Carcross, has such, that the latter be issued some kind of special permit allowing him to handle the game for the school.

It has always appeared to me that the Yukon Game Ordinance is very liberal in its application to the Indian population of the Territory, and that a sufficient provision is made to enable them to obtain game for food at all times of the year; and further, that the restrictions preventing them from killing moose and caribou for sale during the closed season are necessary.

The Game Ordinance does not vest any authority in the Commissioner to issue any kind of special permit, without fee, to Indians or white people, to kill moose or caribou at all times of the year and sell the same to any institution or class of people. And, although it is intimated that such a permit was issued at some time in the past, I have no knowledge of the same having been done, and I can find no record of such a permit having been issued.

It is quite possible for the institution which I believe receives a liberal per capita grant for the maintenance of the Indian children to obtain a supply of moose meat under the provisions of the Game Ordinance. The merchant referred to has no cold storage, and it would be contrary to the provisions of the Game Ordinance to permit this merchant, as has been suggested, to have moose meat in his possession during the closed season, buying the same from any and all Indians. Even if it were permissible under the Ordinance, I would consider such a proceeding dangerous and likely to lead to all kinds of difficulties.

Yours truly,

Sgd. G.A. Jeckell,
Comptroller.

J. Lorne Turner, Esq.,
Director,
Lands, North West Territories and Yukon Br.,
Department of the Interior,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

With further reference to your letter of the 12th October, file 166-1-5, dealing with the representations made to your Department for modification of the game regulations of the Yukon Territory to enable the Carcross school authorities to secure sufficient fresh meat for their requirements, I now enclose copy of a report from Mr. G. I think you will agree that it would be preferable if the representative of the M.S.C.C. at Carcross, Y.T., were to call upon Mr. Jeckell when convenient and discuss the situation with him. Dear Sir:

re: enlargement of the Carcross School.

With further reference to my letter of August 17th, 1935, and your reply to the same on August 21st, 1935, No. 166-1-5 re. the building of an addition to our Carcross School, I beg to state that our Commission requested the Principal to secure from a local builder and contractor plans and specifications for the addition in question, and enclosed herewith you will find the original of those prepared and submitted by Mr. J.E. French, of White Horse, Yukon. You will note that the estimated cost of the addition to the main school building is $8,000.00.

As the report of Col. J.S. Pragnell, Inspector of Indian Agencies, dated July 31st, 1935, and made after he visited this school, stated that he understood there were "probably over 1500 Indians in the Yukon and several hundreds in adjoining British Columbia territory, with over 300 of School age," there can be no doubt about the need of the addition requested above, and our Commission sincerely trust that it may be provided during the current calendar year 1936.

Further, as the Inspector of Indian Agencies, in the report mentioned above, recommended the provision of a small out-building for the home-curing of bacon, the Principal of our Carcross School was requested to secure an estimate of the cost of this, and you will note that the estimate given by Mr. French is $300.00.

Our Commission recommend both of these urgent needs to the sympathetic consideration of your Department, and trust that funds may be made available to provide them this year.

I have the honour to be Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

Dear Sir:

You are aware from previous correspondence of the very urgent need of a hay baler for our Carcross School in Yukon, where the chief hay supply is located about ten or twelve miles from the school and the hay has to be brought in by scow. Our Commission has received what is considered an exceptionally good offer from the International Harvester Co. in Winnipeg, namely, a one horse hay-baler which was sold to a farmer in 1934, but who could not pay for the same. As he used it during one season only when he baled 30 tons, it is guaranteed to be almost as good as new. This baler is offered to us for $189.00. As it weighs approximately 2000 lbs., the freight charges from Winnipeg to Carcross will be approximately $111.00 making the total cost of the baler f.o.b. Carcross approximately $300.00. As the baler if new would sell in Winnipeg for $292.50, we consider it should be purchased, and our Commission would like to know if your Department will authorize this expenditure. The members feel strongly that on account of the exceptional circumstances created through the remote location of the only hay lands available for the use of this school, your Department should assist them by meeting this expenditure. As the baler should be furnished at once, a prompt reply will oblige.

Enclosed herewith you will find plans received from the Pearson Wire and Iron Works Ltd., of the proposed fire escapes to be erected here. Sir:-

1. During my recent visit to the Indian Residential School at Carcross Y.T., I made a close check of the buildings, equipment etc., with a view of bringing to your notice necessary repairs and requirements for the fiscal year 1937-38, and I now forward my findings so that you may give them consideration when submitting your estimates for 1937-38.

2. ADDITION TO THE PRESENT SCHOOL BUILDING.

At the present time there are 47 Indian children in residence at this school, and there is no doubt that the school is overcrowded, there being beds down the centre of the dormitories and in some cases children are sleeping two in one bed. During recent months several applications for admission to the school have had to be turned down owing to the lack of accommodation. The question of an addition to the school has, I believe, been already drawn to the attention of the Department three or four years ago, and I have no doubt the Department have plans and specifications on file which were submitted by two builders and contractors in Whitehorse for an addition to the school. The estimated cost of the proposed addition has been given as $8,000.00.

3. REPAIRS TO FOUNDATION OF WORK SHOP.

There is no question at all that this work should be done as soon as possible. Owing to a rotten foundation it is easily noticeable that the floor in the centre has sagged considerably, and the condition of the foundations is in evidence by the fact that the peak of the roof slopes towards the middle. An estimated cost of having this work done, supplying all material etc would be $300.00.

4. BUILDING FOR CURING BACON.

A building for the curing of bacon would be a great asset to the school and one could be erected at an estimated cost of $300.00.

5. Singer SEWING MACHINE.

At the present time there are two sewing machines in the school both old, and one of which is giving considerable trouble, another sewing machine would be very acceptable, cost $44.36.

F.O.B. Carcross.
GASOLINE ENGINE.

6. One Gasoline Engine, Fairbanks-Morse, 5-8 H.P., to be used to operate a circular saw. The one the school now possesses is not in very good repair, having given many years service and besides has not sufficient power to do the work it is called upon to do. The cost of a new engine would be in the neighbourhood of $275.00.

7. CIRCULAR CORD WOOD SAW.

One Circular Cord wood Saw at an estimated cost of $25.00. The saw the school own at present has been in use for over five years and the constant sharpening necessary has shortened the teeth to such an extent that it is difficult to work with it.

8. PAINTING OUTSIDE OF SCHOOL.

During the past fiscal year the Department allowed a grant to cover the cost of staining the shingles on the outside of the building and it is felt that the siding, window frames etc should be painted in the near future so as to preserve this wood work. The cost of having this done would be in the vicinity of $450.00 and would include the cost of the paint and oil necessary and the painting of the outbuildings as well, all with two coats of paint.

9. Trusting that the above requirements will meet with your approval.

Your obedient servant,

G. Binning,
A/Supt.,
Dept Indian Affairs.

Sir,

I am in receipt of a letter from the Principal of the Indian Residential School at Carcross, which reads in part:

"As several of the Indian Residential Schools under the administration of the Anglican Church and those under the administration of other denominations have been authorized by the Department of Indian Affairs to engage the services of a night watchman, it is strongly felt that such a privilege should be accorded to this school. During the past six years we have had a night watchman such position being filled by the elder school boys, each boy when taken sick at times. At the present time there are no big boys in the school who could do the work as it should be done and we are really up against it unless the Department will come to our assistance. It seems as if night watchmen are regarded as necessary in other schools where the winter may not be as long or severe as they are in the Yukon one is certainly necessary here. During the night fires have to be kept going not only in the school furnace but in the workshop, chicken house and pig pen and so it can be seen that there is an ever present danger of fire. The employment of a night watchman would be a great protection to Government property here and besides assure the children and staff that every precaution possible is taken for their safety.

In a wooden frame building of this nature once a fire got started it would be almost impossible to put it out and the presence of explosion electric wiring (not in the building) the gas lighting plant, gasoline water pump actually in the school building makes the risk from fire even greater. It would be greatly appreciated if you would take this matter up with the Department of Indian Affairs and recommend that each winter the Principal be authorised to employ someone as night watchman. It is suggested that a position of this nature be filled from October 15th to April 15th a period of six months and that the salary be $40.00 per month."

ends.

I would strongly recommend that favourable consideration be given to this request of the Principal.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, December 30, 1936.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 11th instant, regarding the repairs and requirements for the coming fiscal year at the Carcross Indian Residential School.

With reference to the supplying of a sewing machine, I have to inform you that an order is being placed here with the Singer Sewing Machine Company to supply, from the nearest branch office, one Singer sewing machine, household type. This machine will be shipped to the Principal, Carcross, Yukon Territory. The account, in triplicate, covering the cost of the machine, will be sent you, and I would request that you certify same in the usual manner and forward to the Department for payment, after you are assured that the machine has been received at the school, in good condition.

Referring to your letter of the 10th instant, regarding the request of the Principal to be supplied with a new bake oven and giving an estimate of the cost, I have to say that the Department will have no funds during the present fiscal year to authorize the supplying of the oven. I may add that it is doubtful if it will be possible to provide the funds from the appropriation for the fiscal year 1937-38 to supply this equipment.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie.

G. Binning, Esq.,
In charge, Indian Office,
Dawson, Yukon.
Ottawa, December 30, 1936.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 11th instant, regarding the request of the Principal of the Carcross Indian Residential School for a grant towards the salary of a night watchman for a six month period, from October 15th to April 15th.

In this connection I have to say that the Department provides grants towards salary of a night watchman for a number of the Indian residential schools at which there is a certain element of fire hazard. The amount usually allowed for this service is $40.00 per month. The Department will approve of the Principal arranging for the engagement of a fully competent person to carry out the duties as night watchman for the balance of the present winter months, to April 15th, next, and will allow a grant of $40.00 per month towards payment of salary. This grant will be paid to the Principal at the end of each month, upon receipt of a voucher, in triplicate, from you, in favour of the Principal, for the amount due. For your information, I enclose a sample voucher, which you should submit at the end of each month, when a cheque in payment will be sent the Principal. It is to be understood that the Principal will engage the services of a fully competent man to carry out the night watchman's duties.

Early next fall, the Principal should renew his request for a grant for this service, when favourable consideration will be given to providing the grant for the period from October 15th to April 15th following.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie.

G. Binning, Esq.,
In charge, Indian Office,
Dawson, Yukon.

DEPUTY MINISTER.

Inspector G. Binning, R.C.M.P., Dawson, Yukon, who looks after the Indian work, has just forwarded the following radiogram:

"Following received from Principal Indian School Garcross: Mr. French builder and contractor has carefully examined basement and foundation of workshop found same deplorable condition. Basement caved in and many fills completely rotted. To put same in condition to last many years will cost approximately $950. for labour and all materials. Basement requires enlarging and concrete walls and floors. Many foundation fills have to be renewed. As basement only place for storing vegetables work should be completed not later than August 1. Stand to lose crop if work not done before freeze up (STOP). I strongly recommend that authority be granted for this work as I examined this building two weeks ago and found repairs necessary."

Provision has been made in our Appropriation for the current fiscal year for the sum of $1,200 for repairs and improvements at the Garcross Indian Residential School, Yukon Territory. In view of the Principal's request and the recommendation of Inspector Binning, I would appreciate receiving your authority to authorize Inspector Binning to proceed with the necessary work.

You will note from the radiogram that repairs should be completed before August first.

Acting Director.

Dear Sir:

During my recent visit to our Carcross School I noted the following urgent needs, and at a meeting of our Commission, held on the 13th inst., I was instructed to place the same before you and ascertain what help you could provide towards meeting them:

1. A root-house. This could be secured through the enlargement of the space under the workshop now used for this purpose. A full-sized basement with stone walls and a good floor would provide the storage required. (Estimated cost approximately $500.00)

2. An Ice-house. The small building attached to the back of the main school building and now used for this purpose, is too small, and is by no means heat-proof. It could be made to serve as a bacon-curing house if a new ice-house were available. (Estimated cost of ice-house approximately $800.00)

3. Road around the cut-bank of the creek in front of the School, or the construction of a causeway with a short bridge, over the same. Either undertaking would shorten the distance to the Carcross station by approximately half a mile, and eliminate the danger and fatigue of the existing road over a steep sand hill. (Estimated cost $100.00)

4. New residence for the Principal. The foundations of the present building are decayed, and the cost of
repairs and necessary improvements might better be applied to a new structure. (Estimated cost $2,500.00)

(5) An increase in the official capacity of the School from 40 to 50. The pupils in residence at present number 47, and more are available for admission. Here, as at a number of our Society's other Schools, the increased accommodation required could be provided through the building of a detached classroom, thus making the existing classroom available for a dormitory. (The estimated cost of the new classroom is $2,500.00)

6. The placing of all electric wiring in conduits it is felt should be undertaken in the very near future. There is a considerable fire risk having exposed wiring all over the building, especially in the attic. It would not be advisable to attempt here and now to give an estimate of the cost without first getting information from an experienced electrician.

7. Refrigerator for the School kitchen. This is essential for keeping fresh milk, butter, meat, and other foods. (Estimated cost $50.00)

Dear Sir:

1. During my recent visit to the Indian Residential Village School at Carcross, Y.T., I made a close check of all supplies, equipment, etc., with a view of bringing to your notice the necessary repairs and requirements for the fiscal year 1936-39, and I now submit my findings so that you may give the necessary consideration to the estimates submitted for the fiscal year.

2. Repairs to the foundations of the work shop: There is no question at all that this work should be done as soon as possible. Owing to the rotten foundation, it is noticeable that the floor in the centre has sagged considerably and the condition of the foundation is such that the peak of the roof slopes towards the middle. The estimated cost of the work required, supplying all material, etc., will be $500.00.

3. There is a cellar in this building which is used for storing vegetables for winter use, and the suggestion has been made that this excavation be made larger, so that the school would have a full sized basement with concrete walls in which to store vegetables for the winter months. The size of this building is 20 x 36, but I cannot determine the cost of this. It would be considerably in excess of the $200.00 already mentioned.

4. Additions to the present school building: At the present time there are 47 Indian children in residence at this school and during recent months, several admissions have had to be turned down. The question of an addition to the school has I believe, been drawn to the attention of the Department three or four months ago and mentioned by me in my report of October 13th, 1936. The estimated cost of the proposed addition, of which, I understand the plans are on file in your office at Ottawa, is approximately $8000.00. If the building of this addition cannot be carried out in the near future, could the capacity of this school be increased from 40 to 50 pupils. This could be accomplished by erecting a detached classroom at an estimated cost of $2500.00, and the present class room could be used as a dormitory.

5. A building for curing the bacon is required. At the present time the suggestion has been made that the present building used for storing ice should be turned into a bacon-curing building and a new ice house erected. The cost of erecting this new ice house would be approximately $600.00.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

In reply to your letter of July 27th last, No. 165-1-5, in which you inform me that an amount of $1200.00 has been provided in the current year's appropriation for repairs and improvements at our Carcross School. Of this amount, $950.00 is to be used in putting a basement under the workshop, the same to serve as a root house, and you request information as to how the balance of $250.00 should be expended.

On receipt of your letter, I telegraphed immediately to the Principal of our Carcross School and requested a specific recommendation in this connection. His reply was received here this morning and reads in part, as follows:

"In connection with the extra $250.00 sanctioned by the Department I would recommend one or other of the two following items of equipment. These are given in order of importance and I have particularly urged the Superintendent of Indian Affairs of the Yukon to recommend that the first be installed before the coming winter sets in. The cost of the first is well in excess of $250.00, but I feel that if the Department realize the importance of having a new lighting plant here they will not hesitate to sanction the additional $705.00 required.

1. One new Lighting Plant - 4 K.W. - Lister Diesel - direct current, battery charging generator - multi V - belt driven at a cost of $955.00 F.O.B. Carcross, Yukon. This Plant is highly recommended and can be supplied by Hoffer's Ltd.,
1790 Georgia St., Vancouver, B.C. The price of $955.00 F.O.B. Carcross was quoted by this firm. The reason why I have put this item of equipment first is that the present Delco Plant, after fourteen years of service, is very costly to operate. Each year gasoline costs the school about $1,100.00 - 2,000 gallons @ 55¢ per gallon. At a safe estimate I would say that at least 80% of this amount is used in the Delco Plant. Hoffar's Ltd. state that the cost of operating a Lister-Diesel - the type that is required here - is only about one sixth of that of a Delco Plant. The low cost of operation is also strongly stressed by a local electrician in the employ of Mr. W.L. Phelps, K.C., Manager of the Yukon Electrical Company. The installation of a new plant of this type would mean a saving to the Commission of approximately $750.00 a year.

2. One Gasoline Engine - Fairbanks-Morse - 7½ H.P. Type "Z" Style to be used to operate a circular saw. The one the School now possesses is not in the best of repair having given many years of service and besides has not sufficient power to do the work it is called upon to do. The cost of a new engine would be, according to a quotation received from the Fairbanks-Morse Co. Ltd. of Vancouver, $238.40 F.O.B. Carcross, Yukon."

Of the need of the new Lighting Plant there can be no doubt, but as I have already referred fully to this in my letter of July 19th last, I need not repeat what was stated therein. If the additional amount required could possibly be found, the installation of the new Lighting Plant would add greatly to the safety and comfort of the School management and pupils, and also help to reduce considerably the heavy operating cost of this School. Where the nights are so long for so great a part of the year, the importance of having an efficient lighting system cannot easily be over-estimated, and I trust that some way may be found of providing the one which the Reverend Principal Grant has recommended.

Faithfully yours,

Dear Sir:

During the present fiscal year the Department was asked to supply one new bake oven at an estimated cost of $548.59 F.O.B. Carcross, Yukon. As this request was not granted the same has been asked for during the next fiscal year. The question of a new bake oven was discussed with the Secretary during his visit to the school in the spring of this year and his suggestion was made to have the present oven carefully examined with a view to ascertaining whether the installation of new parts would put it in good working order. On my return to the school after the holidays this examination was made and we are convinced that the installation of new parts would make the oven as good as new and render the school many more years of service. A list of the parts needed was made and I wrote to the Brantford Oven and Rack Company, Brantford, Ont., for a quotation on the same. Their reply reads in part as follows:

Item 1. 1 Complete Fire Box for wood or coal, as described in your letter.................. $60.00

Item 2. 2 Cast Iron pipes which lead away one from each side of the Fire Box known as our #147 pipes.................. $4.00
Item 3. 2 Cast Iron Boxes as described in the fourth paragraph of your letter, known by us as No. 181A boxes.................. $6.00

Item 4. 1 Oven Thermometer which would be a 6" stem Palmer Angle Mercury Thermometer........................................... $12.50

Item 5. 1 25# can of #30 cement................................. $2.25

$84.75

"The prices given are all Government Sales Tax extra @ 8¢. If applicable to you please advise when ordering."

The freight charges on the repair parts etc. listed above would be approximately $20.60 making a total estimated cost of $105.35. The Brantford Oven and Rack Company Ltd. state that they carry these parts in stock and are in a position to make immediate delivery.

It would be greatly appreciated if you would take up this matter with the Department asking them to authorize the immediate purchase of the parts required. I am convinced that if these new parts are not installed in the near future it will only be a very short time before the whole oven will be beyond repair. The examination that was made of this oven showed that the cast iron pipes #147, boxes No. 181A were completely burnt out and that the fire box sheeting was gone and the fire bricks badly cracked. The Kitchen Matron is badly hampered in her work by having to use a bake oven that smokes badly and blackens everything that is placed therein.

Yours respectfully,

(Sgd) H.C.M. Grant

P.S. I may also add that having to use this oven in its present condition is dangerous for the point of view of fire risk. The oven space in the Kitchen Range is not adequate for baking the amount of bread that is required here.

MEMORANDUM:

DEPUTY MINISTER,

Inspector G. Binning, R.C.M.P., Dawson, Yukon, who looks after the Indian work, has just forwarded the following radiogram:

"Following received from Principal Indian School Carcross: Mr. French builder and contractor has carefully examined basement and foundation of workshop found same deplorable condition. Basement caved in and many fills completely rotted. To put same in condition to last many years will cost approximately $950. for labour and all materials. Basement requires enlarging and concrete walls and floors. Many foundation fills have to be renewed. As basement only place for storing vegetables work should be completed not later than August 1. Stand to lose crop if work not done before freeze up (STOP). I strongly recommend that authority be granted for this work as I examined this building two weeks ago and found repairs necessary."

Provision has been made in our Appropriation for the current fiscal year for the sum of $1,200 for repairs and improvements at the Carcross Indian Residential School, Yukon Territory. In view of the Principal's request and the recommendation of Inspector Binning, I would appreciate receiving your authority to authorize Inspector Binning to proceed with the necessary work.

You will note from the radiogram that repairs should be completed before August first.

Acting Director.
